questions.text: A 40-year-old man underwent kidney transplantation. Two months after transplantation, he developed fever and features suggestive of bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
• CMV pneumonitis typically occurs 1-6 months post-transplant in the absence of effective prophylaxis.
  • Peak incidence around 6-12 weeks (2-3 months) after organ transplant when immunosuppression is maximal.
  • CMV reactivation or primary infection in the immunocompromised host leads to invasive disease.
  • Interstitial pneumonitis presents with fever, dyspnea, dry cough, and bilateral fine reticular or ground-glass opacities on imaging.
  • CMV infects alveolar epithelial and endothelial cells → mononuclear infiltrates, "owl's eye" nuclear inclusions on histopathology.
  • Diagnostic Clues:
    • Elevated CMV viral load (PCR) in blood or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.
    • Characteristic cells with intranuclear inclusions.
    • Exclude other opportunistic pathogens by negative cultures/PCR for HSV, VZV, and EBV.
  • Other Opportunistic Viruses in Transplant:
    • HSV and VZV pneumonitis are rare post-renal transplant; more common in bone marrow transplant patients or with severe T-cell dysfunction. (Options C & D ruled out)
    • EBV is associated with post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) rather than primary pneumonitis. (Option A)
  • Risk Factors & Prevention:
    • High-dose corticosteroids, lymphocyte-depleting antibodies, and mismatched CMV serostatus (donor CMV+ → recipient CMV-) increase risk.
    • Prophylactic valganciclovir or preemptive ganciclovir therapy reduces incidence

Key Takeaways:

  • CMV is the most likely cause of bilateral interstitial pneumonitis around 2 months post-kidney transplant.
  • Recognize timing ("2 months post-transplant") and immunosuppression level as clues for CMV involvement.
  • Prophylaxis with valganciclovir and surveillance PCR are critical to prevent CMV disease in transplant recipients.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paraesthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• The great or long saphenous vein is formed by the union of the medial end of the dorsal venous arch with the medial marginal vein which drains the medial side of the great toe.
  • It passes upwards in front of the medial malleolus, crosses the lower one-third of the medial surface of the tibia obliquely, and runs along its medial border to reach the back of the knee.
  • The saphenous nerve runs in front of the great saphenous vein.
  • The saphenous nerve is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve
  • It supplies the skin of the medial side of the leg and the medial border of the foot up to the ball of the great toe.

Cutaneous nerves on the front of the leg and the dorsum of the foot are as follows:

In coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the great saphenous vein is commonly harvested. Due to its proximity, the saphenous nerve is at risk of iatrogenic injury during vein stripping, leading to:

  • Paresthesia
  • Sensory loss over the medial leg and foot

Explanation of other options:

(A) Sural nerve:

Supplies posterolateral leg and lateral foot, not the medial leg or foot. It runs with the small saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

(B) Superficial peroneal nerve:

Innervates the anterolateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot, not the medial side.

(C) Deep peroneal nerve:

Supplies a small area between the first and second toes and anterior leg muscles, unrelated to the medial leg or saphenous vein course.

questions.text: The amount of T in a given sample of DNA is 28%. What will be the amount of G?
questions.solution:
According to Chargaff's rule, in a double-stranded DNA molecule:

  • The amount of adenine (A) equals the amount of thymine (T): A = T
  • The amount of guanine (G) equals the amount of cytosine (C): G = C

If T = 28%, then A = 28% as well.

This totals 56% for A and T combined.

The remaining 44% of the DNA is composed of G and C, and since G = C, each must account for half of the 44%.

So:

G = 22% and C = 22%

Therefore, the amount of guanine (G) is 22%.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old male software engineer presents with complaints of fatigue for the past few weeks. He leads a sedentary lifestyle, spending 12-14 hours daily at a computer. His diet consists mainly of junk food, with minimal intake of fruits and vegetables. On examination, he appears pale. Laboratory tests reveal:
1. Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
2. MCV: 120 fL
What is the most likely underlying etiology of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Our patient is having a macrocytic anemia, which easily rules out options c and d.

  • Macrocytic anemia can be seen in either Folate or Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • The chief source of Vitamin B12 is animal and dairy products.
  • Folic acid however is ubiquitous and is seen in most of the foods, but is easily destroyed by cooking.
  • So in a person who eats junk food and does not consume fruits or vegetables, the most likely cause of macrocytic anemia is folate deficiency.

B12 Deficiency (Option A):

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause macrocytic anemia.

However, B12 deficiency is less likely in this scenario because it typically presents with additional neurological symptoms (e.g., tingling, numbness, balance issues).

Folate Deficiency (Option B):

Folate deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia.

Folate (vitamin B9) is essential for RBC production and DNA synthesis.

Poor dietary intake (especially lacking vegetables and fruits) can lead to folate deficiency.

Given the sedentary lifestyle and junk food consumption, folate deficiency is a plausible explanation.

Acute Blood Loss (Option C):

Acute blood loss can cause anemia, but it typically results in normocytic or microcytic anemia.

The elevated MCV (macrocytosis) doesn't align with acute blood loss.

Sideroblastic Anemia (Option D):

Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by abnormal iron metabolism within RBC precursors. It usually presents with microcytic or normocytic anemia.

Sideroblastic anemia is less likely based on the given information.

In summary, considering the elevated MCV and the lifestyle factors, folate deficiency is the most likely cause of macrocytic anemia in this case

questions.text: A Female presented with anogenital warts with gene studies,and it was found that she is having a high risk of cervical cancer. Which is the most likely virus responsible for high risk of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
• The above three options are low risk. HPV is what mostly causes warts on or around the genitals, mouth and throat.
  • High-risk HPV are 14 in number which are 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 66 and 68.
  • Two of these HPV, 16 and 18 are responsible for most of the HPV related cancers.

questions.text: A patient with paraplegia with an ulcer in the gluteal region. Identify the stage of this wound
questions.solution:
Pressure sores/pressure ulcer/decubitus ulcer

Order of involvement: ischium > greater trochanter> sacrum > heels > lateral malleolus > occiput

These begin with tissue necrosis at a pressure point and develop into a cone-shaped volume of necrotic loss. As many as 10% of acute hospital inpatients will have some degree of pressure sore. The majority affect the elderly and patients with spinal injury or decreased sensibility; 80% of paraplegics will get a pressure sore and 8% die as a result.

The pathogenesis of pressure sores revolves around unrelieved pressure: an increase in local tissue pressure above that of perfusion pressure produces ischaemic necrosis that is directly proportional to the duration and degree of pressure and inversely proportional to the area over which it is applied.

Muscle and fat are more susceptible to pressure than skin. Grade of pressure sore

Grade 1 discolouration of skin (non blanchable erythema) reversible if pressure is relieved

Grade 2 some skin loss top most skin, epidermis and dermis no slough or necrosis

Grade 3 skin necrosis full thickness, slough and necrosis may be present

Grade 4 deep tissue destruction involve bone, tendon, necrosis, slough, or eschar is present

In a patient who has no predisposing factors, management is aimed at debridement and repair of the defect, on the assumption that recurrence will not occur once normal function and sensibility returns. In the paraplegic patient, recurrence is likely, so management should involve a multidisciplinary approach.

Primary treatment involves relieving pressure (special mattress, nursing care, relief of muscle spasm and contractures), optimizing nutrition, correcting anemia and preventing infection.

Surgery involves thorough debridement to promote healing and plastic surgery to reconstruct the defect.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
• The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test performed on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the gold-standard non-treponemal assay for diagnosing neurosyphilis because of its high specificity.
  • A reactive CSF VDRL virtually confirms neurosyphilis; however, sensitivity is moderate (~50-60%), so a negative CSF VDRL does not exclude disease.
  • Role of Other Tests
    • FTA-ABS on CSF (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody-Absorption) is highly sensitive (>95%) but less specific, as it may remain reactive after treated infection or blood-contamination of CSF.
    • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization) assays are typically performed on serum, not validated for CSF evaluation, and are not reliable for neurosyphilis diagnosis.
  • Non-Treponemal vs. Treponemal Tests
    • Non-treponemal tests (VDRL, RPR) detect anticardiolipin antibodies; titers correlate with disease activity and decline after treatment.
    • Treponemal tests (FTA-ABS, TPPA) detect antibodies specific to T. pallidum proteins and remain positive for life after infection.
  • Neurosyphilis Presentation
    • May present as asymptomatic CSF abnormalities, meningitis, vascular (stroke), tabes dorsalis, general paresis, or ocular/otic involvement.
  • CSF Abnormalities
    • Elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and positive CSF VDRL or FTA-ABS.
    • CSF FTA-ABS is used when CSF VDRL is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

Key Takeaways:

  • CSF VDRL is the diagnostic test of choice for neurosyphilis due to its high specificity; a reactive result confirms the diagnosis.
  • CSF FTA-ABS is a highly sensitive adjunct test when CSF VDRL is negative but clinical suspicion persists.
  • Serum RPR/TPI and treponemal tests are not reliable in CSF for neurosyphilis evaluation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of travel to Africa developed jaundice with Hemorrhagic fever and yellow conjunctiva. Despite recieving treatment He unfortunately passed away. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented his death?
questions.solution:
The 17 D vaccine refers to the Yellow Fever vaccine, which is highly effective in preventing Yellow Fever.

Yellow Fever is a viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, and vaccination is crucial for travellers to endemic areas like parts of Africa.

The other options mentioned are strains associated with measles (Nakayama, RA 27/3, Jeryll Lynn)

Yellow Fever

  • Yellow fever is caused by Yellow fever Virus which belongs to Flavivirus family (formerly classified as group B arbovirus)and is a zoonotic disease. It affects principally monkeys and other vertebrates in tropical America and Africa and is transmitted to man by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.
  • Geographical distribution: Yellow fever is endemic in West Africa and Central South America.

Clinical Manifestations

  • The Incubation period is about 3-6 days. Febrile illness occurs in early stage of the disease and characterized by the presence of fever, chills, headache, dizziness, myalgia, and backache-followed by nausea, vomiting, and relative bradycardia.
  • Patient is viremic in this stage and may be a source of infection for mosquitoes.
  • Severe cases are characterized by:
    1. Hemorrhagic manifestations
    2. Platelet dysfunction
    3. Hepatitis: Features of liver involvement are Mid-zonal necrosis and presence of councilman bodies. Intranuclear inclusions may be seen inside the hepatocytes called Torres bodies.
    4. Renal dysfunction
    5. Mortality rate is high (>20%), especially among children and the elderly.

VACCINATION

  • Rapid immunisation of the population at risk is the most effective control strategy for yellow fever. For international use, the approved vaccine is the 17D vaccine.
  • It is a live attenuated vaccine prepared from a non-virulent strain (17D strain), which is grown in chick embryo and subsequently freeze-dried.
  • It has to be stored between +5 and -30 deg.C, preferably below zero deg. C until reconstituted with the sterile, cold physiological saline diluent provided.
  • Reconstituted vaccine should be kept on ice, away from sunlight, and discarded if not used within half an hour.
  • The vaccine is administered subcutaneously at the insertion of deltoid in a single dose of 0.5 ml irrespective of age.
  • Immunity begins to appear on the 7th day and lasts for life.

International certificate of vaccination

  • India and many other countries require a valid yellow fever vaccination certificate from travellers arriving from infected areas. In India, vaccination is also required for infants aged ≥9 months. The certificate becomes valid 10 days post-vaccination.
  • In May 2014, the World Health Assembly amended the International Health Regulations (2005) to extend the validity of yellow fever vaccination certificates from 10 years to lifetime. This change came into effect on 11th July 2016 and is legally binding for all IHR member states.

From this date, revaccination is no longer required for international travel, and the lifetime validity applies to all existing and new certificates, starting 10 days after vaccination.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with the skin lesion shown in the image. He has a pet dog at home. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
The lesion given in the figure depicts a boggy swelling of the scalp with pustules and scarring alopecia, characteristic of Kerion.

  • These are infections by dermatophytic fungi- Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton, which classically infect the skin, hair and nails.
  • These organisms are not a component of the normal skin flora.
  • Several species cause infections in cats and dogs and several of them are found in soil and spread from these two sources.
  • The classical lesion caused is the ringworm. The infection of the scalp is called Tinea Capitis and is caused by Trichophyton tonsurans. T tonsurans and Microsporum canis cause Kerion.
  • Topical therapy is generally ineffective as monotherapy for scalp infections and should be combined with systemic agents.
  • Topical ketoconazole or selenium sulphate along with oral Griseofulvin, terbinafine or Itraconazole is the mainstay of treatment, as systemic therapy is required to penetrate the hair follicles and eradicate the fungal infection effectively.

Epidermoid Cyst: These are non-cancerous bumps that develop beneath the skin. They are usually found on the face, neck, or trunk and are slow-growing and painless. They may have a blackhead plugging the central opening and can leak a thick, cheesy substance if ruptured or removed. They don't typically require treatment unless they become painful or infected.

Abscess: An abscess is a painful, red, swollen infection filled with pus. It can form on the skin or inside the body. Abscesses are usually caused by bacteria and can cause symptoms elsewhere in the body. Unlike cysts, which grow slowly, an abscess can appear quickly and is often accompanied by fever or other systemic symptoms

Folliculitis: This is the inflammation of hair follicles on the skin. It appears as small, red bumps that may have a white, pus-filled tip. Folliculitis can be itchy or irritating and is often caused by bacterial infection, although it can also result from fungal infections, irritation, or physical injury to the hair follicles.

questions.text: In type I DM, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Option A: Correct. In type I DM, the lack of insulin results in unopposed action of counterregulatory hormones like glucagon. This leads to increased lipolysis in adipose tissue. The resulting non-esterified (free) fatty acids are transported to the liver and serve as substrates for ketogenesis, contributing to the development of diabetic ketoacidosis.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • Option B: Incorrect. In the absence of insulin, there is increased protein catabolism. Amino acids released from muscle breakdown are used as substrates for gluconeogenesis in the liver.
  • Option C: Incorrect. Type I DM is characterized by increased hepatic glucose output, not decreased. This is due to enhanced gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver, driven by the unopposed action of glucagon.
  • Option D: Incorrect. Insulin promotes glucose uptake in insulin-sensitive tissues (e.g., muscle and adipose tissue). In type I DM, the absence of insulin leads to decreased glucose uptake, contributing to hyperglycemia.

questions.text: An old man presenting, with tender scrotal swelling, h\o fever present. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Necrotising fasciitis

Fournier's gangrene - scrotum involvement

Meleney's gangrene: anterior abdominal wall involvement

This is progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum. It is usually caused by mixed bacterial flora (Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). It may be associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation or trauma.

Finger probe test can be used to diagnose this condition IOC - skin biopsy - shows micro vascular thrombosis

The hallmark is rapid progression from symptoms and signs of cellulitis. There is erythema, swelling, pain and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions but the testis remain unaffected (due to strong layer of tunica albuginea resistant to infection).

It is a surgical emergency. Progression from genitalia to perineum to abdominal wall occurs extremely rapidly. There is an increased risk of bacterial septicaemia. It will lead to death if untreated.

Treatment involves a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and extensive surgical debridement leads to shameful exposure of testis, hyperbaric o2 therapy is given

Other options:

B. Epididymo orchitis - usually those with underlying UTI, prostatitis

C. Torsion of testis - scrotal tenderness present but no fever

D. Carcinoma of testis - usually painless and commonly occurs in younger individuals

choices.text: Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR
Use MR and discard Pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: ANM has to conduct a vaccination camp in a village and she received 2 open vials of pentavalent vaccine and MR vaccine. What should be done next:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines for vaccination practices in outreach settings, the pentavalent vaccine (which includes DPT, HepB, and Hib) should be prioritized because it has a shorter stability period after opening compared to the MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccine.

The pentavalent vaccine should be used within the same session after opening, whereas the MR vaccine can be used within 6 hours if stored properly.

Therefore, it's recommended to use the pentavalent vaccine and discard the MR vaccine in this scenario.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

OPEN VIAL POLICY:

  • Implementation of open vial policy allows reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under UIP in subsequent session(both fixed and outreach) upto four weeks(28 days) subject to meeting certain conditions and thus reduce vaccine wastage.
  • Open Vial policy applies for:
    1. DPT,
    2. TT,
    3. Hepatitis B,
    4. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV),
    5. Liquid Pentavalent,
    6. PCV and
    7. Injectable IPV.
  • Does not apply to:
    1. Measles/MR, - should be used with 6 hours
    2. BCG, - should be used with 6 hours
    3. Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccines, - should be used within 2 hours
    4. Rotavirus - should be used with 6 hours
    5. Covexin/covishield

Open vaccine vials can be reused for up to 4 weeks if:

  • Expiry date hasn't passed
  • Stored and transported at recommended cold chain temperatures
  • Vial septum is uncontaminated and not submerged in water
  • Aseptic technique was used during withdrawal
  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) hasn't reached discard point
  • Open vials must never be submerged in water, should be labeled with date and time of opening, and returned to the Cold Chain Point after the session.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image
questions.solution:
This is a case of shingles (herpes zoster).

  • Shingles results from reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in dorsal root or cranial nerve ganglia, most often in individuals ≥ 60 years or immunosuppressed.
  • After primary varicella infection in childhood, VZV remains dormant in sensory ganglia.
  • With declining cell-mediated immunity (aging, corticosteroids, HIV, malignancy), VZV reactivates, replicates in neurons, and travels along sensory nerves to the skin.
  • Dermatomal Distribution: Lesions appear as unilateral, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base following a single sensory dermatome. Dermatomes from T3 to L3 and trigeminal nerve (especially ophthalmic branch) are involved.
  • Prodrome & Morphology: Prodromal neuropathic pain (burning, tingling, or stabbing) 1 - 3 days before rash. Vesicles ("dew-drop on a rose petal") emerge in clusters, evolve to pustules, and crust over 7-10 days.

Zoster Ophthalmicus

  • Reactivation in the ophthalmic branch (V1) of the trigeminal ganglion → vesicles on forehead, eyelid, tip of nose (Hutchinson's sign) and risk of keratitis/uveitis.

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus)

  • Reactivation in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (VII) → ipsilateral facial paralysis, vesicles in the ear canal or oropharynx, severe otalgia, possible tinnitus/vertigo.

Complications & Sequelae

  • Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN): Neuropathic pain persisting > 30 days post-rash, more common with advancing age.
  • Secondary Bacterial Infection: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes superinfection of vesicles.
  • Disseminated Zoster: In immunocompromised, > 20 lesions outside primary dermatome or visceral involvement → pneumonia, hepatitis, encephalitis with high morbidity.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Small Pox - Deep, firm pustules in a centrifugal distribution; all lesions at same stage; not dermatomal.
  • Option B: Chicken Pox - disseminated vesicles in various stages; bilateral, widespread; not confined to one dermatome.
  • Option D: Atopic Dermatitis - chronic, pruritic eczematous plaques; no grouped vesicles or neuropathic prodrome.

questions.text: Alzheimer's disease is associated with an increase in which of the following apolipoproteins?
questions.solution:
A hallmark of Alzheimer's disease is the accumulation of β-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain. β-amyloid is a 4.3-kDa polypeptide derived from the proteolytic cleavage of amyloid precursor protein (APP). In Alzheimer's disease, β-amyloid becomes elevated and undergoes a conformational shift from a soluble, α-helix-rich state to a β-sheet-rich structure that is prone to self-aggregation, contributing to plaque formation.

Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) plays a role in modulating this transformation. Among its isoforms:

  • Apo E4 has been strongly associated with an increased risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease.
  • This is because Apo E4 appears to bind more readily to β-amyloid, potentially facilitating its aggregation in the brain.

In contrast, Apo E2 and Apo E3 are either neutral or may confer some protective effect.

Therefore, Option D (Apo E4) is the correct answer.

questions.text: A young male shown in image sustained a stab injury on the Anterolateral aspect of the abdomen and he is presenting with BP - 120\80 mm Hg, PR- 80\minute. The next step in the management is?
questions.solution:
Laparotomy Explanation:

  • Penetrating injury - no role of EFAST
  • UNSTABLE PATIENT (shock, peritonitis, evisceration) - EMERGENCY LAPAROTOMY
  • STABLE PATIENT - LOCAL EXPLORATION OF WOUND → if the peritoneal breech present → additional investigation done (CECT abdomen, serial haemoglobin, diagnostic laparoscopy) and patient is kept in observation for 8 -12 hrs
  • If no peritoneal breech present → patient can be discharged

Most common organ injured in penetrating trauma: LIVER

Most common organ injured in blunt trauma: SPLEEN

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
• Gag reflex: It is a protective reflex characterized by the elevation of the palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles with associated retching and gagging in response to stimulation of the mucous membrane of the Oropharynx.
  • It occurs when the palate, tonsil, posterior part of the tongue, or posterior pharyngeal wall are touched by unfamiliar objects such as a swab and spatula.
  • The afferent limb of the reflex is provided by the Glossopharyngeal nerve, and the efferent limb by the vagus nerve.

Explanation of other options:

B. Vagus nerve (X)

Although it contributes to the efferent limb of the gag reflex, it does not carry sensation from the highlighted oropharyngeal region.

C. Accessory nerve (XI)

This nerve innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius, not involved in pharyngeal sensory innervation or the gag reflex.

D. Hypoglossal nerve (XII)

It controls tongue muscles and plays no role in sensation from the oropharynx or gag reflex.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure presents with fatigue, nausea, and yellow-tinged vision. His medications include furosemide and digoxin. On examination, his pulse is 54/min, and an ECG shows complete (third-degree) atrioventricular block. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is classic for digoxin toxicity, supported by the symptoms (GI + visual), bradycardia, AV block, and concurrent loop diuretic use (which predisposes to hypokalemia and enhances digoxin toxicity).

Digitalis is a drug with a very narrow therapeutic index.

Digitalis toxicity produces a variety of side effects including headache, nausea, vomiting, altered colour perception, halo vision and malaise.

Serious adverse events include arrhythmias, mostly bradyarrhythmias due to the enhanced vagal tone. Tachyarrhythmia can also occur.

Digoxin-specific antibody fragmentsfor

  • hemodynamically compromising dysrhythmias,
  • Mobitz II or third degree atrioventricular block,
  • hyperkalemia (>5.5 meq/L; in acute poisoning only).

Temporizing measures include atropine, dopamine, epinephrine, and external cardiac pacing for bradydysrhythmias and magnesium, lidocaine, or phenytoin, for ventricular tachydysrhythmias.

Internal cardiac pacing and cardioversion can increase ventricular irritability and should be reserved for refractory cases.

B. Lidocaine - Useful for ventricular arrhythmias in digoxin toxicity, not bradycardia or AV block.

C. DC shock - Not indicated in bradyarrhythmias or AV block due to digoxin; may worsen arrhythmia due to increased ventricular irritability.

D. Phenytoin - May be used for digoxin-induced atrial or ventricular tachyarrhythmias but not first-line for complete AV block or bradycardia.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension was started on anti-hypertensive medications. Which of the following drugs would have caused this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts angioedema, a well-recognized adverse effect of ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril, lisinopril)
  • ACE inhibitors block conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II and inhibit bradykinin degradation → elevated bradykinin levels → vasodilation and increased vascular permeability → angioedema.
  • Management of ACE Inhibitor Angioedema:
    • Discontinue the ACE inhibitor immediately.
    • Supportive care: airway monitoring, antihistamines, corticosteroids, epinephrine if severe.
    • Switch to alternative antihypertensive (e.g., ARB with caution, or non-ACE agent such as calcium channel blocker).

ACE inhibitors adverse effects:

  • Hypotension: Initial sharp drop in blood pressure, especially in patients on diuretics or with congestive heart failure; can be problematic post-myocardial infarction.
  • Hyperkalemia: Risk increased in renal impairment or when combined with potassium-sparing diuretics, NSAIDs, or β-blockers.
  • Cough: Persistent, brassy cough in 10-16% of patients (1-8 weeks after initiation) due to impaired breakdown of bradykinin and substance P in the lungs.
  • Rashes/Urticaria: Occur in 1-4% of recipients.
  • Dysgeusia: Reversible alteration or loss of taste (notably with captopril).
  • Fetopathic Effects: Fetal growth retardation, organ hypoplasia, and fetal death if used during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.
  • Headache/Dizziness/Nausea/Bowel Upset: Common but usually mild.
  • Granulocytopenia/Proteinuria: Rare, warrant withdrawal if present.
  • Acute Renal Failure: Can be precipitated in bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased glomerular filtration pressure.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, side effects include peripheral edema, flushing, headache, gingival hyperplasia.
  • Option C: Atenolol is a cardioselective β1-blocker, adverse effects include bradycardia, fatigue, cold extremities, potential bronchospasm in reactive airway disease.
  • Option D: Clonidine is a central α2-agonist, side effects include sedation, dry mouth, rebound hypertension on withdrawal.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used for isolating Legionella species?
questions.solution:
Legionella pneumophila is a Gram-negative, motile coccobacillus that is strictly aerobic and has fastidious growth requirements.

Key Points:

  • Grows best on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar, a specialized enriched medium.
  • Charcoal detoxifies inhibitory compounds and yeast extract provides essential nutrients.
  • L-cysteine and iron are also required for optimal growth.

Natural Reservoir:

  • Found in aquatic environments: lakes, rivers, hot tubs, air-conditioning systems, and water tanks.
  • No human-to-human transmission.
  • Transmission occurs via inhalation of aerosols or aspiration of contaminated water.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • B) MacConkey agar: Selective for Enteric Gram-negative rods, especially lactose fermenters like coli. Legionella does not grow on this medium.
  • C) Baird-Parker agar: Selective medium for Staphylococcus aureus.
  • D) Sabouraud dextrose agar: Used for fungal cultures, not suitable for Legionella.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measure to assess the health status of a community and serves as a sensitive indicator of the availability and utilization of health services?
questions.solution:
• The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the best measure to assess the health status of a community and is a sensitive indicator of the availability and utilization of health services.
  • It reflects the number of infant deaths (under one year of age) per 1,000 live births in a given year.
  • High IMR indicates poor health services, inadequate maternal and child care, and lower overall health status of a community.

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

  • It is one of the most universally accepted indicators of health status not only of infants, but also of whole population and of the socio-economic conditions under which they live.
  • In addition, the infant mortality rate is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization and effectiveness of health care, particularly perinatal care.
  • Infant mortality is given a separate treatment by demographers because:
    1. Infant mortality is the largest single age-category of mortality;
    2. Deaths at this age are due to a peculiar set of diseases and conditions to which the adult population is less exposed or less vulnerable
    3. Infant mortality is affected rather quickly and directly by specific health programmes and hence may change more rapidly than the general death rate.
  • Most common cause of IMR in India: Low birth weight and prematurity

Explanation of other options:

Option (B)MATERNAL MORTALITY RATIO

  • According to WHO, a maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes

Option (C ) Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALY)

DALY is a comprehensive measure of disease burden, representing total years lost due to illness, disability, or premature death.

It is the best indicator for assessing disease burden and evaluating the effectiveness of health interventions.

Components:

1. Years of Life Lost (YLL):

= Number of deaths × standard life expectancy at age of death

2. Years Lived with Disability (YLD):

= Number of incident cases × duration × disability weight (0 = perfect health, 1 = death)

Formula:

DALY = YLL + YLD

One DALY = One year of healthy life lost due to disease or disability.

Option (D) Human Development Index (HDI)

HDI is a composite index measuring three core dimensions of human development:

  1. Health - Life expectancy at birth
  2. Education - Mean years of schooling & expected years of schooling
  3. Standard of living - Gross National Income (GNI) per capita (PPP US$)

It reflects achievements in basic aspects of human well-being.

questions.text: A child 5 years old presented with burns on the right upper thorax, right half abdomen, thigh, arm up to axilla. What is the percentage of burns?
questions.solution:
Burn size calculation in children: LUND and BROWDER

The body proportions of children necessitate adjustment of the above-mentioned scales. An infant's head is proportionally larger than an adult's and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each. For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.

Assessing the area of a burn

  • The patient's hand is 1% TBSA, and is a useful guide in small burns
  • The Lund and Browder chart is useful in larger burns
  • The 'rule of nines' is adequate for a first approximation only

In the above question:

Right anterior half of trunk(thorax+abdomen) - 6.5% Right arm up to axilla: 2%

Anterior side of right thigh - 4% Total - 10-15%

WALLACE RULE OF NINE

https://openi.nlm.nih.gov/imgs/512/18/3038395/PMC3038395_IJPS-43-43-g001.png

choices.text: For 5 years 3 weekly or 21 years of age
Till 10 years 3 weekly or till 21 years of age

questions.text: An 11-year-old child is diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever and is prescribed 0.6 million units of IM benzathine penicillin. There is no evidence of carditis on examination or echocardiography. What is the recommended duration of secondary prophylaxis in this case?
questions.solution:
This is a case of isolated rheumatic fever without carditis, for which secondary prophylaxis with benzathine penicillin is recommended. For such patients, guidelines recommend 3-weekly IM penicillin injections for 5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

If there were carditis without residual valvular disease, the duration would be 10 years or until 21 years.

If carditis with persistent valvular disease, prophylaxis extends to 10 years or until 40 years or even lifelong depending on severity. Alternative - Oral penicillin V - 250 mg twice daily.

A. Lifelong prophylaxis - This is reserved for severe valvular disease or high-risk settings with recurrent ARF.

B. Single dose - Inappropriate; ARF recurrence risk remains for years.

D. 10 years or until 25 years - This applies to ARF with carditis but no residual valvular disease.

Duration of treatment Table 359-4

questions.text: Which special stain is used for identifying Streptococcus species?
questions.solution:
Gram stain is the most commonly used differential stain in microbiology and is routinely used for identifying Streptococcus species.

Characteristics of Streptococcus:

  • Gram-positive cocci, appearing in chains or pairs
  • They retain the crystal violet stain and appear purple under the microscope

Steps in Gram staining:

  1. Crystal violet (primary stain)
  2. Iodine (mordant)
  3. Alcohol/acetone (decolorizer)
  4. Safranin (counterstain)

This staining technique helps to:

  • Differentiate Gram-positive (purple) from Gram-negative (pink/red) bacteria
  • Assess bacterial morphology, size, and arrangement
  • Provide initial information for empirical treatment and infection severity

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • A) Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain: Used for acid-fast bacilli, e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not for Streptococcus.
  • C) Mucicarmine stain: Used for identifying mucin-producing cells, especially Cryptococcus neoformans capsule in tissue.
  • D) Malachite green: A spore stain used to visualize bacterial endospores, e.g., Bacillus and Clostridium species.

questions.text: A patient with multiple episodes of vomiting was administered an intravenous drug and later developed abnormal involuntary movements. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
• Intravenous metoclopramide (a D₂ antagonist) treats vomiting by blocking chemoreceptor trigger zone but also blocks nigrostriatal D₂ receptors which causes acute extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).
  • Treatment with Central Anticholinergics:
    • Benzhexol (Trihexyphenidyl): Restores dopamine-acetylcholine balance by blocking central M₁ receptors in striatum → rapid relief of dystonia/parkinsonism.
    • Other Agents: Benztropine or diphenhydramine (anticholinergic effects) also effective.
  • Central Anticholinergic Agents
    • Higher central:peripheral anticholinergic action ratio than atropine; reduce unbalanced cholinergic activity in parkinsonism/EPS.
    • Improve tremor > rigidity. Minimal effect on hypokinesia.
    • Control sialorrhea via peripheral anticholinergic action.
  • Adverse Effects of Central Anticholinergics:
    • Similar to atropine: dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention.
    • In elderly: increased risk of memory impairment, confusion, cognitive decline, urinary retention especially in elderly males.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Levodopa - Dopamine precursor for Parkinson's disease, slow onset, not used acutely for drug-induced dystonia.
  • Option C: Ondansetron - 5-HT₃ antagonist antiemetic, does not reverse D₂ blockade-induced EPS.
  • Option D: Selegiline - MAO-B inhibitor used as adjunct in Parkinson's; not indicated for acute antidystonic therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Beta-2 microglobulin (β2M) is the most important and validated prognostic marker in multiple myeloma. It reflects both tumor burden and renal function, as β2M is produced by malignant plasma cells and is cleared by the kidneys. Elevated levels are associated with:

  • Higher disease stage
  • Greater tumor mass
  • Worse renal function
  • Poor overall survival

It forms a core component of the International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma, which stratifies patients into stages based on β2M and serum albumin levels.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) Serum creatinine: Elevated creatinine indicates renal impairment, which is common in multiple myeloma but not as directly prognostic as beta 2-microglobulin.
  • (C) Calcium: Hypercalcemia is associated with disease severity but is a clinical feature rather than a direct prognostic marker.
  • (D) Protein: Monoclonal protein levels reflect disease activity but are less predictive of prognosis than beta 2-microglobulin.

Key Takeaway:

In multiple myeloma, elevated beta 2-microglobulin is the most reliable poor prognostic marker, reflecting tumor burden and kidney function. It is a critical component of disease staging and outcome prediction.

questions.text: A researcher aims to examine the association between COPD and smoking by using patients' records from government hospitals and records of cigarette sale from the finance and taxation department. This scenario is an example of which type of study design?:
questions.solution:
In this scenario, where the researcher is comparing aggregate data on COPD (outcome) and cigarette sales (exposure), it fits the description of an ecological study.

Ecological studies analyze data at the group level rather than at the

individual level, making comparisons between populations or groups based on aggregate data.

Ecological Study (Correlational Study):

  • Type of analytical(observational) epidemiological study which provide the 'least satisfactory type of evidence on causality'.
  • Units of study: Population
  • Done in a small time frame: Inexpensive; use data that is already available
  • Advantage: Data can be used from populations with different characteristics
  • Disadvantages: Potential problem: Socio-economic confounding
  • Ecological fallacy: Is an error of interpretation of statistical data in an ecological study, whereby characteristics are ascribed to a group of individuals which they may not possess as individuals.

Cross-sectional studies:

  • Cross-sectional study is the simplest form of an observational study.
  • It is based on a single examination of a cross-section of population at one point in time -the results of which can be projected on the whole population provided the sampling has been done correctly. Cross-sectional study is also known as "prevalence study".
  • Gives 'Snapshot of a population'
  • Cross-sectional studies are more useful for chronic than short-lived diseases.
  • Although a cross-sectional study provides information about disease prevalence, it provides very little information about the natural history of disease or about the rate of occurrence of new cases (incidence).

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Causing death of the mother by miscarriage
Causing death of quick unborn child while trying to kill mother

questions.text: Section 314 of IPC (section 90 BNS) deals with?
questions.solution:
• Section 314 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) / section 90 BNS specifically deals with causing the death of the mother by miscarriage.
  • It applies to cases where a person, through illegal actions or negligence, causes the death of the mother during a miscarriage, leading to criminal liability.
  • The section focuses on situations where the miscarriage is caused in such a way that it results in the death of the mother.

Other options:

Option A: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother is defined by Section 312 IPC / Section 88 BNS, which covers causing a miscarriage with the woman's consent.

Option B: Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother is defined by Section 312 IPC / Section 88 BNS, dealing with non-consensual abortion.

Option D: Causing death of a quick unborn child while trying to kill a mother defined by Section 318 IPC / Section 94 BNS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Section 314 IPC deals specifically with causing the death of the mother during a miscarriage.
  • It emphasizes that criminal responsibility arises if the actions lead to the mother's death while attempting or causing a miscarriage.

questions.text: The given drug lacks intrinsic activity against anaerobes, and its resistance occurs most commonly due to inactivation by enzyme:
questions.solution:
Lack of Anaerobic Activity

  • Aminoglycosides require oxygen-dependent transport into bacterial cells → no activity against anaerobes.

Primary Resistance Mechanism

  • Bacterial production of aminoglycoside-modifying enzymes (acetyltransferases, adenyltransferases, phosphotransferases) → antibiotic inactivation.

Pharmacokinetic Properties

  • All are administered as water-soluble sulfate salts.
  • Poor oral absorption → given parenterally.
  • Distribute extracellularly; negligible CNS penetration.
  • Excreted unchanged via glomerular filtration.
  • Bactericidal and more active at alkaline pH.
  • Narrow therapeutic index; main toxicities are ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.
  • Partial cross-resistance exists among different aminoglycosides.

Spectrum of Activity

  • Primarily aerobic gram-negative bacilli (Pseudomonas, Enterobacteriaceae).
  • Often used in combination with beta-lactams or vancomycin for synergy against gram-positives.
  • No anaerobic coverage.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Beta-lactams have anaerobic coverage. Resistance arises from β-lactamase production, altered PBPs, or efflux, not from inactivation by modifying enzymes.
  • Option C: Chloramphenicol is broad spectrum including anaerobes; resistance is due to chloramphenicol acetyltransferase, but the drug does not lack anaerobic activity.
  • Option D: Metronidazole is active exclusively against anaerobes; resistance results from decreased prodrug activation, not by enzymatic inactivation.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient diagnosed with cervical cancer. On examination, necrotizing lesions on the cervix extend to parametrium. What is the management of this stage?
questions.solution:
The 2018 FIGO staging of cervical CA is as follows:

Stagewise Management :

Parametrial involvement places it in stage IIB and the management option for stage IIB is Chemoradiation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presents with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fever persisting for one month. On examination, there is significant pallor and a petechial rash over the body. No lymphadenopathy or organomegaly is noted.

Laboratory findings:
Hemoglobin: 3 g/dL
Platelet count: 10,000/μL
Absolute neutrophil count (ANC): 150/μL
Peripheral smear: Macrocytes
Corrected reticulocyte count: 0.5%
Bone marrow biopsy: Hypocellular, fatty marrow; absent megakaryocytes, no immature/blast cells

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia: The clinical presentation of pallor, gum bleeding, easy bruisability, fever, macrocytosis, low reticulocyte count, and fatty bone marrow with absent megakaryocytes strongly suggests idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia (AA). This condition is characterized by pancytopenia (low hemoglobin, platelets, and ANC) and fatty infiltration of the bone marrow with a lack of hematopoietic cells. It results from immune-mediated destruction of hematopoietic stem cells.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) Disseminated TB involving bone marrow: Tuberculosis can cause bone marrow involvement, but it typically presents with other systemic signs of infection, such as lymphadenopathy or organ-specific findings, not with the specific bone marrow changes seen here.
  • (C) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH can present with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia, but it typically causes hemoglobinuria, and the bone marrow findings would not show fatty infiltration or absent megakaryocytes.
  • (D) Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS typically presents with cytopenias but is associated with dysplastic cells in the bone marrow, not with fatty marrow or absent megakaryocytes.

Key Takeaway:

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia (AA) is characterized by pancytopenia, macrocytosis, low reticulocyte count, and fatty marrow with absent megakaryocytes. It is often immune-mediated, and early diagnosis is crucial for treatment options like bone marrow transplantation.

questions.text: Vaccine to be given after a disaster?
questions.solution:
After a disaster, particularly natural disasters or situations where there is an increased risk of injuries, tetanus vaccination is crucial.

Tetanus is caused by bacteria found in soil, dust, and manure, which can enter the body through cuts, wounds, or burns that are contaminated with these bacteria. Therefore, ensuring tetanus vaccination is up-to-date among affected populations is a priority to prevent tetanus infections.

VACCINATION AFTER DISASTER

  • The WHO does NOT recommend typhoid and cholera vaccines in routine use in endemic areas. The newer typhoid and cholera vaccines have increased efficacy, but because they are multi dose vaccines, compliance is likely to be poor. However, these vaccinations are recommended for health workers.
  • Supplying safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta continue to be the most practical and effective strategy.
  • Mass vaccination of population against tetanus is usually unnecessary. The best protection is maintenance of a high level of immunity in the general population by routine vaccination before the disaster occurs, and adequate wound cleaning and treatment. If tetanus immunization was received more than 5 years ago in a patient who has sustained an open wound, a tetanus a toxoid booster is an effective preventive measure.
  • Natural disasters may negatively affect the maintenance of on going national or regional eradication programmes against polio and measles. Disruption of These programmes should be monitored closely. If cold-chain facilities are inadequate, they should be requested at the same time as vaccines.
  • As per WHO, NO MASS vaccination is required in case of post-disasters phase but recommends tetanus and hepatitis b vaccination for Frontline workers/disaster responders.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity, resting tremor, and masked facies ('blank facial expression'). Which of the following can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
• Parkinson's Disease Features: Rigidity, resting tremor, bradykinesia, and masked facies reflect dopamine deficiency in the nigrostriatal pathway.
  • Selegiline Mechanism
    • Selective, irreversible monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor → decreases dopamine breakdown → increases synaptic dopamine levels.
    • Used as monotherapy in early Parkinson's and as adjunct to levodopa in advanced disease to enhance and prolong dopamine effect.
  • Clinical Benefits:
    • Modest symptomatic improvement in motor function. Delays need for levodopa.
    • May reduce "wearing-off" phenomenon when combined with levodopa.
  • Adverse Effects: Insomnia, orthostatic hypotension.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic and is used in treatment resistant schizophrenia
  • Option B: Donepezil is an anticholinesterase used in treatment of alzheimer's disease.
  • Option D: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic used in treatment of schizophrenia. It blocks D2 receptors → worsens parkinsonian symptoms by further reducing dopamine activity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of a motor vehicle accident has presented to the casualty with a pelvic fracture. His vitals are stable, but he is unable to pass urine. On examination, he has blood at the penile meatus. Angio has been performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?
questions.solution:
• The urethra can also rupture in accidental injuries.
  • Rupture of the penile urethra leads to collection of urine in the superficial perineal space.
  • Rupture of the membranous urethra causes accumulation of urine in the pelvic cavity.
  • Rupture of the urethra leads to extravasation of urine, which may be superficial or deep.
  • In superficial extravasation, the urine spreads downwards deep to the membranous layer of the superficial fascia. It first fills the superficial perineal space; and then the scrotum, the penis and the lower part of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • It is prevented from going to the ischioanal fossa or the thigh by the firm attachment of the membranous layer of superficial fascia to their boundaries.
  • In deep extravasation, the urine spreads upwards into the extraperitoneal space of the pelvis around the bladder and prostate, into the anterior abdominal wall.

Explanation of incorrect options:

(A) Spongy urethra

Lies within the corpus spongiosum and is distal; not typically injured in pelvic fractures, but rather in straddle injuries or instrumentation.

(B) Bulbar urethra

Part of the anterior urethra; usually injured in straddle injuries, not pelvic fractures.

(D) Penile urethra

A distal part of the spongy urethra; injury here causes urine to collect in the superficial perineal space, not in the pelvic cavity.

questions.text: A dead body is brought to the mortuary. On external examination, the rectal temperature was found to be 39 degree Celsius. The probable cause could be?
questions.solution:
• A rectal temperature of 39°C (102.2°F) in a dead body suggests that the person likely died in a state of fever, which is characteristic of septicemia (a severe bacterial infection that leads to systemic inflammation and high fever).
  • Septicemia can cause a sustained high body temperature, and if the body is brought to the Mortuary soon after death, the temperature may still be elevated due to the body’s inability to cooldown quickly.
  • The temperature of the body post-mortem (called post-mortem temperature) can provide clues regarding the cause of death, and in the case of septicemia, it may be elevated for a period before the body cools.

Other options:

Option A- Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: While it can lead to death, it usually causes a rapid decline in body temperature, rather than sustained fever.

Option C- Corrosive poisoning: This can cause death due to organ damage, but fever is not a typical postmortem finding in corrosive poisoning cases.

Option D- Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide typically causes death by hypoxia and may not result in a high body temperature. It usually causes rapid collapse and coma without a prolonged fever.

Key Takeaways:

  • An elevated post-mortem body temperature (39°C) is often associated with septicemia, as it can cause sustained fever before death.
  • Septicemia leads to systemic infection and inflammation, which can elevate body temperature until the body cools after death.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with cough, cold, and fever. His sputum is rusty, but tests are negative for tuberculosis. He reports a recent trip to China where he consumed crab. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation and travel/food history are strongly suggestive of paragonimiasis, a parasitic infection caused by the lung fluke Paragonimus westermani.

Key features of Paragonimus westermani infection:

  • Transmission: Ingestion of undercooked or raw freshwater crabs or crayfish containing metacercariae.
  • Geographic distribution: Most common in East Asia (China, Korea, Japan), also found in parts of South America and Africa.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Chronic cough, fever, hemoptysis (often described as rusty sputum due to blood-tinged mucus)
    • Pulmonary infiltrates on imaging may mimic tuberculosis
    • Eosinophilia is often present
  • Diagnosis:
    • Microscopy of sputum or stool for characteristic eggs
    • Serology or imaging in difficult cases

Incorrect options:

  • B) Fasciola hepatica: A liver fluke, acquired from eating water plants like watercress, causing hepatic symptoms (e.g., right upper quadrant pain, hepatomegaly), not respiratory symptoms.
  • C) Fasciola buski: A giant intestinal fluke, also from aquatic plants. It causes GI symptoms like abdominal discomfort and diarrhea, not cough or hemoptysis.
  • D) Entamoeba histolytica: A protozoan causing amoebic dysentery and sometimes liver abscesses. It does not present with pulmonary symptoms or rusty sputum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female who was sexually active with multiple sexual partners presents with swelling in the wall of labia majora. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bartholin abscess

Causes. A Bartholin abscess forms when a small opening(duct) from the gland gets blocked. Fluid in the gland builds up and may become infected. Fluid may build up over many years before an abscess occurs.

Most common organism involved e.coli> gonorrhea

Soaking in a tub filled with a few inches of warm water(sitz bath) several times a day for three or four days may help a small, infected cyst to rupture and drain on its own. Surgical drainage. You may need surgery to drain a cyst that's infected or very large.

Topical treatments

  • Tea tree oil: Applying a mixture of tea tree oil and castor oil to the abscess may encourage drainage. Tea tree oil has natural antibacterial properties....
  • Apple cider vinegar (ACV): Typically, people who use ACV to treat a Bartholin's abscess dilute it and apply it to the cyst with a cotton ball.

Surgical treatment:incision and drainage followed by insertion of word catheter

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and decreased vision in the right eye. On examination, the eye shows no red reflex, and fundus details are obscured. There is no history of trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Leukocoria, or a white pupillary reflex, is a critical clinical sign in pediatric ophthalmology. It often indicates serious underlying intraocular pathology requiring urgent evaluation.

Among the causes, retinoblastoma is the most important malignant tumor of childhood, typically presenting before 5 years of age.

Retinoblastoma:

Other differential diagnoses of leukocoria include Coats disease (a retinal vascular disorder causing exudative retinal detachment), persistent fetal vasculature (PFV) (a congenital developmental anomaly of the primary vitreous), and congenital cataract. However, these conditions have distinctive features:

  • Coats disease typically shows retinal telangiectasia and exudation on fundoscopy.
  • PFV presents with microphthalmia and persistent fetal vessels.
  • Congenital cataracts cause opacity of the lens without intraocular mass.

Prompt diagnosis and treatment of retinoblastoma, which may include chemotherapy, focal therapies, or enucleation in advanced cases, are crucial to prevent life-threatening spread and preserve life.

questions.text: Neurological examination of a patient revealed the following: Diplopia and suspected involvement of other cranial nerves, tingling and numbness in the lower extremities. Symptoms were getting worse upon taking a hot bath. Defect of which of the following cells is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Oligodendrocytes are a type of macroglia that form myelin around axons in the central nervous system (CNS) (brain and spinal cord).
  • In Multiple Sclerosis (MS), there is patchy destruction of myelin in the CNS, which is produced by oligodendrocytes.
  • Demyelination delays or blocks nerve conduction, leading to neurological symptoms like diplopia, tingling, and numbness.
  • Symptoms may worsen with increased body temperature (eg, hot bath), a phenomenon commonly seen in MS.
  • The autoimmune process in MS targets CNS myelin, causing inflammation and axonal injury.
  • The clinical picture described - cranial nerve involvement, sensory issues in lower limbs, and heat sensitivity - is consistent with MS and points to oligodendrocyte dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

Ependymal cell

  • These line the brain ventricles and central canal, involved in CSF circulation, not myelin formation.

Astrocyte

  • Maintain the extracellular environment and form the blood-brain barrier, but do not produce myelin.

Microglia

  • Act as immune scavenger cells within the central nervous system (CNS), clearing debris, but are not involved in myelination.

questions.text: All of the following are components of metabolic syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Metabolic syndrome constitutes a constellation of metabolic abnormalities that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

The main components of metabolic syndrome are:

  • central obesity,
  • hypertriglyceridemia,
  • low HDL,
  • hyperglycemia
  • hypertension

CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH METABOLIC SYNDOME X:

Cardiovascular diseases, Diabetes mellitus, non alcoholic steatohepatitis, hyperuricemia, PCOS, obstructive sleep apnoea.

Other metabolic alterations that occur secondary to or accompany insulin resistance include increases in apoB and apoC-III, uric acid, prothrombotic factors (fibrinogen, plasminogen activator inhibitor 1), serum viscosity, asymmetric dimethylarginine, homocysteine, white blood cell count, proinflammatory cytokines, C-reactive protein, urine albumin/creatinine ratio.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Which of the following is a microbiological test that can be used for diagnosing Leptospira infection?
questions.solution:
The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the gold standard serological test for diagnosing leptospirosis, a zoonotic infection caused by Leptospira interrogans and other Leptospira species.

Key features of MAT:

  • Detects serovar-specific antibodies against live Leptospira antigens.
  • Requires a panel of live Leptospira cultures and trained personnel.
  • Results are reported as antibody titers; a fourfold rise between acute and convalescent sera is diagnostic.
  • Usually becomes positive after the first week of illness.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • A) Cold agglutination test: Used primarily for Mycoplasma pneumoniae diagnosis, not Leptospira.
  • B) Standard agglutination test: A general term, but not specific for Leptospira.

Additional Diagnostic Points:

  • Culture media for isolation:
    • EMJH (Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris) medium
    • Fletcher medium, Stuart, and Korthof media
  • Other serological tests (used when MAT is not available):
    • ELISA (detects IgM antibodies)
    • Macroscopic slide agglutination test (MSAT)
    • Indirect hemagglutination assay (IHA)
  • Laboratory findings in leptospirosis:
    • Leukocytosis, ↑ ESR
    • Mild thrombocytopenia
    • ↑ Bilirubin (especially conjugated) and ALP
    • ↑ BUN and creatinine (if renal involvement)
    • Prolonged PT

Epidemiological Clue - "3 Rs of Leptospirosis":

  • Rats (reservoir)
  • Rain (flooding, exposure to contaminated water)
  • Rice fields (occupational exposure)

High-risk groups: farmers, sewage workers, veterinarians, fishermen

questions.text: A 30 years old patient presented to the casualty after a motor vehicle accident. He has bruises on his chest. His pulse is 120 beats per minute. BP is 90/60 mmHg and respiratory rate is 40/minute. A chest X-ray was performed and shown below. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pneumothorax

Pneumothorax is the presence of air outside the lung, within the pleural space. It must be distinguished from bullae or air cysts within the lung. Bullae can be the cause of an air leak from the lung and can therefore coexist with pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax features

  1. Raised JVP
  2. Decreased BP
  3. Absent breath sound
  4. Mediastinal shift to opposite side
  5. Ipsilateral Hyper resonant lung field on percussion

Management: immediate step - needle thoracocentesis

  • In adults:2nd intercostal space midclavicular line (most common and preferred) 5th intercostal space mid axillary line( alternative)
  • In children: 2nd intercostal space mid clavicular line

Definitive management: in both adults and children: intercostal drainage tube in 5th intercostal space mid axillary line( triangle of safety)

Indications for surgical intervention for pneumothorax include:

  • Second ipsilateral pneumothorax
  • First contralateral pneumothorax
  • Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Pneumothorax fails to settle despite chest drainage
  • Spontaneous haemothorax: professions at risk (e.g. pilots, divers)
  • Pregnancy

questions.text: A student was yawning in afternoon class and got stuck in an open mouth. Which of the following muscles is responsible?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is involved in opening the mouth during yawning or other actions requiring wide mouth opening. When a person yawns, the lateral pterygoid muscles contract to depress the mandible and open the mouth.

Muscles of mastication:

questions.text: Route of metastasis of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebrae:
questions.solution:
Spread by the bloodstream occurs particularly to bone; indeed, the prostate is the most common site of origin for skeletal metastases, followed in turn by the breast, the kidney, the bronchus and the thyroid gland.

The bones involved most frequently by carcinoma of the prostate are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites.

It is spread to lower lumbar vertebrae via the vertebral venous system i.e prostatic venous plexus also called as SANTORINI PLEXUS

Spreads in prostate cancer;

Local or direct spread- seminal vesicles, bladder, urethra, rectum

Lymphatic - obturator nodes, external and internal iliac nodes

Hematogenous- commonly bone especially vertebrae, pelvis, ribs. Lungs and liver less common

Prostate cancer never spread through transcoelomic route

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presented in the medicine OPD with resting tremor, rigidity, and loss of facial expression. The part of the brain commonly involved in this patient is:
questions.solution:
• Parkinson's disease results from degeneration of the substantia nigra pars compacta, a part of the basal ganglia.
  • This area normally sends dopamine-secreting neurons to the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are also parts of the basal ganglia.
  • Loss of dopamine leads to:
    • Rigidity of muscles
    • Resting tremor (3-6 Hz), even without intentional movement
    • Akinesia (difficulty initiating movement)
    • Postural instability (poor balance and frequent falls)
    • Other symptoms: Dysphagia, speech disturbances, fatigue, and later-stage dementia
  • The basal ganglia, through disrupted feedback loops, becomes overactive due to the loss of dopaminergic inhibition → leading to motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Explanation of incorrect options:

a) Hippocampus

  • Involved in memory formation. Damage causes memory impairment, not motor symptoms like tremor or rigidity.

b) Amygdala

  • Related to emotions and behavior. Not primarily involved in motor control or Parkinsonian features.

c) Cerebellum

  • Controls coordination and balance. Its lesion causes intention tremor, not resting tremor typical of Parkinson's.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 6 months. An ultrasound reveals a 2 cm submucosal fibroid. What is the definitive treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• Submucosal fibroids are a type of leiomyoma that protrude into the endometrial cavity, either partially or completely. Even small submucosal fibroids can cause significant menorrhagia because they increase the surface area of the endometrium, interfere with normal uterine contractility, and may undergo bleeding. They are the most common type of fibroid associated with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).
  • In this case, the patient is 45 years old and presents with 6 months of heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), with ultrasound confirming a 2 cm submucosal fibroid. At this age, she is likely perimenopausal, and fertility is no longer a concern. The definitive treatment of choice is hysterectomy, as it removes both the uterus and the fibroid, offering a complete and permanent cure for her symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

A. OCP for 3 months:

  • Oral contraceptive pills can be used to regulate the menstrual cycle and temporarily reduce menstrual flow. However, they offer only symptomatic relief and do not treat the fibroid itself. Moreover, in a perimenopausal woman, OCPs are used cautiously due to increased risk of thromboembolic events, especially in women over 40. Hence, not a definitive treatment.

B. Progesterone for 3 months:

  • Progestins help by opposing estrogen, thereby reducing endometrial proliferation and menstrual blood loss. However, like OCPs, this is also a temporary measure that does not shrink or remove the fibroid. It is useful in selected cases, but not curative, especially when a structural cause like a submucosal fibroid is confirmed.

C. Endometrial sampling:

  • This is a diagnostic procedure, not a therapeutic one. It is indicated to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma, particularly in women over 40 years with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). While it may be an important step in evaluation, it has no role in treatment, and certainly not in the definitive management of fibroid-related menorrhagia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of foods which is followed by recurrent vomiting. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The described symptoms of intense cravings for food followed by recurrent vomiting are characteristic of bulimia nervosa. Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder that primarily affects young females and is characterised by recurrent episodes of binge eating. During these episodes, individuals consume large amounts of food in a short period, often feeling a loss of control during the process. To compensate for the excessive food intake and prevent weight gain, individuals with bulimia nervosa engage in behaviours like self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives or diuretics, fasting or excessive exercise.

Other options:

  1. Binge eating disorder: While the term "binge eating" is present in this option, it is important to distinguish binge eating disorder from bulimia nervosa. In binge eating disorder, individuals have recurrent episodes of binge eating similar to bulimia nervosa, but without compensatory behaviours such as vomiting. The absence of compensatory behaviours is a key distinction between the two disorders.
  2. Atypical depression: Atypical depression is a subtype of major depressive disorder (MDD), characterised by mood reactivity (ability to experience improved mood in response to positive events), increased appetite or weight gain, excessive sleep and feeling of heaviness in the limbs. While appetite changes are present, the described pattern of intense cravings followed by recurrent vomiting is not typical for atypical depression.
  3. Anorexia nervosa: Anorexia nervosa is another eating disorder, but it involves a different pattern of behaviour. Individuals with anorexia nervosa have a fear of gaining weight and they restrict their food intake significantly, leading to severe weight loss and potentially dangerously low body weight.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bulimia nervosa is marked by binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors (e.g., vomiting, laxative use).
  • Binge eating disorder lacks the compensatory behaviors seen in bulimia nervosa.
  • Atypical depression and anorexia nervosa have different patterns of symptoms and are not characterized by the specific combination of binge eating and purging seen in bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: Uterine artery doppler done at 12-14 weeks, will help in the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Uterine artery doppler is done at 22-24 weeks of pregnancy to predict late onset preeclampsia.

  • Normal finding: Diastolic notch disappears by 22-24 weeks of pregnancy
  • Abnormal finding: Diastolic notch persisting beyond 24 weeks of pregnancy

In high risk pregnancies, it is done in the 1st trimester to predict early onset preeclampsia.

questions.text: Fertilization most commonly takes place at:
questions.solution:
Fertilization most commonly occurs in the ampulla of the uterine (fallopian) tube. This segment is the widest and longest part of the tube and is richly lined with mucosal folds that help facilitate the meeting of the sperm and ovum. After ovulation, the fimbriae sweep the ovulated secondary oocyte into the uterine tube, where it travels toward the uterus. Sperm ascending through the female reproductive tract typically meet the ovum in the ampulla.

Upon successful fertilization, the secondary oocyte completes meiosis II to form the ovum and second polar body, and the resulting zygote begins its journey toward the uterus for implantation. The timing and structure of the ampulla make it the most favorable site for this event.

Explanation of incorrect options:

a) Infundibulum:

This is the funnel-shaped, distal part of the uterine tube near the ovary. It helps capture the ovulated oocyte via its fimbriae but is not typically the site of fertilization.

c) Isthmus:

This is the narrow part of the tube closer to the uterus. By the time the oocyte reaches here, the ideal time for fertilization has usually passed.

d) Interstitium:

This is the portion of the uterine tube that passes through the uterine wall. Fertilization here is extremely rare and may lead to complications such as ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 40 years old woman presented to the clinic with a 4 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant. Biopsy from the mass showed densely packed cells with bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Colloid carcinoma, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is a rare subtype of breast carcinoma characterized by abundant extracellular mucin in which clusters of bland tumor cells are seen floating. It generally presents in older women and has a favorable prognosis compared to other invasive types.

Pathology of breast cancer

  • Breast carcinoma arises from the milk ducts in 90% (ductal carcinoma) or from the lobule in 10% (lobular carcinoma) of patients.
  • The disease may remain confined to the epithelium of the duct or lobule with no breach in the basement membrane; this is called in situ disease.
  • Infiltration of the surrounding tissue through a breach in the basement membrane leads to 'invasive or infiltrative' ductal or lobular carcinoma. The tumor may be well differentiated, moderately differentiated or poorly differentiated.
  • The modified Bloom-Richardson scoring system for tumor grade includes the sum of individual scores for three variables (percentage of tumor cells with tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism and the size and number of mitoses/HPF)
  • Rare histological variants, usually carrying a better prognosis, include colloid or mucinous carcinoma, whose cells produce abundant mucin; medullary carcinoma, with solid sheets of large cells often associated with a marked lymphocytic reaction; and tubular carcinoma.
  • The papillary type of carcinoma (both in situ and invasive) is a rare type of breast cancer accounting for 0.5-1% of all neoplasms. The lesion is characterized by papillomas with a fibrovascular core and surface covered by epithelial and myoepithelial cells.
  • It usually carries a better prognosis and rarely spreads to lymph nodes and the bloodstream. The tumor cells may overexpress estrogen receptors (ER positive), progesterone receptors (PR positive), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu positive) and androgen receptors (AR positive).

B. Tubular carcinoma - Composed of well-formed tubules lined by a single layer of bland epithelial cells. It does not feature mucin production. Also associated with a favorable prognosis.

C. Papillary carcinoma - Shows fronds or finger-like projections with a fibrovascular core. Mucin is not a defining feature.

D. Medullary carcinoma - Composed of solid sheets of large high-grade cells with prominent nucleoli and a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate. Lacks mucin.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis was started on anticoagulant therapy. The next day she presented with the condition depicted in the image. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The figure shows dermal vascular necrosis which is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is mainly seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

Warfarin-Induced Skin Necrosis (WISN):

  • Occurs 3-10 days after initiation of warfarin (but can appear as early as day 1 in protein C-deficient patients).
  • Pathogenesis: Early warfarin therapy causes a transient hypercoagulable state by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors and protein C more rapidly than procoagulant factors → microvascular thrombosis in subcutaneous fat and dermis.
  • Predisposing factor: Genetic protein C (or S) deficiency leads to unopposed clotting in dermal vessels.
  • Clinical presentation: Painful, erythematous macules → purpura → bullae → full-thickness skin necrosis, typically on breasts, thighs, buttocks, or extremities.
  • Management of WISN:
    • Immediately discontinue warfarin.
    • Reverse with vitamin K and, if needed, fresh frozen plasma or PCC (prothrombin complex concentrate).
    • Start alternative anticoagulation (e.g., heparin) once bleeding risk is controlled.
    • In known protein C deficiency, consider heparin bridge before initiating warfarin.
  • Preventive Strategy:
  • "Slow-start" warfarin (low dose or overlap with heparin) to allow protein C levels to stabilize before procoagulant factor reduction.

Purple Toe Syndrome

  • Develops 3-8 weeks after warfarin initiation.
  • Blue-tinged discoloration of toes or forefoot due to cholesterol microembolization from atheromatous plaques.
  • Blanches with pressure and improves on leg elevation.

Other Warfarin Toxicities:

  • Bleeding: Most common; monitor INR.
  • Other infrequent reactions include alopecia, urticaria, dermatitis,fever, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and anorexia.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Heparin can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) with skin necrosis at injection sites, but lesions appear at heparin injection sites 5-10 days after initiation, not days 1-2 on extremities distant from injections.
  • Option C: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor. It does not cause protein C mediated necrosis or purpuric skin lesions.
  • Option D: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. No association with skin necrosis or purpura
