questions.text: A child presented with manifestation of streptococcal infection but no carditis. What will you suggest for secondary prevention?
questions.solution:
Primary Prevention:

  • The aim of primary prevention is to prevent the first attack of RF, by identifying all patients with streptococcal throat infection and treating them with penicillin
  • A single intramuscular injection of 1.2million units of benzathine benzyl penicillin for adults and 600,000 units for children is adequate or oral penicillin (Penicillin V or Penicillin G) should be given for 10 days.
  • For patients with allergy to penicillin, 1st generation cephalosporins cefadroxil or cephalexin is used. Other drugs include erythromycin, clarithromycin or azithromycin.

Secondary Prevention:

  • Secondary prevention (i.e., the prevention of recurrences of RF) is a more practicable approach, especially in developing countries.
  • It consists in identifying those who have had RF and giving them one intramuscular injection of benzathine benzyl penicillin (1.2 million units in adults and 600,000 units in children) at intervals of 3weeks .
  • This must be continued for at least 5 years or until the child reaches 21 years whichever is later.
  • For patients with carditis (mild mitral regurgitation or healed carditis), the treatment should continue for 10 years after the last attack or at least until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.
  • More severe valvular disease or post-valve surgery cases need life-long treatment.
  • This prevents streptococcal sore throat and therefore recurrence of RF and RHD.

questions.text: Patient undergoes B/L adrenalectomy in view of bilateral pheochromocytoma . On post operative day 1 patients develop lethargy, fatigue. Blood pressure and pulse were normal And there is no evidence of volume depletion What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: This is a case of acute adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis caused due to removal of bilateral adrenal glands causing a reduction in the level of mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoid hormones. It should be managed immediately with intravenous fluids and replacement of glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoids

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below.
questions.solution:
The image depicts the life cycle of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a Flavivirus transmitted primarily by Culex mosquitoes, especially Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui complex.

Key features of Japanese encephalitis virus:

  • Family: Flaviviridae
  • Vector: Culex mosquitoes
  • Reservoir/Amplifier host: Pigs and wading birds
  • Dead-end hosts: Humans and horses (do not contribute to further transmission)
  • Geographic distribution: Predominantly Asia and Western Pacific regions
  • Clinical significance:
    • Most infections are asymptomatic or mild
    • Severe cases involve encephalitis with high fever, headache, disorientation, seizures, and sometimes death
  • Prevention:
    • Vaccination in endemic areas
    • Vector control
    • Pig immunization may reduce transmission in high-risk rural/agricultural areas

questions.text:
A 50 years old male presented with fatigability for one year. Evaluation showed mild anemia, massive splenomegaly.

The lab investigations showed:
1. Hemoglobin (Hb): 10 g%
2. Total leukocyte count (TLC): 120 x 10³/μL
3. Platelet count: 500 x 10³/μL
4. Differential count: Neutrophils 60%, Basophils 4%, Eosinophils 6%, Lymphocytes 15%
5. Peripheral smear: Myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms were seen.
6. Myeloid to erythroid (M:E) ratio: 8:1.

What is the most sensitive investigation?
questions.solution:
FISH stands for Fluorescence In situ hybridization and is a molecular cytogenetics technique.

  • The age, the symptoms and the presence of massive splenomegaly points towards a myeloproliferative disorder.
  • From the peripheral smear, we can see that there is an increase in neutrophils with a shift to left having band forms, myelocytes and metamyelocytes and an increase in myeloid erythroid ratio classical of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia.
  • The cytogenetic abnormality seen in 90% of patients with CML is the reciprocal translocation between chromosome 9 and 22(Philadelphia chromosome).
  • This translocation can be identified by the technique of FISH and PCR.
  • FISH and PCR can yield false positives at low levels or false negatives due to technical issues; hence, CML diagnosis must always rely on bone marrow cytogenetic analysis.

Explanation of other options:

Option (B)Immunophenotyping is a process used to identify the cells based on the antigens on their surface. It cannot be used for identifying chromosomal anomalies.

Option (C)FDG PET is the imaging technique used to identify areas of increased metabolism as in malignancy or infections. It can help us to identify the organ involved, but doesn't help in identifying the type of disease.

Option (D)Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase measures the alkaline phosphatase in neutrophils.

  • Its value is high in leukemoid reaction, tissue damage, steroid use, OCP, aplastic anemia, hodgkin's lymphoma and Down syndrome.
  • It is elevated in myeloproliferative disorders, but is low in the chronic phase of CML. It is low in PNH and hereditary hypophosphatemia.

choices.text: Just below the level of umbilicus

questions.text: What is the position of the uterus on postpartum day 1?
questions.solution:
• Immediately after delivery, the uterus contracts (involution) to expel the placenta and reduce its size. Just postpartum, immediately after delivery, the uterus is typically located in the midline of the abdomen, just below the level of the umbilicus-corresponding to 20week. This position is known as the "fundal height." It maintains the same height for 24hrs and then reduces at the rate of 1 finger breadth per day. It continues to contract over the next few days and weeks, becomes pelvic organ by weeks and return to its pre-pregnancy size and position by 6 week

Other options:

  1. Two fingers below umbilicus- by day 2
  2. Four fingers below umbilicus by day 4
  3. Just above symphysis pubis- just before 2 weeks

questions.text: A 45 year old man presented to the emergency department with mental confusion, nystagmus and ataxia. There is involvement of the 6th nerve too. On history, he is a chronic alcoholic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological emergency typically caused by a deficiency in thiamine (vitamin B1), which is common in chronic alcoholics. The classic triad of symptoms for Wernicke's encephalopathy includes:

  • Mental confusion (altered consciousness or cognitive dysfunction)
  • Ataxia (lack of coordination and unsteady gait)
  • Nystagmus (involuntary eye movement)

Additionally, cranial nerve abnormalities, particularly the involvement of the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve), leading to horizontal diplopia (double vision), are also commonly observed. This is consistent with the patient's presentation in this case.

Wernicke's encephalopathy requires urgent treatment with thiamine supplementation, as it can progress to Korsakoff syndrome if left untreated, which involves permanent memory impairment.

Other options:

  • Delirium tremens: Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically presents with agitation, confusion, hallucinations, and autonomic instability (e.g., increased heart rate, blood pressure). While mental confusion and agitation can occur, delirium tremens does not specifically involve nystagmus, ataxia, and cranial nerve abnormalities like in Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • Korsakoff psychosis: Korsakoff psychosis (or Korsakoff syndrome) is a long-term consequence of thiamine deficiency, usually following Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, amnesia, confabulation (making up stories to fill in memory gaps), and lack of insight. However, it does not typically present with nystagmus, ataxia, or 6th nerve involvement, which are more suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • De Clerembault syndrome: Also known as Erotomania, it is a psychiatric disorder where an individual believes that another person, often of higher social status, is in love with them. It is not associated with neurological symptoms like confusion, ataxia, or cranial nerve involvement, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Key Points:

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is a medical emergency that often occurs in chronic alcoholics due to thiamine deficiency.
  • It presents with mental confusion, nystagmus, ataxia, and sometimes cranial nerve palsies.
  • Immediate thiamine administration is crucial to prevent further neurological damage and progression to Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: The difference between the incidence in exposed and non-exposed group is best given by
questions.solution:
Attributable risk (also known as risk difference) is the difference in incidence of a disease or condition between an exposed group and a non-exposed group.

It quantifies the amount of risk that can be attributed to the exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Option (c )POPULATION-ATTRIBUTABLE RISK

This quantifies the avoidable incidence of the disease due to exposure in the entire population.

PAR = [(Incidence in total population - incidence in non exposed)/Incidence in total population] * 100

Option (A)RELATIVE RISK V/S ATTRIBUTABLE RISK


Option (D)ODDS RATIO (CROSS-PRODUCT RATIO)

From a case control study, we can derive what is known as Odds Ratio(OR) which is a measure of the strength of the association between risk factor and outcome.


Odds ratio is a key parameter in the analysis of case control studies. The derivation of odds ratio is based on three assumptions:

  • The disease being investigated must be relatively rare;
  • The cases must be representative of those with the disease, and
  • The controls must be representative of those without the disease.

questions.text: 60yr old nondiabetic, chronic alcoholic patient with multiple oral lesions shown, the lesion is painful with burning sensation. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Premalignant lesions

The majority of oral cancers do not originate from a preexisting lesion. However, there are a group of oral premalignant lesions, or more accurately described potentially malignant lesions, that are mucosal abnormalities from which oral cancer can arise.

These lesions include:

  • Leukoplakia
  • Erythroplakia
  • Erythroleukoplakia
  • proliferative verrucous leukoplakia (PVL)
  • oral submucous fibrosis
  • oral lichen planus and
  • lupus erythematosus

A leukoplakia is a white patch or plaque that cannot be rubbed off, while an erythroplakia is a bright red velvety plaque, neither of which can be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other recognisable condition. A speckled leukoplakia or erythroleukoplakia red velvety plaque is essentially a combination of both; it carries the greatest risk for malignant change. The management of premalignant lesions is challenging, not least because of an inconsistency with nomenclature internationally but also because the natural history of these lesions remains unclear.

Malakoplakia- rare chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease typically affecting urinary tract, especially the bladder, but it can occur in other organs. HPE finding- michaelis gutmann bodies


Treatment: excision and biopsy

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue persisting for over a year. On examination, he has massive splenomegaly.

Laboratory findings show:
1. Hemoglobin: 10 g/dL
2. Total leukocyte count (TLC): 120,000/μL
3. Platelets: 500,000/μL
4. Differential count: Neutrophils 60%, Basophils 4%, Eosinophils 6%, Lymphocytes 15%, Myeloblasts 3%; remainder includes myelocytes and band forms.
5. Bone marrow: M:E ratio of 18:1

What is the most specific next investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is classic for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in the chronic phase. Hallmark features include:

  • Marked leukocytosis with left shift (myelocytes, metamyelocytes, blasts <10%)
  • Basophilia and eosinophilia
  • Mild to moderate anemia
  • Thrombocytosis
  • Massive splenomegaly
  • High myeloid-to-erythroid (M:E) ratio

To confirm the diagnosis, the most specific and sensitive test is FISH or PCR for BCR-ABL1 fusion, which detects the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)(q34;q11)). This fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, driving uncontrolled myeloid proliferation.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (B) Immunophenotyping: While useful for diagnosing hematological malignancies like acute leukemias or lymphomas, it is not specific for CML, as it does not identify the BCR-ABL1 fusion.
  • (C) Whole body PET CT: This is primarily used for staging and monitoring solid tumors and lymphomas but does not contribute to the diagnosis of CML.
  • (D) Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP): LAP score is reduced in CML, but it is a less specific and outdated test compared to molecular diagnostics like FISH or PCR.

Key Takeaway:

In suspected CML, the most specific diagnostic test is FISH or PCR to detect the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, confirming the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome.

questions.text: A child at birth has sensorineural hearing loss, diminished vision and a heart defect (PDA). Likely an organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) classically presents with a triad of sensorineural hearing loss, ocular defects (such as cataracts and retinopathy), and cardiac defects, most commonly patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

Maternal rubella infection during the first trimester disrupts fetal organ development, leading to these characteristic anomalies

Key Takeaway :-



Incorrect Options:

A) CMV: While it causes sensorineural hearing loss and visual impairment, it is not typically associated with PDA or other congenital heart defects. CMV often presents with microcephaly and periventricular calcifications.

B) Toxoplasma gondii: Causes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, but not cardiac defects like PDA.

D) Chickenpox virus: Congenital varicella syndrome includes limb hypoplasia and skin scarring, but does not cause the classic triad seen here.

choices.text: Point B to C: Na+ channel opening

questions.text: An action potential is recorded from a mammalian neuron and marked with different letters. Which of the following pair is correct?
questions.solution:
• Point A - Resting Membrane Potential
    • Neuron is at rest (~-70 mV).
    • Membrane is more permeable to K⁺ than Na⁺.
    • Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.
  • Point B to C - Depolarization
    • Voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open → Na⁺ rushes into the cell.
    • Membrane potential becomes less negative and may overshoot to a positive value.
    • This marks the rising phase of the action potential.
  • Point D - Repolarization
    • Na⁺ channels inactivate, stopping further Na⁺ entry.
    • Voltage-gated K⁺ channels open → K⁺ exits the cell.
    • Membrane potential returns toward the resting level.
  • Point E - Hyperpolarization
    • K⁺ channels close slowly, causing excess K⁺ outflow.
    • Membrane becomes more negative than resting → hyperpolarized.
    • Marks the relative refractory period, during which a stronger stimulus is needed to trigger another action potential.
    • Na⁺/K⁺ pump restores ionic balance.

Explanation of incorrect options:

a) Point A: Threshold

Point A represents the resting potential, not the threshold level for action potential initiation.

c) Point D: K⁺ channel closure

At Point D, K⁺ channels are opening, not closing - this leads to repolarization.

d) Point E: Absolute refractory period

Point E corresponds to hyperpolarization and the relative refractory period, not the absolute one.

choices.text: Promotes release of noradrenaline at the synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman receives botulinum toxin injection for her facial wrinkles. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Botulinum Toxin

  • Botulinum toxins A and B are exotoxins from Clostridium botulinum that cleave SNARE proteins (e.g., SNAP-25), blocking vesicular exocytosis of acetylcholine (ACh) at cholinergic nerve terminals.
  • Result: long-lasting reduction of neuromuscular transmission → localized muscle paralysis.

Clinical Rationale for Cosmetic Use:

  • Injection of minute quantities (e.g., BOTOX®, DYSPORT®) in facial muscles temporarily weakens overactive muscles, reducing age-related wrinkle formation.
  • Toxin's effect begins 2-3 days post-injection, peaks at 1-2 weeks, and lasts 3-4 months.

Additional Therapeutic Uses:

  • Treatment of spastic disorders due to cholinergic overactivity:
    • Blepharospasm, hemifacial spasm, spasmodic torticollis, spastic cerebral palsy, post-stroke spasticity, strabismus, nystagmus, spasmodic dysphonia, axillary hyperhidrosis.

Adverse Effects of Cosmetic Injection:

  • Local: ptosis, diplopia, facial weakness, injection-site discomfort.
  • Systemic/to high dose: dry mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, general muscular weakness, respiratory paralysis. No systemic absorption expected with proper local injection. Any absorbed toxin binds presynaptic terminals irreversibly until new SNARE proteins are synthesized (weeks to months).

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Promotes release of noradrenaline - Incorrect, botulinum toxin targets cholinergic neurons, not adrenergic.
  • Option C: Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors - Incorrect, it does not block postsynaptic receptors but prevents ACh release presynaptically.
  • Option D: Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors - Incorrect, it causes blockade, not stimulation.

questions.text: A newborn baby after birth is presenting with the following finding - diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bladder exstrophy

  • Bladder exstrophy (ectopia Vesicae) is a congenital disorder in which failure of development of the anterior lower abdominal wall leads to an abdominal wall defect through which the bladder is exposed.
  • Diastasis of the pubic symphysis and an anterior opening of the urethra (epispadias) can coexist. The condition forms part of a spectrum of conditions ranging from epispadias to bladder exstrophy or to more severe cloacal exstrophy, the so-called exstrophy-epispadias complex.

Clinical features

Exstrophy of the bladder can be associated with a spectrum of anomalies affecting the external genitalia, urinary system, bony pelvis, abdominal wall, rectum and anus.

questions.text: A female delivered a 1.2 kg baby prematurely at 31 wk. The child had hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, petechial rash. The child failed the neonatal hearing screen. CT scan showed periventricular calcification. Likely congenital infection?
questions.solution:
CMV is the most common congenital infection causing hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, petechiae (due to thrombocytopenia), and sensorineural hearing loss (failed hearing screen).

The periventricular calcifications seen on CT are characteristic of congenital CMV infection (in contrast to diffuse or scattered calcifications in toxoplasmosis).

Prematurity and low birth weight are common in congenital CMV.

Incorrect Options:

  1. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Usually presents with skin vesicles, encephalitis, and disseminated infection, but periventricular calcifications are not typical.
  2. Toxoplasma gondii: Causes diffuse intracranial calcifications (not periventricular), chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus but usually does not cause petechial rash or jaundice.
  3. Parvovirus B19: Causes fetal hydrops and anemia but not typically hepatosplenomegaly or intracranial calcifications.

Key Takeaways :-

questions.text: A patient is undergoing a surgery where anesthesia is maintained on Halothane. The patient developed muscle rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following agent would have also contributed to this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is showing classic signs of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) — a rare but life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic agents, including volatile agents (e.g., Halothane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., Succinylcholine).

Malignant hyperthermia is due to a genetic defect in the RYR1 gene, leading to excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Key features include:

  • Muscle rigidity (especially masseter spasm)
  • Hyperthermia, tachycardia, acidosis
  • Hyperkalemia and myoglobinuria

Succinylcholine, when combined with volatile anesthetics like Halothane, greatly increases the risk.

Incorrect Options:

B. D-tubocurarine: A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; does not trigger malignant hyperthermia. Can cause histamine release and hypotension, but not MH.

C. Rocuronium: Also a non-depolarizing agent (aminosteroid group); safe in MH-susceptible patients.

D. Cisatracurium: A benzylisoquinolinium non-depolarizing blocker; does not trigger MH. Safer in hepatic/renal disease due to Hofmann elimination.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a long history of alcohol use presents with fatigue, abdominal distension, and easy bruising. Physical examination reveals jaundice, palmar erythema, and shifting dullness. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, low albumin, and a prolonged prothrombin time. A liver biopsy reveals eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions that are cytokeratin positive. These inclusions are primarily composed of:
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of chronic liver disease, likely cirrhosis-evidenced by signs of portal hypertension (ascites), synthetic dysfunction (bruising, low albumin, coagulopathy), and stigmata of liver disease (palmar erythema, jaundice). The liver biopsy shows eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions that are cytokeratin positive, characteristic of Mallory-Denk bodies.

These inclusions are aggregates of intermediate filaments, particularly cytokeratins 8 and 18, which accumulate due to hepatocellular injury and impaired protein degradation. Mallory-Denk bodies are classically seen in alcoholic liver disease, but can also appear in other chronic liver conditions.

Incorrect Answers Explained:

  • (A) Actin: Actin is part of the cytoskeleton but is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.
  • (B) Microtubule: Microtubules are involved in intracellular transport and mitotic spindle formation but do not form the eosinophilic inclusions seen in liver cells.
  • (D) Fibronectin: Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein and is not involved in the formation of cytoplasmic inclusions like Mallory-Denk bodies.

Key Takeaway:

Eosinophilic inclusions in the liver biopsy of a cirrhotic patient that are cytokeratin positive represent Mallory-Denk bodies, which are aggregates of intermediate filaments, specifically keratin, seen in liver cell injury.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive growing swelling from the last 2 years. On examination it was dense, mobile and nodular as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a progressively growing, dense, mobile, and nodular swelling in the parotid region is highly suggestive of a parotid gland tumor. The parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors, and the majority of them are benign.

Features of parotid swelling:

  • Lifting of the ear lobule.
  • Pain due to stretching of the capsule/fascia.
  • Deep lobe enlargement: Tonsillar fascia pushed medially.

Other options:

Jaw tumor: Jaw tumors are rare, but they can occur. They can be benign or malignant, and they can present as a painless, slow-growing mass.

Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign tumors that are made up of skin tissue. They can occur anywhere on the body, including the face and neck.

Sebaceous cyst: Benign tumors made up of sebaceous glands. They can occur anywhere on the body, but most commonly on the face and scalp.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of apixaban?
questions.solution:
Apixaban is a direct, selective, reversible inhibitor of activated factor X (factor Xa).

By binding the active site of factor Xa, it prevents conversion of prothrombin to thrombin (factor IIa), thereby reducing thrombin-mediated fibrin clot formation.

Pharmacokinetics & Dosing:

  • Oral bioavailability ≈ 50%; peak concentration in 3-4 hours.
  • Half-life ~12 hours; eliminated via renal (~25%) and fecal routes.
  • Standard dose for nonvalvular atrial fibrillation: 5 mg twice daily (reduced to 2.5 mg BID if two of: age ≥ 80, weight ≤ 60 kg, serum creatinine ≥ 1.5 mg/dL).
  • For treatment of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism: 10 mg BID for 7 days, then 5 mg BID.

Advantages Over Traditional Anticoagulants:

  • Fixed-dose regimen without routine monitoring of coagulation parameters (no INR required).
  • Rapid onset of action (no heparin lead-in).
  • Lower risk of major bleeding (particularly intracranial hemorrhage) compared to warfarin.

Mechanism of action of other anticoagulants:

questions.text: A child is suffering from recurrent chronic infections with encapsulated bacteria. This is due to deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Role of IgG2 in Immunity:
    • IgG2 is critical for opsonization and clearance of polysaccharide-encapsulated bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae).
  • IgG2 Deficiency:
    • Leads to inability to mount effective antibody responses against polysaccharide antigens → recurrent sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated organisms.
    • Most common IgG subclass deficiency; may occur alone or with IgG4 deficiency.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Normal total IgG, IgA, IgM levels.
    • Low IgG2 subclass level (<150 mg/dL).
    • Poor response to polysaccharide vaccines (e.g., 23-valent pneumococcal vaccine).
  • Clinical Management:
    • Prophylactic antibiotics for recurrent infections.
    • Immunization with conjugate vaccines to bypass polysaccharide-specific defect.
    • Immunoglobulin replacement therapy if severe.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: IgG1deficiency results in susceptibility to protein-antigen pathogens (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus), not primarily encapsulated bacteria.
  • Option C: IgG3 is important for antiviral and protein antigen responses; deficiency leads to viral infections, not classic encapsulated bacterial disease.
  • Option D: Low total IgG would suggest pan-hypogammaglobulinemia (e.g., agammaglobulinemia), not isolated encapsulated bacterial infections.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image.
questions.solution:
Contact leukoderma occurs due to the destruction of melanocytes following exposure to specific chemicals. Common culprits include:

  • Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH): Found in rubber gloves treated with this compound.
  • Para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP): Used in adhesives like bindi glue.
  • Para-phenylenediamine (PPD): Found in hair dyes and a leading cause of cosmetic-related leukoderma.

These chemicals trigger a toxic reaction, resulting in depigmentation of the skin.

Incorrect Options:

(A) Vitiligo:

  • An autoimmune condition causing melanocyte destruction but not due to chemical exposure. It has a progressive course and often symmetrical distribution.

(B) Piebaldism:

  • A rare genetic condition characterized by stable, congenital hypopigmented patches due to melanocyte migration defects. Typically present since birth.

(C) Albinism:

  • A genetic condition resulting in a lack of melanin production in the skin, hair, and eyes. Unlike contact leukoderma, it is systemic and not due to external exposure.

Key Takeaway: Contact leukoderma is an acquired depigmentation caused by chemical exposure, unlike autoimmune or genetic conditions like vitiligo, piebaldism, and albinism.

questions.text: A study was conducted to assess malnutrition among young children. A total of 100 children were selected each from rural and urban areas. Among them, 30 rural and 20 urban children were found to be malnourished. Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to compare the two groups?
questions.solution:
APPROACH

  • Step 1: Independent vs related groups: Here, 2 independent groups are compared - urban and rural children
  • Step 2: Proportion/Percentages vs Mean: Here, proportions are being compared- Rural: 30/100 and urban: 20/100 are malnourished
  • Step 3: 2 groups are compared

Hence, Proportions of outcome between two independent groups are compared, hence chi square test is done as the test of significance

Explanation of other options:

TESTS OF SIGNIFICANCE

These tests are mathematical methods by which the probability(p) or relative frequency of an observed difference, occurring by chance is found.

Tests of significance for comparing depends on:

  • Whether comparison is between independent or related groups
  • Whether proportions or mean are being compared
  • Whether one, two or ≥2 groups are being compared

Tests of significance can either be Parametric or Non Parametric Tests:

IF OUTCOME IS IN PROPORTION/PERCENTAGE/QUALITATIVE

IF OUTCOME IS IN MEAN/QUANTITATIVE VARIABLE

Extra edge

  • Sometimes, in case of small samples as in case of rare diseases, we need to apply non parametric counterparts in case mean variables. That is data is continuous but shows non normal distribution

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain?
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid haemorrhage: pt presents with thunderclap headache

Most common overall cause: trauma

Most commonspontaneous cause of SAH: rupture of berry aneurysm, on CT- star of death appearance

  • Extradural hemorrhage(EDH) - due to injury to anterior division of middle meningeal artery, on CT- biconvex shaped haemorrhage
  • Subdural hemorrhage: due to rupture of bridging cortical veins, on CT- concave convex shaped haemorrhage

Trauma is the commonest cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and this is managed conservatively. It is not usually associated with significant vasospasm.

Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage is usually associated with vasospasm. The possibility of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage actually leading to collapse and so causing a head injury needs to be borne in mind, and formal or CT angiography may be required to exclude this.

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
questions.solution:
A partial mole is a type of hydatidiform mole, which is a form of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) characterized by abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue with some fetal parts or embryonic tissue present. It results from fertilization of an ovum by two sperm (dispermy) or by one sperm that duplicates, leading to a triploid karyotype (usually 69,XXY or 69,XXX).

  • Partial mole is considered a premalignant condition, meaning it has the potential to cause abnormal growth but is not malignant by itself.
  • It typically causes enlarged, cystic placental tissue with some fetal development.
  • Unlike complete moles, partial moles are less likely to progress to invasive disease or GTN.
  • Because of this, partial mole is not classified as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). GTN refers specifically to malignant or invasive forms like invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, PSTT, and ETT.
  • Patients with partial mole generally undergo uterine evacuation and require monitoring of beta-hCG levels to detect any progression, but most cases resolve without developing into neoplasia.

Incorrect Options:

A) Choriocarcinoma:

  • Highly malignant form of GTN.
  • Composed of anaplastic trophoblasts with no villi.
  • Can follow any pregnancy, including molar pregnancy, abortion, or term delivery.

B) Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumour (PSTT):

  • Rare variant of GTN, arising from intermediate trophoblasts at the placental implantation site.
  • Presents with low hCG levels and delayed onset after pregnancy.
  • Resistant to chemotherapy, hence surgical management is primary.

C) Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumour (ETT):

  • Another rare form of GTN, histologically similar to carcinoma.
  • Also arises from intermediate trophoblasts.
  • Requires surgical treatment, typically hysterectomy

questions.text: Blood stored in citrate phosphate dextrose is better for hypoxia patients than acid citrate dextrose because:
questions.solution:
2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) binds to deoxygenated hemoglobin and reduces its affinity for oxygen by altering the quaternary structure, helping hemoglobin release oxygen to tissues. The concentration of 2,3-BPG decreases during blood storage, which reduces oxygen delivery capacity. Blood stored in citrate phosphate dextrose (CPD) shows less fall in 2,3-BPG compared to acid citrate dextrose (ACD), making it better suited for patients with hypoxia, as oxygen release from hemoglobin remains more effective.

Explanation of other options:

a) It has less P50

Lower P50 means higher oxygen affinity, which is not desired in hypoxia. CPD helps maintain oxygen release by preserving 2,3-BPG, not by lowering P50.

b) It is less acidic

Partially true, but not the main reason. While CPD is less acidic, the clinical benefit in hypoxia comes from better 2,3-BPG preservation, not pH alone.

d) None of the above

Option (c) is correct

questions.text: A 45 year old patient complains of recurrent swelling in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the swelling. Imaging was performed and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sialolithiasis

Salivary gland stones can form in the gland ducts. Patients between the ages of 30 and 60 with sialolithiasis typically present with cyclical postprandial swelling (meal time syndrome) of the major salivary glands and dryness possibly due to decreased salivary flow. Duct abnormality, inflammation and increased calcium content of the saliva may contribute to an increased risk of sialolithiasis. Chronic dehydration and pharmacological causes of decreased salivary flow are often implicated.

The submandibular gland is most commonly affected (85%) owing to the ascending course of its duct, predisposing it to stagnation of the mucinous as well as the more viscous saliva it produces. The alkaline saliva precipitates calcium and phosphate and predisposes to stone formation. On examination, there is an asymmetrical enlargement of the gland and a large proximal stone may be palpated in certain cases. Submandibular gland duct stones are mainly proximal and parotid gland duct stones are mainly distal.

Sialolithiasis complicated by a secondary bacterial infection may present with an abscess. IOC : NCCT ORAL CAVITY

Conventional radiographs are considered as an initial diagnostic test. However, small stones may be missed and only 80% of stones are radio-opaque. In such cases, computed tomography (CT) scanning, ultrasonography and a magnetic resonance

Sialography is the gold standard for diagnosis and involves injecting a dye into the duct of the salivary gland. It not only helps in diagnosis of sialolithiasis but also identifies any pathology in the duct. In addition, it may be therapeutic in certain cases. Sialendoscopy provides direct visualization of the duct and can be used for removal of stones. It is a safe procedure that can be performed under local anesthesia with better outcomes than open surgery.

questions.text: A patient has developed high frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The cause of hearing loss is found to be due to pathology of the basilar membrane. Which structure lies closest to the site of pathology?
questions.solution:
• The basilar membrane is a crucial structure in the cochlea of the inner ear, responsible for frequency tuning and sound perception.
  • High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss indicates damage to the hair cells or nerve fibers in the cochlea that respond to high-frequency sounds.
  • The basilar membrane lies adjacent to the cochlear fluids and is directly involved in the transmission of sound vibrations to the hair cells.
  • The closest structure to the basilar membrane is the oval window, a membrane-covered opening between the middle ear and the cochlea, where the stapes bone transmits sound vibrations.

The image below shows the cross-sectional of the cochlear membrane.

Other options:

Stria Vascularis: The Stria Vascularis is a highly vascularized structure located in the lateral wall of the cochlear duct. It plays a role in maintaining the endolymphatic potential and is not in close proximity to the basilar membrane.

Modiolus: The Modiolus is the central core of the cochlea, around which the cochlear turns spiral. It provides structural support and contains nerve fibers but is not directly involved in the pathophysiology of high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

Helicotrema: The Helicotrema is the point of communication between the scala vestibuli and the scala tympani at the apex of the cochlea. It is not directly related to the pathology of the basilar membrane.

Key Takeaway:

Basal turn of cochlea senses high frequency sound while apex senses low frequency sound.

questions.text: Which of the following is depicted in the figure?
questions.solution:
The image depicting Sturm's conoid represents the optical consequence of astigmatism, a refractive condition where the eye fails to focus light into a single point on the retina due to different curvatures in different meridians of the cornea or lens. Instead of forming a point focus, astigmatic eyes focus light into two line foci, which are oriented at right angles to each other.

When parallel light rays pass through an astigmatic optical system (such as a cornea with toric curvature), they are refracted to form two focal lines instead of one. These lines lie at different distances along the optical axis, creating a three-dimensional region known as the Sturm's conoid.

  • The first line focus corresponds to the meridian with the greatest curvature (most refractive power).
  • The second line focus corresponds to the meridian with the least curvature (least refractive power).
  • Between these two focal lines lies the circle of least confusion, which represents the best possible focus and is targeted during cylindrical correction.

This phenomenon is unique to astigmatism and is not seen in myopia, hypermetropia, or presbyopia, where the refractive error is uniform in all meridians.

Other options:

Myopia: All light rays are focused in front of the retina, but in a single point focus. No separate focal lines are formed, and Sturm's conoid is not present.

Hypermetropia: Light rays are focused behind the retina, again forming a single point focus. It does not produce two line foci or a conoid of Sturm.

Presbyopia: This is an age-related accommodative failure due to reduced lens elasticity. It affects near vision but has nothing to do with meridional refractive power differences or multiple focal planes.

questions.text:
A software engineer presents to the OPD with complaints of easy fatigability. He reports sitting in front of a computer for 12-14 hours per day and consuming more junk food with low intake of fruits and vegetables. CBC reveals:
1. Hemoglobin (Hb): 9 g%
2. Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV): 120 fL
What is the most likely nutrient deficiency causing his anemia?
questions.solution:
The patient's lab findings reveal a macrocytic anemia (elevated MCV of 120 fL), which is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia. Among the most common causes of macrocytic/megaloblastic anemia is folic acid deficiency.

Contributing factors in this case:

  • Poor dietary intake (low fruits and vegetables)
  • Sedentary lifestyle with reliance on junk food
  • No signs of bleeding or chronic illness

Folic acid is essential for DNA synthesis, and its deficiency impairs red cell maturation, resulting in large, immature red blood cells (macrocytosis).

Incorrect Answers Explained:

  • (B) Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency typically causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia (low Hb and low MCV), which does not fit the findings of macrocytosis here.
  • (C) Sideroblastic anemia: This condition is associated with microcytic or normocytic anemia and is not related to dietary deficiency. It is linked to defective heme synthesis.
  • (D) Acute blood loss: Acute blood loss leads to normocytic anemia initially, without the macrocytosis seen here.

Key Takeaway:

Macrocytic anemia (high MCV) in a patient with poor dietary habits and fatigue is most likely due to folic acid deficiency, which can be addressed by improving dietary intake or supplementation.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with a history of long-standing hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe breathlessness.BP is 190/110 mmHg, and Spo2 is 86% on room air. Chest X-ray is as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute pulmonary edema, likely due to hypertensive cardiac failure. The chest X-ray findings support this, showing:

  • Upper lobe venous congestion
  • Interstitial edema
  • Kerley B lines
  • Bilateral perihilar "bat-wing" pattern

IV nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in hypertensive acute pulmonary edema. It rapidly reduces preload and afterload, thereby decreasing pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) and relieving pulmonary congestion.

A. Oxygen + Antibiotics: While oxygen therapy is crucial for maintaining adequate oxygenation in patients with pulmonary edema, antibiotics are not typically indicated unless there is a concurrent infection. Antibiotics would not directly address the acute pulmonary edema associated with hypertension.

B. Intravenous Salbutamol (Albuterol): Salbutamol is a bronchodilator commonly used in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). While it may help alleviate some symptoms associated with pulmonary edema by reducing bronchospasm, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

D. Nebulized Salbutamol (Albuterol): Nebulized salbutamol is similar to intravenous salbutamol in its mechanism of action as a bronchodilator. While it may provide some relief for respiratory symptoms, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Causative agent for Donovanosis
questions.solution:
Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale) is a chronic, progressive, sexually transmitted infection characterized by painless, beefy-red genital ulcers that bleed easily. The causative agent is Calymmatobacteriumgranulomatis, a gram-negative intracellular bacterium.

The bacteria are identified by the presence of Donovan bodies - intracellular, safety-pin-shaped organisms seen in macrophages on tissue smears.

Transmission is primarily via sexual contact.

Incorrect Options:

A. Haemophilusducreyi:

Causes chancroid, characterized by painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Not the cause of donovanosis.

C. Treponema pallidum:

The spirochete responsible for syphilis, which presents with a painless chancre initially and then systemic symptoms. Not related to donovanosis.

D. Leishmania donovani:

Protozoan parasite causing visceral leishmaniasis (Kala azar). Not related to genital ulcers or donovanosis

questions.text: A male patient presented with bilateral toe gangrene with amputee digits and leg claudication. H\o impotence is seen . Where is the site of occlusion seeing the image shown below
questions.solution:
Patient having claudication of calf muscles, numbness in thigh with impotence. Impotence suggest higher site vascular obstruction -

LERICHE SYNDROME- most common in middle age man result from chronic atherosclerosis

Triad- 1. Claudication of buttocks and thighs

2. Impotence

3. Absent or diminished femoral pulse

Diagnosis- doppler, CT angiography, or MR angiography

Treatment- endovascular stenting or aortobifemoral bypass surgery

questions.text: A 74-year-old patient with CAD presents with palpitations. ECG is shown below. Bp is 120/84 mm hg. Which of the following shall be the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This ECG shows a regular wide complex tachycardia (WCT) with monomorphic QRS complexes, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). The patient is hemodynamically stable (normal BP), which favors medical management over electrical cardioversion.

In stable VT, the treatment of choice is IV amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic that:

  • Slows conduction through the AV node
  • Prolongs the action potential
  • Is effective for both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias

The question deals with wide complex tachycardiawith a stable BP of 120/80 suggestive of stable VT. Drug is iv Amiodarone

A. Oral metoprolol - Too slow in onset and not effective for acute control of VT. Also, beta-blockers are not first-line in wide-complex tachycardia unless the rhythm is known to be supraventricular with aberrancy.

B. Intravenous metoprolol - May worsen hemodynamics and is contraindicated in VT as it does not reliably terminate ventricular tachycardia and may depress myocardial contractility.

D. Oral amiodarone - Too slow in onset for acute rhythm control; not used for emergent rhythm conversion.

questions.text: Which antiviral drug is used in both HIV and hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Action

  • Emtricitabine is a fluorinated cytidine analogue that is phosphorylated intracellularly to its active triphosphate form.
  • Inhibits HIV-1 reverse transcriptase → chain termination.
  • Inhibits HBV DNA polymerase → chain termination in hepatitis B.

Pharmacokinetics

  • Oral bioavailability ~93%; once-daily dosing due to long intracellular half-life (~39 hours).
  • Minimal cytochrome P450 interactions → fewer drug-drug interactions.

Clinical Use & Considerations:

  • Included in fixed-dose combinations for HIV (e.g., tenofovir/emtricitabine).
  • Active against chronic HBV; monotherapy not recommended in HBV-HIV coinfection due to risk of HBV flare on discontinuation.
  • Preferred regimen for HBV-HIV coinfected patients: tenofovir + emtricitabine or tenofovir + lamivudine to avoid monotherapy and resistance.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Acyclovir is a guanosine analogue activated by viral thymidine kinase, effective only against HSV and VZV.
  • Option B: Abacavir is a Guanosine analogue NRTI active against HIV-1, no activity against HBV.
  • Option D: Enfuvirtide is an HIV-1 fusion inhibitor (gp41), no activity against HBV.

Key takeaways:

  • Lamivudine, emtricitabine, and tenofovir as the main agents with dual HIV/HBV activity.
  • Emtricitabine's once-daily dosing and dual action make it a cornerstone of coinfection therapy.
  • Always use combination NRTIs to prevent resistance and avoid HBV flares on discontinuation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female working in a village school develops profuse watery diarrhea described as "rice water stool." Which receptor does the toxin of the causative pathogen bind to?
questions.solution:
• The description of "rice water stool" is characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae.
  • Cholera toxin (CTX) comprises A and B subunits. The B subunit binds specifically to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells.
  • It activates adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP, leading to massive CL- and water loss.
  • Clinical Features of Cholera
    • Sudden onset of profuse, painless, watery diarrhea ("rice water stool"), often with vomiting.
    • Rapid dehydration can lead to hypovolemic shock if not promptly treated with rehydration.
  • Diagnosis & Laboratory Findings
    • Stool culture on selective media (TCBS agar) yields yellow, mucoid colonies (sucrose fermenter).
    • Dark-field microscopy or direct stool wet mount may reveal motile, curved, comma-shaped organisms.
  • Treatment & Prevention
    • Prompt oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with electrolyte solution; IV fluids for severe dehydration.
    • Doxycycline single dose (300 mg) or azithromycin can shorten duration of diarrhea.
    • Vaccination (live attenuated or killed oral vaccines) recommended for travelers or in endemic areas.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: GM2 ganglioside receptor is the binding site for Shiga toxin. It stops protein synthesis in gut cells, causing bloody diarrhea.
  • Option C: Guanylate Cyclase Receptor - Heat-stable enterotoxin of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli binds to guanylate cyclase C, raising intracellular cGMP, opening chloride channels and causing watery diarrhea.
  • Option D: Adenylate cyclase receptor -No adenylate cyclase receptor exists on the cell surface; cholera toxin instead activates intracellular adenylate cyclase by modifying a G protein after binding GM1 ganglioside.

questions.text: Following surgery for varicose veins, the patient started complaining of numbness along the medial aspect of leg. Which nerve is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Long saphenous vein stripping - saphenous nerve injury

Short saphenous vein stripping - suralnerve injury

Complications of standard varicose vein surgery

Complications (minor and major) are reported in up to 20% of patients who undergo traditional varicose vein surgery.

Wound infections, the most common complication, are reduced by prophylactic antibiotics. Nerve injury is the most common serious complication.

The incidence of saphenous nerve neuralgia is up to 7% following GSV stripping to the knee (the incidence is higher with stripping to the ankle).

The incidence of sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury may be as high as 20% and 4%, respectively, following SSV surgery.

The incidence of venous thromboembolic complications is approximately 0.5% following varicose vein surgery; however, patient risk factors must be individually assessed and appropriate prophylaxis administered according to guidelines.

questions.text: A child is presented with dermatitis, thinning of hair, and alopecia. The family has a history of eating raw egg whites for a long time. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is likely to be:
questions.solution:
Biotin:

Biotin is widely available in food and synthesized by intestinal flora in excess of requirements.

Deficiency is rare, except in individuals consuming large amounts of raw egg whites, which contain avidin, a protein that binds and inactivates biotin.

Deficiency leads to dermatitis, thinning of hair, and alopecia, as seen in this child.

It may also occur in those on prolonged total parenteral nutrition.

Key Points to Note (Other Options):

Option A: Vitamin A

Deficiency causes night blindness, then xerophthalmia, and keratinization of the cornea. It impairs immune cell differentiation and increases infection risk due to decreased retinol-binding protein during illness.

Option B: Vitamin B12

Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and irreversible spinal cord degeneration due to methioninedeficiency. Most commonly due to absorption issues (e.g., autoimmune loss of intrinsic factor), not diet. Vegans are at risk.

Option D: Iron

Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia and may lead to hair loss, but not dermatitis or alopecia as prominently as in biotin deficiency.

questions.text: An infection occurring after how many hours of hospital stay is defined as a nosocomial infection?
questions.solution:
Nosocomial infections are defined as those that are acquired after admission to the hospital which the patient has not been incubating during admission.

It appears first after 48 hours or more of hospital admission or within 30 days after having received hospital care.

Hospital acquired pneumonia is an example for nosocomial infection

Reference: Niger Med J. 2012;53(2):59-64

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was scheduled for Total laparoscopic hysterectomy. She was concerned about the procedure and enquired the gynecologist about laparoscopic hysterectomy. What is the disadvantage of total laparoscopic hysterectomy compared to open hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Other options:

A. Increased blood loss is seen in open laparoscopy

B. Long hospital stay is seen in open surgeries

C. Postoperative is more in open than laparoscopic

questions.text: Highest oxygen content in fetal circulation is seen in
questions.solution:
The highest oxygen content in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava (IVC).This is because the oxygen-rich blood from the placenta returns via the umbilical vein, and a significant portion bypasses the liver through the ductus venosus, entering the IVC. The IVC thus contains a mixture of highly oxygenated placental blood and deoxygenated blood from the lower body. This well-oxygenated blood is preferentially directed across the foramen ovale into the left atrium, then to the left ventricle, supplying the brain and upper body.

Incorrect Options:

B) Hepatic veins: These carry blood from the liver to the IVC, but since the blood mixes with hepatic venous blood, oxygen content is lower than in the IVC after the ductus venosus entry.

C) Umbilical artery: This carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta, so it has the lowest oxygen content.

D) Subclavian artery: Although the left subclavian artery receives relatively well-oxygenated blood from the left ventricle, its oxygen content is less than that in the IVC before mixing and shunting occur.

questions.text: A primigravida is shifted to the PNC ward just after 30 min of a vaginal delivery of a full-term healthy infant. The baby is doing well. On examination, the patient is hypotensive, hypoxic and has disseminated intravascular coagulation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter the mother's bloodstream, usually during labor, delivery, or immediately postpartum. This triggers a severe and sudden reaction that can lead to life-threatening complications for the mother. Here's an overview:

Causes and Pathophysiology

  • The exact cause of AFE isn't well understood, but it's thought to involve an abnormal immune response to amniotic fluid entering the maternal circulation.
  • This entry can cause an intense inflammatory reaction, triggering widespread clotting (disseminated intravascular coagulation, or DIC), respiratory distress, and cardiovascular collapse.

Signs and Symptoms

Symptoms usually appear suddenly and may include:

  1. Sudden respiratory distress: Shortness of breath, rapid breathing, or difficulty breathing.
  2. Cardiovascular collapse: A sudden drop in blood pressure, leading to shock.
  3. Severe bleeding (DIC): This may manifest as hemorrhaging, with uncontrolled bleeding at various sites.
  4. Seizures and loss of consciousness: Due to lack of oxygen and blood flow to the brain.

Diagnosis

AFE is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on symptoms, as it often presents abruptly during or right after childbirth. There's no specific test for AFE

Treatment

Immediate, intensive treatment is critical and usually includes:

  • Respiratory support: Often mechanical ventilation to help the mother breathe.
  • Cardiovascular support: Medications and fluids to stabilize blood pressure and support the heart.
  • Blood product transfusions: To manage DIC and severe bleeding.
  • Emergency delivery: If AFE occurs before delivery, an emergency C-section may be performed to protect both mother and baby.

Causes of DIC in pregnancy:

  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Intrauterine death
  • Severe preeclampsia
  • AFLP
  • Abruption

Option A: PPH: No history of excessive bleeding hence ruled out

Option B: Uterine inversion is associated with mismanaged 3rd stage of labour, with the uterus lying outside.

Option C: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy:

  • Starts in last month of pregnancy or within 5 months of delivery
  • Cardiac failure can be seen
  • Not a cause of DIC

questions.text: Familial hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) is associated with a defect in:
questions.solution:
Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes. The most commonly involved genes include:

  • MLH1
  • MSH2
  • MSH6
  • PMS2

These MMR genes are responsible for detecting and repairing base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops that occur during DNA replication. Defective MMR leads to microsatellite instability (MSI)-the molecular hallmark of Lynch syndrome.

This condition significantly increases the risk for colorectal cancer, often on the right side of the colon, and also raises the risk for endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract, and other cancers.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) Nucleotide excision repair: This pathway repairs bulky DNA adducts, such as thymine dimers caused by UV radiation, and is defective in diseases like xeroderma pigmentosum, not HNPCC.
  • (B) Base pair excision repair: This process fixes small, non-helix-distorting base lesions like deaminated bases or single-strand breaks, which are not associated with HNPCC.
  • (C) Point mutation: While point mutations can occur in various diseases, HNPCC is specifically related to defects in mismatch repair genes rather than point mutations as a primary mechanism.

Key Takeaway:

Familial HNPCC/Lynch syndrome is caused by mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes, leading to microsatellite instability and increased risk for colorectal and other cancers.

questions.text: A child presented with refractory anemia. Below is provided the smear of bone marrow biopsy of the child. The probable enzyme deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Option A:

Image showing macrophages (Gaucher cells) become laden with lipid (glucosylceramide).

  • Gaucher disease is caused by a β-glucosidase (aka β-glucocerebrosidase)
  • This leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide (Cer-Glc).
  • Clinical features include:
    • Enlarged liver and spleen
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Mental retardation in infants (severe cases)
  • Histologically, Gaucher cells are lipid-laden macrophages appearing in bone marrow biopsies.

Explanation of other options:

Option B: 1,4 Alpha glucosidase

  • Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase(acid maltase) deficiency can lead to Pompe disease. It is glycogen storage disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.

Option C: Hexosaminidase A

  • Hexosaminidase A deficiency can lead to Tay sach disease, characterized by mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness.

Option D: Hexosaminidase B

  • Deficiency leads to Sandhoff disease.

questions.text: An immunocompromised 35-year-old HIV-positive patient reports persistent, voluminous watery diarrhea. Stool examination with modified acid-fast stain reveals oocysts of a coccidian parasite. Which is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• Isospora belli is identified by oocysts on modified acid-fast stain; cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) inhibits folate synthesis in the parasite and clears infection effectively.
  • It causes chronic, profuse, secretory diarrhea in HIV or other immunosuppressed patients.
  • Oocysts are ellipsoidal (20-30 µm) with smooth walls and stain red on modified acid-fast.
  • Treatment duration: 7-10 days. Consider secondary prophylaxis in patients with CD4 <200 cells/µL.

Table of common infections in immunocompromised hosts

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Penicillin targets bacterial cell walls; not effective against coccidian protozoa.
  • Option B: Benzathine penicillin is used for syphilis or streptococcal prophylaxis; no activity against Isospora.
  • Option D: Albendazole is effective against helminths (nematodes); not used for Isospora belli.

questions.text: A patient developed vomiting 3-4 hrs after eating a meal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the statements is correct about the Colombo Plan?
questions.solution:
THE COLOMBO PLAN

The Colombo Plan was established on 1 July 1951 by Australia, Canada, India, Pakistan, New Zealand, Sri Lanka and the United Kingdom and currently has expanded to 28 member countries

Objectives:

  1. To promote interest in and support for the economic and social development of the Asia-Pacific region.
  2. To promote technical cooperation and facilitate technology transfer among member countries.
  3. To review and coordinate technical cooperation efforts among member governments and international agencies to accelerate development.
  4. To encourage South-South cooperation by sharing developmental experiences among member nations.

questions.text: A 22-year-old comes to OPD she is primigravida very sure of dates with 20 weeks POG, on examination fundal height comes 16 weeks size. USG showed reduced liquor. Probable cause
questions.solution:
Renal agenesis causes severe oligohydramnios due to lack of fetal urine production, which is the primary source of amniotic fluid after the first trimester.

Reduced amniotic fluid leads to decreased uterine size, explaining the fundal height lagging behind gestational age.

In bilateral renal agenesis (Potter's syndrome), oligohydramnios is marked, and this also results in characteristic fetal features due to compression.

Incorrect Options:

B) Fetal anemia: Usually causes increased cardiac output and may lead to polyhydramnios or hydrops fetalis, not reduced amniotic fluid. Fundal height is generally not reduced.

C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF): A congenital heart defect; typically, it does not cause oligohydramnios or reduced fundal height.

D) Neural tube defect (NTD): Some NTDs (like anencephaly) may cause polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing; they do not cause reduced amniotic fluid.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, weight loss, and recurrent infections, and has a history of occupational exposure to benzidine. Which type of cancer is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Benzidine is an aromatic amine that is a well-documented occupational carcinogen, particularly associated with bladder cancer. It was historically used in industries such as dye manufacturing, rubber, leather, and printing.

In patients exposed to benzidine, clinical signs such as:

  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections
  • Sometimes painless hematuria should raise suspicion for urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma of the bladder.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) Lung Cancer: While chemical exposures can lead to lung cancer, benzidine is not strongly associated with lung cancer but rather with bladder carcinogenesis.
  • (C) Blood Cancer: Benzidine exposure is not linked to hematological malignancies such as leukemia or lymphoma.
  • (D) Bowel Cancer: Bowel cancer is associated with dietary factors, genetic predispositions, and chronic inflammatory conditions, not benzidine exposure.

Key Takeaway:

Benzidine exposure is a high-risk factor for bladder cancer. Symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and recurrent infections in an exposed individual should raise suspicion for this malignancy.

choices.text: Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive
Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with two days of fever and altered sensorium, accompanied by a purpuric rash over her legs. Which of the following correctly describes the organism responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
• A young adult with acute fever, altered sensorium (meningitis/meningoencephalitis), plus a nonblanching purpuric rash → highly suggestive of meningococcemia due to Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Purpura results from endotoxin-mediated endothelial injury and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • Key Organism Characteristics
    • Morphology & Staining: Gram-negative diplococci ("kidney-shaped," often seen inside neutrophils on CSF/blood smear). Oxidase positive.
    • Biochemical Profile: Ferments both glucose and maltose (distinguishes it from gonorrhoeae, which ferments glucose only).
  • Diagnosis: CSF or blood Gram stain shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci; culture on chocolate/Thayer-Martin agar; confirm with oxidase test and carbohydrate utilization (glucose +, maltose +).
  • Clinical Manifestations
    • Meningococcemia
      • Rapid onset fever, chills, myalgia, hypotension.
      • Petechial/purpuric rash on extremities/trunk (nonblanching).
      • Progression to septic shock, DIC, multi-organ failure if untreated.
    • Waterhouse - Friderichsen Syndrome
      • Fulminant septicemia with massive adrenal hemorrhage, rapidly progressing to shock and death.
      • Characterized by extensive purpura fulminans.
    • Meningitis
      • Headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, altered level of consciousness.
      • Can coexist with septicemia.
    • Pyogenic meningitis
      • Commonly affects young children (3-5 years of age).
  • Treatment: Immediate IV ceftriaxone or cefotaxime. Close contacts receive rifampin or ciprofloxacin prophylaxis.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Lacks the maltose fermentation detail needed to identify meningitidis specifically.
  • Option C: Identifies Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which causes pharyngitis or skin infections, not purpura fulminans.
  • Option D: Describes Streptococcus pneumoniae, which causes meningitis but typically without a purpuric rash.

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2:
questions.solution:
• Pyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form acetyl-CoA.
  • This reaction is catalyzed by a multienzyme complex associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex of the citric acid cycle.
  • Step 1:
    • Pyruvate is decarboxylated by the pyruvate dehydrogenase component.
    • This forms a hydroxyethyl derivative of the thiazole ring of enzyme-bound thiamin diphosphate.
  • Step 2:
    • The hydroxyethyl derivative reacts with oxidized lipoamide, the prosthetic group of dihydrolipoyl transacetylase, to form acetyl lipoamide.
  • In thiamin (vitamin B1) deficiency, glucose metabolism is impaired, leading to significant and potentially life-threatening lactic and pyruvic acidosis.
  • Step 3:
    • Acetyl lipoamide reacts with coenzyme A to form acetyl-CoA and reduced lipoamide.
  • Step 4:
    • Reduced lipoamide is reoxidized by the flavoprotein dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase, which contains flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).
  • Step 5:
    • The reduced flavoprotein is oxidized by NAD+, which transfers reducing equivalents to the respiratory chain.
  • Overall reaction:
    • Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Pyruvate decarboxylase is not part of the human pyruvate dehydrogenase complex; it's involved in yeast fermentation.
  • Option C: Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate, not acetyl-CoA.
  • Option D: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is E3, not E2, in the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.

So Option A is correct.

questions.text: Golden coloured rings in the eye are being evaluated. Which investigation should be done?
questions.solution:
Golden-colored rings in the eye refer to Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings, which are seen in Wilson's disease. Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism leading to copper deposition in tissues, especially the liver, brain, and cornea. The screening and diagnostic test of choice is serum ceruloplasmin, which is typically low in affected individuals. Additional tests may include 24-hour urinary copper, hepatic copper content, and slit-lamp examination for KF rings.

Incorrect options:

B) Serum Ferritin: Marker for iron storage; used in iron deficiency anemia and hemochromatosis, not related to copper metabolism.

C) Serum Copper: Can be low or normal in Wilson's disease and is not reliable alone, as it includes both bound and unbound copper.

D) Serum Magnesium: Unrelated to eye rings or copper metabolism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with dental caries is scheduled for dental extraction. Which of the following does not need prophylaxis for endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended only for high-risk cardiac conditions undergoing high-risk procedures (such as dental work involving gingival manipulation or perforation of oral mucosa)

Indications of IE prophylaxis -

questions.text: Patient aged 30 years presented with swelling around knee. Aspirate shows giant cells and mononuclear cells. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Osteoclastoma, also known as Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), typically occurs in adults between 20-40 years of age. Commonly arises at the epiphysis of long bones, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia). Histology shows a mixture of multinucleated giant cells (osteoclast-like) and mononuclear stromal cells. Presents with pain, swelling, and may show soap-bubble appearance on X-ray. Although classified as benign, GCT is locally aggressive and may recur or rarely metastasize to lungs.

Incorrect Options:

  • A. Osteosarcoma: A malignant bone tumor seen in younger patients (10-25 years), arises from metaphysis, shows malignant osteoid on histology-not giant cells.
  • B. Chondrosarcoma: Typically occurs in middle-aged to older adults. Involves pelvis, femur, and ribs. Produces cartilage, not giant cells.
  • C. Ewing's sarcoma: Seen in children and adolescents, arises from diaphysis of long bones. Histology shows small round blue cells, no giant cells.

questions.text: You are a doctor working with doctors without borders. Your latest assignment would be a 6 months service at an African village. You being cautious, take mefloquine prophylaxis. With its consumption, due to its quality of high protein binding, you would expect:
questions.solution:
• High Protein Binding → Decreased Glomerular Filtration
    • Mefloquine is >98% bound to plasma proteins; only the free fraction is filtered at the glomerulus.
    • With most of the drug remaining bound in blood, renal filtration of mefloquine is minimal.
  • Absorption & Distribution
    • Orally well absorbed; peak levels in 5-15 hours.
    • Although lipophilic and concentrating in tissues (liver, lung, intestines), high protein binding keeps most drug intravascular initially.
    • Extensive tissue binding prolongs effect but does not equate to a large free-drug volume of distribution.
  • Metabolism & Elimination
    • Metabolized extensively in the liver; excreted primarily in bile.
    • Significant enterohepatic recirculation and tissue binding yield a long half-life (2-3 weeks).

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: high plasma protein binding means the drug would remain in the intravascular compartment and hence will have a low Volume of distribution
  • Option C: high plasma protein binding increases the duration of action
  • Option D: high plasma protein binding would lead to more drug interactions as many drugs may bind to a similar protein.

questions.text: Transparency of the corneal endothelium is maintained by:
questions.solution:
Keratan Sulfate

  • Keratan sulfate consists of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units with sulfate groups attached to the 6′-position of GlcNAc or Gal.
  • It was originally isolated from the cornea (Keratan sulfate I) and cartilage (Keratan sulfate II).
  • In the eye, keratan sulfate plays a critical role in maintaining corneal transparency by lying between collagen fibrils, helping to keep the corneal stroma transparent.
  • Changes in proteoglycan composition, including keratan sulfate, are associated with corneal scars, which disappear as the cornea heals.
  • It acts as a structural component of the extracellular matrix, contributing to the organization of collagen fibrils in the cornea, thus ensuring transparency.

Explanation of other options:

A. Heparan Sulfate

  • Definition: A proteoglycan present on many extracellular cell surfaces, containing GlcN with fewer N-sulfates than heparin, with GlcUA as the predominant uronic acid.
  • Reason it's incorrect: It is mainly involved in cell growth, signaling, and cell-cell communication, and is associated with the plasma membrane, not specifically with maintaining corneal transparency.

C. Hyaluronic Acid

  • Definition: An unbranched chain of repeating disaccharides (GlcUA and GlcNAc) found in ECM of many tissues, especially in hydrated tissues like skin, cartilage, and vitreous humor.
  • Reason it's incorrect: While it plays a role in cell migration and ECM hydration, it is not specifically responsible for maintaining corneal transparency.

D. Chondroitin Sulfate

  • Definition: Proteoglycans linked to chondroitin sulfate by the Xyl-Ser O-glycosidic bond, found in cartilage and the ECM, especially in bones and nervous tissue.
  • Reason it's incorrect: It primarily maintains cartilage structure and is involved in the ECM of bones and nervous tissue, not specifically in corneal transparency.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with fever, migratory arthritis affecting the large joints of the lower limbs, tachycardia, and a pansystolic murmur. Echocardiography reveals mitral regurgitation. A biopsy is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely in histopathology?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is highly characteristic of acute rheumatic fever (ARF), especially with symptoms such as:

  • Fever
  • Migratory polyarthritis
  • Cardiac involvement (evidenced by a pansystolic murmur and mitral regurgitation)

On biopsy, the hallmark histological lesion of ARF is the Aschoff body, a type of granulomatous inflammation found in the myocardium. These lesions contain:

  • Anitschkow cells (also called "caterpillar cells" due to their chromatin pattern)
  • Multinucleated giant cells
  • Fibrinoid necrosis in early stages. This finding is pathognomonic for rheumatic carditis.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (B) Granuloma annulare: This is a benign skin condition with no association with fever, arthritis, or cardiac involvement.
  • (C) Granulomatous vasculitis: This occurs in conditions like Wegener’s granulomatosis or giant cell arteritis, which do not match the clinical presentation or biopsy findings here.
  • (D) Epithelioid granuloma: Found in diseases like tuberculosis or sarcoidosis, epithelioid granulomas do not have the specific histological features of Aschoff bodies.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of Aschoff bodies in a patient with fever, migratory arthritis, and mitral regurgitation strongly suggests acute rheumatic fever, particularly with a history of streptococcal infection. This highlights the cardiac involvement seen in ARF.

questions.text: Lesion producing incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
• A lesion of the optic tract classically produces a homonymous hemianopia, which means loss of the same visual field (either right or left) in both eyes.
  • In the case of optic tract lesions, the hemianopia is typically incongruous, meaning that the visual field defects in both eyes are not exactly symmetrical in shape or density.
  • This incongruity helps localize the lesion to the optic tract, as more posterior lesions (such as in the visual cortex) tend to produce highly congruous (mirror-image) defects due to the more organized retinotopic mapping of visual fibers as they reach the occipital lobe.
  • In addition to the visual field loss, optic tract lesions are uniquely associated with a phenomenon known as Wernicke's hemianopic pupil, also called the Wernicke's pupil reaction.
  • This is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) that is paradoxically seen in the eye contralateral to the lesion, i.e., the eye on the side opposite to the optic tract that is damaged.
  • This occurs because the optic tract carries more crossed fibers (from the contralateral eye’s nasal retina) than uncrossed fibers (from the ipsilateral temporal retina).
  • Thus, when the optic tract is damaged, more input from the contralateral retina is lost, leading to a subtle afferent pupillary defect when light is shone in that eye.
  • However, because the optic nerves and pupils themselves are intact, this RAPD is only detected using the swinging flashlight test and does not cause visible anisocoria.

Other options:

Optic nerve: Lesions here cause monocular vision loss, not homonymous hemianopia. The optic nerve transmits input from only one eye, so field loss would not be homonymous (same side in both eyes). Also, it typically produces a full field loss in the affected eye, not a hemianopia.

Optic radiations: Lesions in the optic radiations (especially temporal and parietal lobes) can cause homonymous hemianopia, but the defects are usually more congruous as the fibers are more organized. These lesions do not produce Wernicke's pupil.

Visual cortex: Lesions here also produce congruous homonymous hemianopia due to precise retinotopic mapping. Additionally, cortical lesions usually spare the pupillary light reflex, as the reflex pathway bypasses the occipital cortex entirely.

Lesions of optic pathway:

The Td vaccine is recommended for children at the ages of 10 and 16 years as part of the booster dose schedule.
