questions.text: During autopsy, if a pathologist removes the organs from the tongue to the prostate as a single block for later individual examination, which of the following dissection techniques is being employed?
questions.solution:
• Letulle's technique involves en masse dissection, where all thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed together as one block from the tongue to the prostate.
  • This block is then dissected individually outside the body, allowing efficient and systematic examination.
  • It is preferred in forensic settings for preserving anatomical relationships.

Autopsy techniques

questions.text: DNA packing is done by which of the following proteins
questions.solution:
Option A: Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins.

  • H1 histones are the least tightly bound to chromatin.
  • H1 can be easily removed with a salt solution, making chromatin more soluble.
  • The organizational unit of this soluble chromatin is the nucleosome.
  • Nucleosomes contain four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
  • The sequences and structures of these four histones (H2A, H2B, H3, and H4) are highly conserved between species.
  • Variants of these histones exist and are used for specialized purposes.
  • This extreme conservation suggests:
    • The function of histones is identical in all eukaryotes.
    • The entire molecule is involved specifically in performing this function.
  • The carboxyl-terminal two-thirds of histone molecules are hydrophobic.
  • The amino-terminal third is particularly rich in basic amino acids.

Histone Interactions:

  • Histones interact with each other in very specific ways.
  • H3 and H4 form a tetramer containing two molecules of each → (H3-H4)2.
  • H2A and H2B form dimers → H2A-H2B.
  • Under physiologic conditions, these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer with the composition:
    • → (H3-H4)2 - (H2A-H2B)2.

Explanation of other options:

Option B: Glycoprotein is not involved in DNA packing. Option C: Nucleic acids are DNA & RNA.

Option D: Adenine is a Nitrogen base present in nucleic acid.

questions.text: A primigravida patient presented with a soft tender abdomen. On examination the fetus is in the ROP position. How will you deliver?
questions.solution:
The frequency of posterior position(occiput of the fetus towards the sacrum of the mother) in labor is approximately 20% and of this 5% remain posterior until the end of labor. These posterior positions are associated with higher rates of cesarean section and instrumental delivery


Occiput posterior (OP) position is the most common fetal malposition. It is important because it is associated with labor abnormalities that may lead to adverse maternal and neonatal consequences, particularly operative vaginal or cesarean birth.

Mechanism of labour and possible outcome in occipito posterior position:

  1. 90% normal delivery, complete forward rotation
  2. Incomplete forward rotation
  3. Posterior rotation

If the pelvis is adequate normal vaginal delivery is the preferred mode of delivery

questions.text: A patient presents after ingesting 100 tablets of aspirin. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Alkalinization of Urine Enhances Elimination of Acidic Drugs

  • Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a weak acid. IV sodium bicarbonate alkalinizes serum and urine, shifting salicylate to the ionized form → reduced tissue (CNS) penetration and increased renal excretion (ion trapping).
  • Other acidic drugs (methotrexate, phenobarbital) share this principle
  • Alkaline drugs require urinary acidification (e.g., ammonium chloride).

Acute Salicylate Poisoning:

  • Clinical Features
    • More common and severe in children; fatal dose in adults ~15-30 g.
    • Presents with: vomiting, dehydration, electrolyte disturbances, respiratory alkalosis progressing to metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia, tinnitus, altered mentation, hyperpyrexia, convulsions, petechial hemorrhages, and risk of respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse.
  • Supportive Management & Monitoring
    • IV Fluids with Na+, K+, HCO3-, and Glucose: Correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Titrate sodium bicarbonate infusion to achieve serum pH ~7.45-7.55 and urine pH >7.5.
    • External Cooling: Manage hyperpyrexia.
    • Blood Transfusion and Vitamin K: Administer if bleeding occurs (coagulopathy from salicylates).
    • Hemodialysis: Indications: salicylate level >100 mg/dL, refractory acidosis despite alkalinization, renal failure, CNS symptoms, or pulmonary edema.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: N-acetylcysteine is an antidote for acetaminophen toxicity (replenishes glutathione), not effective for salicylate overdose.
  • Option C: Glucagon is indicated in beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker overdose (increases cAMP), not for aspirin toxicity.
  • Option D: Gastric Lavage should be considered only if the patient presents extremely early and under airway protection as it carries risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Tocilizumab is a newer monoclonal antibody for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It acts against
questions.solution:
IL-6: Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptors. IL-6 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and other inflammatory diseases. By inhibiting IL-6 signaling, tocilizumab reduces inflammation and alleviates symptoms in RA patients.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) IL-3: IL-3 is involved in hematopoiesis but is not a target of tocilizumab in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • (B) IL-12: IL-12 is associated with immune responses, but tocilizumab specifically targets IL-6, not IL-12.
  • (D) IL-2: IL-2 is involved in T-cell growth but is not targeted by tocilizumab.

Key Takeaway:

Tocilizumab works by blocking the IL-6 receptor, which helps manage inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis and other cytokine-driven diseases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with recent-onset diplopia and squint. On examination, you observe that the secondary deviation is greater than the primary deviation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the clinical context of an elderly male with diabetes and hypertension presenting with diplopia (double vision) and squint, the most likely diagnosis is paralytic squint, especially when secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation.
  • Paralytic squint is caused by weakness or paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to cranial nerve palsy.
  • The most commonly involved nerves are the oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), and abducens (VI) nerves.
  • In elderly patients with vascular risk factors like diabetes and hypertension, microvascular ischemia is a common etiology for cranial nerve palsies leading to paralytic squint.
  • A key clinical feature that differentiates paralytic squint from other types is the relationship between primary and secondary deviation.
  • Primary deviation is measured when the normal eye is fixating, and the affected eye deviates.
  • Secondary deviation is measured when the affected eye is made to fixate, and the normal eye deviates.
  • In paralytic squint, secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation due to Hering's law of equal innervation, which states that both eyes receive equal neural input.
  • Since the affected eye's muscle is weak, when it tries to fixate, the normal eye's corresponding muscle contracts excessively, leading to a larger observable deviation. This is a hallmark of paralytic squint and is used diagnostically.

Other options:

Comitant squint: Commonly seen in children, shows an equal angle of deviation in all directions of gaze and is not associated with diplopia or ocular muscle weakness. In comitant squint, both primary and secondary deviations are equal, and eye movements are full.

Restrictive squint, as seen in conditions like thyroid eye disease or orbital trauma with muscle entrapment, shows mechanical limitation of movement, but again, the primary and secondary deviations are generally equal or minimally different.

Pseudostrabismus is a false appearance of misalignment caused by facial features like a broad nasal bridge or epicanthal folds, and it does not present with true ocular deviation or diplopia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with complaints of generalized weakness and muscle cramps. Her ECG reveals ST segment depression, flattened T waves, and prominent U waves. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is most likely responsible for these ECG changes?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia leads to delayed ventricular repolarization, resulting in characteristic ECG changes such as ST segment depression, flattened or inverted T waves, and prominent U waves, especially in the precordial leads. These changes reflect prolonged repolarization and an increased risk of arrhythmias. Severe hypokalemia may also lead to QT interval prolongation due to a prolonged ST segment.

Prolongation of the QT interval is also seen with drugs that increase the duration of the ventricular action potential:

  • class IA antiarrhythmic agents and related drugs (e.g., quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide, tricyclic antidepressants, phenothiazines) and
  • class III agents (e.g., amiodarone, dofetilide, sotalol, ibutilide).
  • Systemic hypothermia also prolongs repolarization, usually with a distinctive convex elevation of the J point (Osborn wave).
  • Marked QT prolongation, sometimes with deep, wide T-wave inversions, may occur with intracranial bleeds, particularly subarachnoid hemorrhage ("CVA T-wave" pattern)

Hyperkalaemia typically causes peaked T waves, PR prolongation, and later, sine-wave patterns with eventual asystole-not U waves or ST depression.

Hypocalcaemia prolongs the ST segment, leading to a prolonged QT interval but does not produce U waves. ST elevation is caused by hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia and hypothermia

Hypercalcemia shortens the QT interval and can cause ST elevation, not depression or U waves.

questions.text: Which of the following statistical measures is used to predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable?
questions.solution:
The coefficient of regression is used to find one variable (dependent variable)based on the value of another variable (independent variable). It represents the slope of the regression line in a linear regression model and quantifies the relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable.

Explanation of other options:

Option (A)Coefficient of Variation (CV)

  • CV measures relative variability and allows comparison between variables with different units or scales (e.g., height vs weight).
  • It is calculated as:
  • CV = (Standard Deviation / Mean) × 100
  • Unlike standard deviation (SD), which is in units of measurement, CV is unitless, making it ideal for comparing dissimilar data.
  • It overcomes limitations of SD when comparing datasets with different units or magnitudes.

Option (B) Coefficient of correlation:Measures the degree of linear relationship between two quantitative (continuous) variables.

  • Value of 'r' ranges from -1 to +1:
  • +1: perfect positive correlation
  • 0: no correlation
  • -1: perfect negative correlation
  • Visualized by: Scatter diagram

Option (D):COEFFICIENT OF DETERMINATION

  • Coefficient of determination is the percentage of variation in a variable that is explained by one or more of the others.
  • It is generally obtained in a regression setup.
  • Coefficient of determination = (Correlation coefficient)2 = r2

questions.text: A patient on haloperidol has "Drug A" added. After adding, he develops excessive salivation and features of metabolic syndrome (elevated lipids). Which drug is "Drug A"?
questions.solution:
• Excessive Salivation (Sialorrhea) is a hallmark side effect of clozapine due to its strong M4 muscarinic agonism and α2-adrenergic blockade in salivary glands.
  • Clozapine has high affinity for 5-HT2C and H1 receptors → ↑ appetite and weight gain → high risk of metabolic syndrome.
  • Hematologic Toxicity:
    • Agranulocytosis incidence ~0.8%; other blood dyscrasias (neutropenia, leukopenia).
    • Requires regular CBC monitoring (weekly ×6 months, then biweekly ×6 months, then monthly).
  • Additional Adverse Effects:
    • Sedation (H1 antagonism), orthostatic hypotension (α1 antagonism), tachycardia, urinary incontinence.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Aripiprazole - Side effects include akathisia and hypoprolactinemia. Minimal sedation, negligible metabolic risk, no sialorrhea.
  • Option C: Risperidone - Highest risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia among atypicals. Moderate metabolic risk, does not cause marked sialorrhea.
  • Option D: Ziprasidone - Low metabolic risk. Notable for QT prolongation, minimal anticholinergic effects, no sialorrhea.

questions.text: Phostostress test is used to differentiate
questions.solution:
• The Photostress Recovery Test (or Photostress Test) is a simple clinical test used to differentiate between macular pathology and optic nerve disorders in patients presenting with central vision loss or reduced visual acuity.
  • The principle behind this test lies in the recovery capability of the photoreceptors, primarily the cones, in the macula after being "bleached" or temporarily desensitized by intense light.
  • In this test, the patient is asked to fixate on a bright light source (like an ophthalmoscope beam) directed at the fovea for about 10 seconds, which bleaches the photopigments in the cone cells.
  • After the light source is removed, the patient is asked to read a near-vision chart or identify letters previously seen.
  • The time taken to recover and regain pre-exposure visual acuity is measured, this is the photostress recovery time.
  • In a normal eye or in patients with optic nerve disorders, the recovery time is typically less than 30 seconds, because although the nerve is affected, the macular photoreceptors are intact and capable of rapid regeneration of their visual pigments.
  • However, in macular disorders (e.g., age-related macular degeneration, central serous chorioretinopathy), the cone photoreceptors themselves are dysfunctional or damaged, resulting in a prolonged recovery time, usually over 50 seconds.

Other options:

Cataract & Glaucoma:

Cataracts affect the media clarity of the eye (lens opacity), and glaucoma affects the optic nerve, but neither specifically evaluates photoreceptor function. The photostress test is not sensitive or specific for differentiating between these two conditions.

Corneal & Lens Diseases:

Both corneal and lenticular (lens) diseases affect light transmission to the retina. The photostress test assesses retinal (macular) function, not media opacities. Thus, it is not useful in evaluating or differentiating corneal vs. lens pathologies.

Vitreous & Retina:

Vitreous disorders (e.g., vitreous hemorrhage, floaters) are non-retinal and do not affect the photoreceptor function directly. While retinal diseases can cause visual impairment, the photostress test specifically helps differentiate macular (retinal) from optic nerve pathology, not vitreous issues.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Oseltamivir and Zanamivir?
questions.solution:
• Neuraminidase Inhibition (Mode of action)
    • Both oseltamivir and zanamivir bind to and inhibit the influenza virus neuraminidase enzyme.
    • Neuraminidase is essential for cleavage of sialic acid residues that otherwise tether newly formed virions to budding host cells.
    • Inhibition prevents release of progeny virions → reduces viral spread within the respiratory tract.
  • Clinical Uses
    • Effective against influenza A (including H1N1, H5N1) and influenza B.
    • Treatment: 75 mg oseltamivir orally twice daily for 5 days (or equivalent for zanamivir).
    • Prophylaxis: 75 mg oseltamivir once daily for at least 10 days during an outbreak.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Oseltamivir: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain (reduced by taking with food), headache, weakness, diarrhoea, cough, insomnia, and rare skin reactions.
    • Zanamivir: Bronchospasm and cough in patients with underlying airway disease (e.g., asthma).

questions.text: Which antibiotic should be avoided in patients who are well-controlled on theophylline therapy?
questions.solution:
Macrolides increase the level of theophylline by inhibiting Cyp450 and causes theophylline toxicity. Hence co administration should be avoided.

Agents which enhance theophylline metabolism primarily by inducing CYP1A2 lower its plasma level: dose should be increased by the factor given in parenthesis.

Examples include: Smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, phenobarbitone, charcoal broiled meat meal.

Drugs that inhibit theophylline metabolism and increase its plasma level include erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, cimetidine, oral contraceptives and allopurinol; in such cases, the theophylline dose should be reduced to2/3.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He complains of double vision, especially when looking to the right. On examination, his right eye is unable to move laterally. Which cranial nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
• Lateral (outward) movement of the eyeball is controlled by the Lateral Rectus muscle.
  • Lateral Rectus is supplied by the 6th cranial nerve (Abducens nerve).
  • It is the most commonly injured nerve in head trauma due to its long intracranial course and sharp turns.
  • Palsy leads to loss of abduction → patient complains of horizontal diplopia, especially on looking to the side of the lesion.

Other Options:

Third nerve palsy (Oculomotor nerve):
  • Supplies all extraocular muscles except Lateral Rectus (6th) and Superior Oblique (4th).
  • In palsy: eye is down and out, ptosis, and possibly pupil dilation.
  • Medial movement (inward) is affected, not lateral.

Trochlear nerve palsy (Fourth nerve):

  • Supplies Superior Oblique, which helps in depression and intorsion of the eye when looking inwards.
  • Palsy leads to vertical diplopia, worsens when looking down and in (e.g., reading, stairs).
  • Lateral movement is not affected.

Facial nerve palsy (Seventh nerve):

  • Controls muscles of facial expression.
  • Has no role in eye movement.
  • May cause inability to close the eye (lagophthalmos), but not loss of outward eye movement.

questions.text: A series of redox couples arranged in ascending order in the inner mitochondrial membrane makes ETC. There are mainly four complexes. The complex IV inhibitor includes
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of the respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons & drugs which are fatal at high doses.

Option A: Cyanide inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase), which catalyzes the reduction of O2 to water via heme groups (a, a3) and copper centers (CuA, CuB). This blocks electron transfer and prevents O2 from being fully reduced, halting respiration.H2S, carbon monoxide(CO), and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.

Explanation of other options:

Option B: Carbon monoxide(CO) inhibits Complex IV, not carbon dioxide(CO2).

Option C: The antibiotic oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

Option D: Ouabain inhibits the Na-K ATPase pump.

Key Takeaways:

Complex I is inhibited by Rotenone, Piericidin A, Barbiturates such as amobarbital also inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q. At sufficiently high dosage, they are fatal.

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A, dimercaprol & BAL inhibit the respiratory chain at Complex III.

questions.text: In low ovarian reserve, anti mullerian hormone level will be:
questions.solution:
Serum antimüllerian Hormone (AMH): Levels of serum AMH is a best predictor of ovarian stimulation response. Its level also comes with the direct proportion of preantral and antral follicle count. Levels of AMH(1ng/mL) declines with age and with poor ovarian reserve. Levels of AMH can be measured any time in the menstrual cycle as they do not fluctuate.

AMH: AMH is produced by the granulosa cells of the preantral/antral small follicles(less than 8mm). Serum levels of estradiol and inhibin B depend on the pituitary FSH feedback mechanism. Level of AMH is not dependent on the feedback mechanism. This is one of the reasons for which AMH is being considered as a better predictor of ovarian reserve compared to estradiol and inhibin B. Levels of AMH can be measured at any time in the menstrual cycle. It therefore understood that AMH is qualitative whereas Antral Follicle Count(AFC) is a quantitative marker of ovarian reserve.

Normal level- 1-1.5ng/ml

Borderline-less than 1ng/ml

Decreased levels- less than 0.5ng/ml

Undetectable- premature ovarian failure

Other tests for ovarian reserve- serum FSH levels(most common test done), antral follicular count, serum inhibin

questions.text: A 4 days postpartum woman presented with tearfulness, mood swings and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of tearfulness, mood swings and occasional insomnia that occur 4 days postpartum are consistent with postpartum blues. Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues", is a common and mild condition that affects many women after giving birth. It is considered a normal response to the hormonal changes and emotional adjustments that come with childbirth.

Postpartum blues typically begin within a few days after delivery and can last for a week or two. Symptoms include mood swings, tearfulness, irritability, anxiety and difficulty sleeping. Importantly, the symptoms are generally mild and do not impair the mother's ability to function or care for her baby.

Other options:

B. Postpartum Psychosis: Postpartum psychosis is a rare and severe psychiatric emergency that typically occurs within the first two weeks after childbirth. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe mood disturbances, confusion and disorganized behavior. The symptoms described in the scenario are not indicative of postpartum psychosis.

C. Postpartum Depression: Postpartum depression is a more severe and longer-lasting condition than postpartum blues. It usually develops within the first few weeks after childbirth, but its symptoms are more persistent and intense than those of postpartum blues. Postpartum depression can significantly affect a mother's ability to care for herself and her baby and it may require professional intervention and treatment.

D. Postpartum Anxiety: While postpartum anxiety is a valid condition that can occur after childbirth, the symptoms described in the question(tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia) are more characteristic of postpartum blues. Postpartum anxiety involves excessive worry, restlessness and racing thoughts, which were not mentioned in the scenario.

Key Takeaways:

  • Postpartum blues typically occur within the first few days after childbirth, are mild, and resolve within a week or two.
  • Postpartum psychosis and postpartum depression are more severe and require immediate attention and treatment.
  • Postpartum anxiety involves excessive worry, which was not indicated in this case.

questions.text: Glanzmann thrombasthenia is due to a defect in:
questions.solution:
Gp IIb/IIIa: Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a congenital platelet disorder caused by a defect in the Gp IIb/IIIacomplex, which is essential for platelet aggregation. This glycoprotein complex is responsible for the binding of fibrinogen to platelets, a crucial step in platelet aggregation during clot formation. The defect leads to bleeding tendencies due to impaired platelet function.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (B) Gp I b-IX: This is the complex involved in Bernard-Soulier syndrome, another platelet disorder that affects platelet adhesion to the vessel wall, not aggregation.
  • (C) CD68: CD68 is a marker for macrophages and is not involved in platelet aggregation or Glanzmann thrombasthenia.
  • (D) Von Willebrand factor: Von Willebrand factor is involved in platelet adhesion to the damaged vessel wall (not aggregation), and its deficiency causes von Willebrand disease, not Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

Key Takeaway:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia results from a defect in the Gp IIb/IIIa complex on platelets, leading to impaired platelet aggregation and increased bleeding risk.

questions.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral side of body is seen in thrombosis of which artery ?
questions.solution:
Embolic occlusion or thrombosis of a V4 segment of vertebral artery or PICA causes ischemia of the lateral medulla. The constellation of vertigo, numbness of the ipsilateral face and contralateral limbs, diplopia, hoarseness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome is called the lateral medullary (or Wallenberg's) syndrome This sensory pattern is seen in Lateral medullary syndrome.

The arteries responsible may be vertebral> PICA>Superior, middle or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery(PICA) in its proximal segment supplies the lateral medulla and, in its distal branches, the inferior surface of the cerebellum. So the most appropriate would be PICA.

questions.text: A patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis is prescribed metronidazole. Which of the following should the patient avoid consuming?
questions.solution:
Alcohol - Metronidazole Interaction

  • Some patients taking metronidazole develop a disulfiram-like reaction if they drink alcohol.
  • Symptoms include flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, and rapid heartbeat.

Other Relevant Metronidazole Interactions

  • Enzyme Inducers (Phenobarbitone, Rifampin): May speed up metronidazole breakdown → lower drug levels and reduced effectiveness.
  • Cimetidine: Slows metronidazole metabolism → higher drug levels; a lower dose of metronidazole may be needed.
  • Warfarin: Metronidazole inhibits its breakdown → increases bleeding risk; monitor INR and adjust dose.
  • Lithium: Metronidazole can reduce its excretion → higher lithium levels; monitor for toxicity.

Explanation of other options:


  • Option A: Grapefruit Juice - affects CYP3A4, but has no significant interaction with metronidazole.
  • Option C: Benzodiazepine - no clinically important interaction with metronidazole.
  • Option D: MAOI/SSRI - metronidazole is not an MAOI and does not trigger serotonin syndrome with SSRIs.

questions.text: Presenting diameter of full flexed head?
questions.solution:
Suboccipitobregmatic diameter is the presenting diameter in a full flexed fetal head.

Table 1.2: Anteroposterior diameters of fetal skull

questions.text: A labourer working under direct sun collapses with loss of consciousness. His body temperature is recorded as 106°F. Which of the following is the least likely finding?
questions.solution:
The patient is exhibiting classic signs of heat stroke, a life-threatening condition caused by prolonged exposure to high ambient temperatures.

  • Core body temperature >104°F (40°C) is diagnostic
  • In heat stroke, the thermoregulatory system fails, particularly sweat gland function.
  • As a result:
    • Sweating is absent
    • The skin becomes hot and dry
    • Vasodilation and dehydration lead to hypotension
    • The heart rate increases (tachycardia) to compensate for reduced perfusion
  • Types of Heat Injury:
    • Heat Exhaustion: Core temp < 104 °F, diaphoresis still present.
    • Heat Stroke: Core temp ≥ 104 °F, central nervous system dysfunction, absent sweating, and risk of end-organ damage.

Explanation of other answers:

  • Hypotension = Common due to vasodilation and intravascular volume depletion
  • Tachycardia = The body compensates for circulatory failure
  • Hot skin = Characteristically hot and dry in heat stroke due to failure of sweating

Key Takeaways:

  • In heat stroke, sweating is typically absent due to the failure of thermoregulatory mechanisms.
  • Hot skin, tachycardia, and hypotension are typical signs of heat stroke.
  • Immediate cooling and medical intervention are required in cases of heat stroke to prevent organ damage and death.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base on the trunk as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia after primary infection (chickenpox).

  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain and burning sensation along the affected dermatome.
    • Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base distributed unilaterally along dermatomes.
  • Treatment:
    • Antiviral medications like acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir, administered within 72 hours of symptom onset to reduce complications and duration.
  • Incorrect Options:
  • (A) Herpes Simplex:
    • Usually presents as grouped vesicles on mucocutaneous junctions (e.g., lips or genital area). Does not follow a dermatome pattern and is recurrent in nature.
  • (C) Molluscum Contagiosum:
    • Caused by the poxvirus, presenting as multiple pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. It is painless and not vesicular.
  • (D) Chickenpox:
    • Caused by primary varicella-zoster virus infection, presenting as a polymorphic rash (vesicles, papules, and crusts) that is generalized and pruritic, often involving the trunk and extremities.

Key Takeaway: Herpes zoster presents as unilateral painful vesicles along a dermatome, distinguishing it from other conditions with vesicular or papular rashes

questions.text: A patient presents with deformity of the finger as shown in the picture. O\E its found that the PIP is involved but DIP is spared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows swan neck deformity( flexion at DIP and extension at PIP) seen in rheumatoid arthritis

Rheumatoid arthritis mainly involves small joints (MCP joint, PIP joint) with sparing of DIP characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis

Incorrect Options:

A. Osteoarthritis: Commonly involves DIP joints (Heberden's nodes) and PIP joints (Bouchard's nodes) but spares MCPs. Pain worsens with activity and improves with rest.

C. Psoriatic arthritis: Typically involves DIP joints, sometimes with nail changes (pitting, onycholysis) and dactylitis ("sausage digits").

D. Ankylosing spondylitis: Primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, not small joints of the hand. Peripheral arthritis, if present, involves large joints.

questions.text: A lesion in the superior temporal gyrus is most likely to cause which of the following
questions.solution:
Superior temporal gyrus is supplied by the inferior division of the MCA.The area corresponds to Wernicke's area and lesion leads to sensory or Wernickes or fluent aphasia. An embolus to the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery, especially the posterior temporal or angular branches, is the most common cause of Wernicke's aphasia.

The motor speech area lies in the frontal lobe and is supplied by the superior division of MCA and it causes motor/Brocas/nonfluent aphasia



Explanation of other options:

Option (A) Anomic Aphasia:A mild, fluent aphasia characterized by difficulty in word-finding, particularly for nouns and verbs, while comprehension and repetition remain intact.

Option (C )Broca's Aphasia:A non-fluent aphasia characterized by effortful, halting speech with relatively preserved comprehension but impaired repetition, commonly resulting from damage to the inferior frontal gyrus.

Option (D)Non-Fluent Aphasia:A classification of aphasias, including Broca's aphasia, where speech production is limited and effortful, often accompanied by relatively preserved comprehension.

questions.text:
A partogram of a woman who is in labour shows the findings:
Fetal heart rate: <110 bpm:
Amniotic fluid: Meconium stained:
Moulding: 2+:
Dilatation: 10 cm
Descent: Fetal head stuck at -3 station:
Oxytocin infusion is already given. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Signs of Fetal distress along with moulding and failure of head descent even after full cervical dilatation is suggestive of Cephalopelvic disproportion(CPD).

The best choice of management is the Cesarean section.

Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD) is a condition in which a baby's head or body is too large to pass through the mother's pelvis during childbirth. This mismatch between the fetal head and maternal pelvic size can prevent a safe vaginal delivery. CPD can be due to various factors, such as a large baby (often associated with diabetes in pregnancy), maternal pelvic abnormalities, or abnormal fetal positioning.

Diagnosis of CPD is generally made during labor if there is a failure to progress, despite strong contractions and proper fetal positioning. It is challenging to predict CPD before labor with certainty, as many women with borderline pelvic dimensions deliver successfully. When CPD is identified, a cesarean section is usually recommended to reduce risks to both the mother and baby.

Options A,B,C are not indicated in CPD.

questions.text: A 25 years old patient with a history of massive RTA developed dyspnea and petechial rashes after 3 days of trauma. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Fat emboli syndrome (FES)

  • Fat emboli syndrome (FES) is a condition characterized by respiratory distress, altered mental status, and skin petechiae.
  • Marrow fat from the fracture site is believed to enter the pulmonary circulation, where it causes activation of the coagulation cascade, platelet dysfunction, release of vasoactive substances and inflammatory cytokines, and subsequent neutrophil infiltration.
  • The treatment of FES is mostly supportive, but a meta analysis has shown that the use of corticosteroids in patients with multiple long bone fractures reduces the rate of FES by 78% without significantly increasing the risk of complications related to treatment of the fractures.

Infective emboli of bacteria or an infected clot may cause mycotic aneurysms, septicaemia or infected infarcts.

Parasitic emboli, caused by the ova of Taenia echinococcus and Filaria sanguinis hominis, may occur in some countries.

Tumor cells (e.g. hypernephroma and cardiac myxoma) are rare causes of emboli.

questions.text: The dietary requirement for an individual which fulfills the needs of 97.5% of individuals in the population is known as?
questions.solution:
The dietary requirement for an individual that fulfills the requirement of 97.5% of individuals in the population is known as Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA)

  • The Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) is the average daily dietary intake level that is sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option (A) RDAs are set based on Estimated Average Requirements (EARs) but include an additional safety margin to ensure that they cover the needs of most of the population.
  • Option (C ) Net Protein Utilization (NPU) refers to the percentage of absorbed protein that is retained and used for bodily functions and growth, not the overall nutrient requirement.
  • Option (D) Nutritive value generally refers to the nutritional content or quality of a food or diet, not a specific requirement level.

Net Protein Utilization (NPU):

  • NPU measures protein quality by combining digestibility coefficient and biological value, using the formula:
  • NPU = (Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen intake) × 100
  • It provides a more accurate assessment than amino acid score and requires specialized lab testing. For calculations, 1g protein = 6.25g nitrogen.
  • Protein requirements vary with NPU-lower NPU means higher protein need, and vice versa

questions.text: Identify the injury.
questions.solution:
When blunt force trauma occurs at bony prominence sites, the resulting injury may resemble an incised wound due to its clean edges but is actually a laceration. This type of injury is referred to as an incised-looking laceration. An example is a head injury caused by a blunt weapon.

Other options:

Incision: Sharp weapon injury, wound-regular margin, tissue bridges (intact muscle fibres & nerves) absent

Lacerated looking incised wound: When sharp force trauma occurs in areas with multiple skin folds, such as the axilla or scrotum, the resulting injuries may resemble lacerations due to their irregular margins.

Laceration: Blunt weapon injury, wound-irregular margin, tissue bridges present.

Key takeaways:


Types of Lacerated wound:

i) Split Laceration/Incised looking Lacerated wound: Blunt object, force of impact is perpendicular,site of injury is over bony prominences

ii) Stretch Laceration: Force of impact is tangential


iii) Avulsion/Degloving/Flaying/Shearing laceration: Force of impact is almost horizontal, skin gets avulsed


iv) Tear laceration: Direction of force is irregular eg falls over multiple small stones


v) Crush laceration: A heavy object like a bus passes over tissue, causing a crush to tissue. It may be total amputation, near total amputation, partial amputation. It doesn't depend upon direction of force while the first 4 types depend upon direction of force.


Incised wound:

Tailing of wound indicates incised wound.

choices.text: Cobalt blue filter and lissamine stain

questions.text: Identify the Stain with light as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Fluorescein sodium is a water-soluble dye that fluoresces bright green under blue (cobalt blue) light. It is used extensively to detect:

  • Corneal epithelial defects (e.g., abrasions, ulcers)
  • Tear film breakup time
  • Contact lens-related injuries
  • Foreign bodies
  • Seidel's test (to check for aqueous leak)

When cobalt blue light (wavelength ~465-490 nm) is used to illuminate an eye stained with fluorescein, the dye emits green fluorescence. This enhances the contrast and visibility of corneal lesions.

Other options:

Option B: Non-specific. No known diagnostic dye produces this combination in ophthalmology.

Option C: Lissamine green stains devitalized cells and mucin, often used in dry eye assessment. It does not fluoresce and appears green without special lighting. The image below shows diffuse lissamine green staining in a person with severe keratoconjunctivitis sicca.


Option D: Lissamine green does not require cobalt blue light and does not fluoresce. Hence, this combo is incorrect.

questions.text: True regarding the change seen in this image is?
questions.solution:
In the given image, greenish discoloration along the vessels due to postmortem changes is known as marbling.

Marbling:

  • Marbling is a characteristic sign of early decomposition, marked by a greenish-black discoloration along superficial subcutaneous veins, producing a marbled appearance of the skin.
  • After death, putrefactive anaerobic bacteria (especially Clostridium species) invade the blood vessels.
  • These bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S).
  • H2S reacts with hemoglobin to form iron sulfide, a dark pigment responsible for the color.
  • The pigment tracks along veins → produces a marbled or mosaic pattern under the skin.
  • Begins around 18-24 hours postmortem (earlier in warm, humid climates), becomes prominent in 36-48 hrs.
  • Considered an early sign of putrefaction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in speaking, tremors, and difficulty walking over the past 6 months. He has a history of irritability and mood swings for the past year. On examination, he has dysarthria, fine tremors, and muscle rigidity. His general examination shows mild jaundice and hepatomegaly. A slit-lamp examination reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism, leading to the accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, and cornea.
  • The Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a classic eye finding in Wilson's disease, seen on slit-lamp examination.
  • Kayser-Fleischer ring appears as a brownish-green ring around the corneal margin, particularly in the anterior part of the cornea. It is caused by copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea and is often present in patients with neurological and psychiatric symptoms, as well as hepatic involvement.
  • The patient's neurological signs (dysarthria, tremors, rigidity) and hepatic signs (jaundice, hepatomegaly) combined with the KF ring strongly point to Wilson's disease.
  • Differential diagnosis of Kayser-Fleischer ring:
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
    • Cryptogenic cirrhosis
    • Chronic cholestasis

Other options:

Option B: Hemochromatosis is a disorder of iron overload and typically presents with hepatomegaly, diabetes, and skin pigmentation. While it can lead to liver cirrhosis and neurological symptoms, it does not cause Kayser-Fleischer rings. Iron overloads deposits in tissues, unlike copper in Wilson's disease. Option C: Chronic copper poisoning can cause hepatic and renal dysfunction but does not typically present with Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea. The signs would be more related to toxic exposure and lack the neurological and psychiatric manifestations seen in Wilson's disease. Option D: Hereditary retinal degeneration, like retinitis pigmentosa, leads to vision loss and night blindness due to retinal damage. It does not cause Kayser-Fleischer rings, and the eye findings are more focused on the retina rather than the cornea

questions.text: person giving false evidence under oath will be punished under which section of the Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS)?
questions.solution:
Under the Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), Section 229 corresponds to Section 193 of IPC, which deals with punishment for intentionally giving false evidence, whether under oath or during a judicial proceeding.

This is particularly relevant when assessing the credibility of medico-legal testimonies, including witness depositions, medical expert reports, and sworn statements.


Explanation of other answers:

  • Section 227 BNS - Pertains to giving false evidence but this refers to the act itself, not the punishment.
  • Section 228 BNS - Deals with fabrication of false evidence
  • Section 234 BNS - Related to issuing false certificates

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with wrist pain on the lateral side. On examination, the following test was positive. Tendon sheath of which two muscles have been involved
questions.solution:
• The test shown in the image is Finkelstein's test.
  • This test is done to determine if there is Tenosynovitis in the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons of the wrist.
  • The condition is called de Quervain's disease, which gives rise to pain on the lateral side of the wrist.

Explanation of other options:

B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is in the third dorsal compartment, not involved in de Quervain's. Abductor pollicis brevis is a thenar muscle, not part of the wrist tendons.

C. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

Only abductor pollicis longus is involved. Abductor pollicis brevis is intrinsic to the hand and not affected in de Quervain's.

D. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

Extensor pollicis longus is part of the dorsal compartment and not involved in de Quervain's.


Reference: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Finkelstein%27s_test2.png

Author- Lillie. t

questions.text: A 25 years old male presented with a 2 cm nodule.Thyroidectomy was done. The histology picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histologic features seen are nuclear enlargement, overlapping, chromatin clearing ("Orphan Annie eye nuclei"), nuclear grooves, and intranuclear inclusions. These are classic for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).

Papillary thyroid carcinoma

PTC is the most common thyroid malignancy. Interestingly, up to 30% of patients who die of non- thyroid disease have deposits of PTC in autopsy studies, suggesting that many patients live with this disease undetected. Nonetheless, when PTC is diagnosed most patients will be offered treatment. The disease is known for its propensity for lymph node metastases.

These are more common in younger patients, in whom they do not affect the otherwise excellent survival. This finding is in contrast to most malignancies, where the finding of metastatic disease confers a poor outcome. One contentious finding in patients with PTC is a high rate of occult micrometastases (as high as 40% of N0 patients in the central neck). Despite the presence of metastases, few patients progress to have clinically meaningful disease and the role of elective nodal surgery is in question.

Distant metastases are uncommon in PTC.

Recently, increasing interest has focused on 'papillary microcarcinoma'. This term is used to describe a PTC that is <10 mm in size. These lesions are common (detected in about 10% of benign thyroid resections) and not associated with adverse outcomes, including recurrence or non-survival.

B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and shows amyloid deposition in stroma and elevated calcitonin, not the described nuclear features.

C) Toxic nodular goiter is a benign hyperplastic condition and does not show nuclear changes seen in PTC.

D) Follicular thyroid carcinoma shows capsular and vascular invasion without the nuclear features of PTC.

questions.text: Scurvy with delayed wound healing. Likely cause?
questions.solution:
Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency, which leads to impaired hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis. This results in defective collagen, a key structural protein in blood vessels, skin, gums, and bone matrix. Delayed wound healing is a hallmark of this defective collagen formation. Other features include bleeding gums, petechiae, anemia, swollen joints, and irritability.

Incorrect options:

B.Glucose synthesis error: Unrelated to the pathophysiology of scurvy. Glucose pathways do not contribute to collagen synthesis or vitamin C metabolism directly.

C.Calcium metabolism error: Seen in rickets or parathyroid disorders, but not related to scurvy or wound healing.

D.Vitamin C absorption error: Rare. While malabsorption can worsen deficiency, the clinical manifestation is due to defective collagen, not malabsorption per se.


Key Takeaways:-

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator for poor prognosis in a case of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
• β2-Microglobulin is the light chain of the class I major histocompatibility antigens (HLA-A, -B, -C) on the surface of every cell. It is the single most powerful predictor of survival

Serum albumin and β2 microglobulin are used for staging Multiple Myeloma and is known as the International Staging

System(ISS) it has replaced the Durie salmon staging.


Other poor prognostic factors in myeloma are- High labelling index, circulating plasma cells, poor performance status and high LDH levels.
