NS @ 20 ml/kg over 1 hr with insulin bolus
NS @ 10 ml/kg over 1 hr with insulin later
NS @ 20 ml/kg over 1 hr with insulin later

questions.text: A child with acidotic breathing, arterial pH 7.2, dehydration and urine 3+ for ketones with Blood glucose of 550 mg/dl. Management?
questions.solution:
The child is in moderate to severe DKA (pH 7.2, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, dehydration).

Initial management in pediatric DKA always starts with fluid resuscitation. The priority is to correct hypovolemia and perfusion deficits.

Normal saline (NS) 20 ml/kg over 1 hour is the standard initial fluid bolus.

Insulin is started only after 1-2 hours of fluid therapy, and not as a bolus-this helps prevent cerebral edema, a serious complication in pediatric DKA.


Incorrect Options:

  1. NS @ 10 ml/kg with insulin bolus: Inadequate fluid resuscitation and insulin bolus is contraindicated in children due to risk of cerebral edema.
  2. NS @ 20 ml/kg with insulin bolus: While fluid rate is correct, insulin bolus should never be given in pediatric DKA.
  3. NS @ 10 ml/kg with insulin later: Correct timing of insulin, but fluid volume is insufficient for initial resuscitation in moderate-severe DKA.

Key Takeaway:-

Following is the management protocol of diabetic ketoacidosis:-

questions.text:
A patient presented with bitemporal hemianopia. Imaging revealed an arterial aneurysm compressing the optic chiasma.
Which artery is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
• At the optic chiasm, the nasal fibers of the optic nerve decussate.
  • These crossed fibers are more damaged than the uncrossed fibers.
  • This leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • The structures that are close to the optic chiasm include the anterior communicating artery and the pituitary stalk.
  • Aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery or mass lesions of the sella cause this visual field defect.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the hospital with abdominal pain, jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss. On examination of radiography and CT scan, a physician finds a slowly growing Tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas. Which of the following structures is most likely compressed by the tumor?
questions.solution:
• Parts of the pancreas: Head, Neck, Body, and Tail.
  • The head has three borders-superior, inferior, and right lateral; two surfaces—anterior and posterior.
  • One process, projects from the lower and left part of the head towards the left, is called the Uncinate process.
  • Uncinate process: It is related anteriorly to the superior mesenteric vessels and posteriorly to the aorta.
  • Tumor of the Uncinate process of the pancreas affects the superior mesenteric vessels.

Explanation of other options:

(A) Portal vein: Formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas, not in direct relation to the uncinate process. Less likely to be compressed by a tumor in the uncinate region.

(B) Common hepatic artery: Lies superior to the pancreas and courses toward the liver. It is not adjacent to the uncinate process.

(D) Inferior mesenteric artery: Arises from the aorta well below the level of the pancreas. No direct anatomical relationship with the uncinate process.

choices.text: Dotted lines represent pressure with no micturition
Segment 1A denotes pressure due to residual urine
Micturition reflex is inhibited at phase 2

questions.text: True about the following figure?
questions.solution:
The figure is a cystometrogram, showing the relationship between bladder volume and intravesical pressure. Segment 1B is a long, relatively flat portion of the curve where bladder volume increases significantly with minimal change in pressure. This reflects the bladder's high compliance and plasticity, which is governed by the Laplace law (Tension = Pressure × Radius). Despite increasing volume, the bladder wall adapts by stretching, thus maintaining a relatively constant pressure. This property allows the bladder to store urine without triggering premature micturition. Therefore, Segment 1B accurately represents Laplace's law in action.


A normal cystometrogram, showing also acute pressure waves (dashed spikes) caused by micturition reflexes.

Explanation of other options:

a) Dotted lines represent pressure with no micturition Dotted lines show acute pressure spikes during micturition reflexes, not resting pressure. b) Segment 1A denotes pressure due to residual urine Segment 1A reflects the initial slight pressure rise with early bladder filling, not residual urine. d) Micturition reflex is inhibited at phase 2

In Segment II, the micturition reflex is initiated, not inhibited-hence the sharp rise in pressure.

questions.text: Rubella virus belongs to which family?
questions.solution:
The Rubella virus is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus that belongs to the family Togaviridae, genus Rubivirus. It is enveloped and has icosahedral symmetry.

Key characteristics:

  • Only one serotype exists globally.
  • Transmission: Primarily respiratory droplets; source can be subclinical infections.
  • Incubation period: Around 14-21 days (3-4 weeks).
  • Postnatal rubella: No carrier state.
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS): Infected infants can shed the virus for months, making them a prolonged source of infection

questions.text: A patient presents with a mediastinal mass and is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia (PRCA). What is the most probable cause of the aplasia?
questions.solution:
Thymoma is strongly associated with pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) due to its impact on immune regulation (immune-mediated destruction of erythroid precursors caused by abnormal T-cell function originating from the neoplastic thymic environment). This condition occurs in approximately 5-10% of thymoma cases. The mediastinal mass described is a hallmark of thymoma, which disrupts normal T-cell function, leading to autoimmune destruction of erythroid precursors.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) Bronchogenic carcinoma: While bronchogenic carcinoma can cause paraneoplastic syndromes, it is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia.
  • (B) Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can cause marrow infiltration leading to pancytopenia but is not a typical cause of isolated red cell aplasia.
  • (D) Breast cancer: Breast cancer may lead to anemia due to bone marrow metastases or chemotherapy, but it is not a recognized cause of pure red cell aplasia.

Key Takeaway:

A mediastinal mass with red cell aplasia is most commonly linked to thymoma, a tumor of the thymus gland, due to its autoimmune complications

questions.text: All are found in left ventricular failure. except?
questions.solution:
Lung oligemia is a condition characterized by reduced blood flow (perfusion) to the pulmonary vasculature, often seen as a radiologic finding in diseases where pulmonary blood flow is compromised like acute pulmonary embolism.Lung oligemia is not seen in cardiac failure

Tachycardia, pulsus alternans, elevated JVP, tender hepatomegaly, extremity edema, basal rales, pleural effusion, S3 gallop are all physical signs of heart failure.

Edema may be absent in acute HF especially in young even though venous pressure is high. There will be features of pulmonary congestion on chest X ray.

  • Upper lobe venous redistribution,
  • Interstitial edema (kerley B lines),
  • alveolar edema,
  • cardiomegaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with morning stiffness and reduced chest expansion. Also, the patient had a complaint of red eyes. What is the diagnosis on the basis of history and radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given xray shows bamboo spine due to osteophyte formation which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, progressive inflammatory arthritis which chiefly involves the synovial joints of the spine along with the adjacent soft tissues as well as the sacroiliac joints, although peripheral, large joints such as the hips, shoulders and knee can also be involved.

Radiological features:

SI joints: The classic sacroiliitis is bilateral and symmetrical. Changes occur in both the synovial along with ligamentous (superior and posterior) parts of the sacroiliac joints. The earliest radiographic findings occur in the subchondral cortex which appears blurred or lost. Later, small (rat-bite) erosions appear which are worse along the iliac aspect of the joint. These cause widening of the joint space with hazy margins. This is followed by larger erosions, subjacent sclerosis and joint space narrowing as irregular new bone bridges the joint space with eventual ankylosis and resolution of the sclerosis. The modified New York criteria is used for grading of sacroiliitis and was established in 1994.

Spine: Spinal involvement classically starts at the dorsolumbar or lumbosacral junction . Erosions initially occur at the vertebral margins at the site of attachment of the outer fibers of the annulus fibrosus (Romanus lesions) with adjacent sclerosis (shiny corner sign). Healing of these erosions or laying down of bone beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament causes "squaring" of the vertebral bodies, best appreciated on lateral radiographs of the lumbar spine. Exuberant new bone formation may even cause anterior convexity of the vertebral body (barrel- shapedvertebrae).

ossifications may be seen in the interspinous ligaments and facet joints causing the dagger and tram-track signs respectively. Facet joint ankylosis is the major factor causing loss of spinal mobility.


Dagger sign


Tram Track/Trolley sign

KEY TAKEAWAY- Radiological findings in Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Calcification of anterior longitudinal ligament.

Calcification of intervertebral disc giving rise to bamboo spine//Tram track sign/Trolley sign. Calcification of interspinous ligament- dagger sign

On MRI -lesions seen in the anterior part of intervertebral disc [Andersson lesion ].

questions.text: Which of the following maneuver is being done
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates the head tilt-chin lift maneuver, which is a fundamental airway-opening technique used in emergency and anesthesia settings. This maneuver helps to open the airway by relieving obstruction caused by the tongue falling back against the posterior pharynx, which commonly occurs when a patient is unconscious or unresponsive.

How it is performed:

  • The head is gently tilted backward by placing one hand on the patient's forehead and applying pressure to lift the head.
  • Simultaneously, the chin is lifted upward and forward using the fingertips of the other hand placed under the bony part of the chin.
  • This combined movement extends the neck and lifts the tongue away from the back of the throat, allowing unobstructed airflow.

Clinical significance:

  • It is the first step in airway management during CPR and emergency resuscitation when there is no suspicion of cervical spine injury.
  • It helps maintain a patent airway in unconscious patients until definitive airway management (like intubation) can be performed.
  • It is crucial to ensure adequate ventilation and oxygenation in patients who cannot protect their own airway.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6453697/

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is typically absent in a classic case of heat stroke?
questions.solution:
• Heat stroke results from failure of the thermoregulatory mechanism, leading to extremely high body temperature (up to 110°F or 43.3°C). It presents with delirium, convulsions, and altered consciousness. The skin is hot and dry, with absent or minimal sweating.
  • It is a medical emergency with a high case fatality rate (up to 40% or more), even with prompt treatment.
  • Management involves rapid body cooling, preferably in an ice-water bath, until rectal temperature falls below 102°F (38.9°C).

questions.text: Which vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines pose a theoretical risk of transmission to the fetus, and hence are contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • Live attenuated vaccines are avoided in pregnancy because of the risk of teratogenicity and vertical transmission.
  • If a woman receives the varicella vaccine, she should be advised to avoid pregnancy for at least 1 month after vaccination.

Incorrect Options:

B) Rabies vaccine:

  • Safe in pregnancy. Rabies is a fatal disease, so post-exposure prophylaxis is never delayed in pregnant women.
  • The vaccine used is inactivated, not live.

C) Tetanus toxoid:

  • Strongly recommended in pregnancy.
  • Protects both mother and newborn from tetanus.
  • Usually given as part of Tdap (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis) in antenatal care.

D)Hepatitis B vaccine:

  • Safe in pregnancy.
  • An inactivated vaccine, and routinely given to high-risk pregnant women.
  • Also given to newborns of hepatitis B-positive mothers within 24 hours of birth.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A Pap smear shows cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, pleomorphism, and a low maturation index, involving almost the entire thickness of the epithelium. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
Dysplasia refers to disordered growth and maturation of epithelial cells. Key features include:

  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Pleomorphism
  • Low or absent maturation from the basal to the superficial layer

When these changes involve most or all of the epithelial thickness but the basement membrane remains intact, the condition is classified as severe dysplasia or carcinoma in situ, a pre-malignant lesion.

Incorrect Answer Explanation:

  • (A) Metaplasia: Metaplasia is the replacement of one type of normal epithelium with another type, often as an adaptive response to stress. It does not involve nuclear pleomorphism or hyperchromasia.
  • (C) Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of normal cells in a tissue, without cellular atypia or disordered maturation.
  • (D) Carcinoma: Carcinoma refers to malignant epithelial tumors where the basement membrane is breached, which is not the case here.

Key Takeaway:

Hyperchromatic nuclei, pleomorphism, and low maturation index involving the entire epithelial thickness without invasion of the basement membrane are hallmarks of dysplasia or carcinoma in situ, a pre-malignant condition

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of trauma one week back presents with confusion and ataxia. He is on treatment for alcohol dependence and his last intake was 2 weeks back. CT scan reveals the following finding. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The red arrows point to a Hyperdense collection which is crossing the left fronto- temporal sutures, suggestive of left SDH

An SDH is a collection of acute blood products that lies in or between the inner border cell layer of the dura and the arachnoid.

Trauma is the most common cause of SDH.

Tearing of bridging cortical veins as they cross the subdural space to enter a dural venous sinus (usually the superior sagittal sinus) is the most common etiology.

MostSDHs spread diffusely over the affected hemisphere and are therefore typically crescent- shaped.



Left EDH-Biconvex lentiform does not cross suture lines.


Acute on chronic SDH - acute bleed - hyperdense Chronic bleed - hypodense


SAH - most common cause is rupture of berry aneurysm.

However in young people - head trauma is more common.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • SDH crosses sutures and does not cross midline.
  • EDH is limited by sutures.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female delivered a 1 kg baby at 31 weeks of gestation. The child has hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. On CT, periventricular calcification is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease is the most common cause of CNS infection in neonates.

It results from vertical transmission of the CMV from the mother to the fetus transplacentally.

In congenital infections the pattern of distribution of calcification helps to identify the causative organism.

In CMV, it is seen in the periventricular region. Toxoplasmosis shows randomly distributed lesions.


Periventricular calcification in CMV.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Periventricular calcification seen in CMV

Intraparenchymal calcification (diffuse nodular calcification at basal ganglia) seen in Toxoplasmosis.

Sub ependymal calcification seen in Tuberous sclerosis. Starry sky calcification- Neurocysticercosis

questions.text: Disc diffusion method is also known as
questions.solution:
The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a standardized microbiological technique used to assess the antibiotic susceptibility of bacterial pathogens.

Key Features:

  • A standardized bacterial inoculum is evenly spread over the surface of a Mueller-Hinton agar plate.
  • Filter paper discs impregnated with antibiotics are placed on the agar.
  • After incubation (usually 18-24 hours at 35-37°C), zones of inhibition are measured around the discs.
  • Results are interpreted as Sensitive (S), Intermediate (I), or Resistant (R) using CLSI (Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute) or EUCAST guidelines.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • B) VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test): A serological test for syphilis, not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing.
  • C) Dark field microscopy: A diagnostic technique for visualizing spirochetes, like Treponema pallidum, not used for antimicrobial testing.

choices.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
50% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

questions.text: In a patient with parathyroid adenoma, how do we confirm the removal of the correct gland after surgery?
questions.solution:
The Miami criteria are used to confirm successful resection of a hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland during parathyroidectomy. According to this protocol, a drop in intraoperative PTH levels by at least 50% from the highest pre-excision value within 10 minutes after gland removal confirms that the source of excess PTH has been excised. This relies on the short half-life of PTH (3-5 minutes). If the PTH does not drop as expected, multiglandular disease may be present, and further exploration is warranted.

80% of individuals with PHPT have a single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy , where the localised abnormal parathyroid gland is removed

Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by u performing an intraoperative PTH assay.

The basic concept is that the half-life of circulating PTH is 3-5 minutes and there should therefore be a significant drop detected in the plasma PTH following resection of a single adenoma.

If no such drop is detected, then multigland disease may be suspected and conversion to a bilateral neck exploration should be considered.

The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection. A drop in the PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease

B. 50% in 5 minutes - Too early; standard measurements are taken at 10 minutes to allow for full metabolic clearance.

C and D. 25% reduction - Insufficient drop; may indicate residual hyperfunctioning tissue or multiple adenomas.

Therefore, a ≥50% drop in PTH within 10 minutes confirms successful removal per Miami criteria.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of fever, photosensitivity, rash sparing nasolabial fold presents to OPD. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by:

  • Multisystem involvement: Skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, and nervous system.
  • Classic symptoms: Fever, photosensitivity, and rash sparing the nasolabial fold (characteristic of the malar rash in SLE).
  • Demographics: More than 90% of cases occur in women, commonly of childbearing age.

The presence of fever, photosensitivity, and a malar rash sparing the nasolabial fold strongly suggests SLE.

Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Dermatomyositis:
    • Features include a heliotrope rash (violaceous rash on the eyelids) and Gottron's papules (over knuckles), which are not seen in this case.
    • Photosensitivity can occur, but joint pain and fever are less prominent.
  • (C) Melasma:
    • A pigmentary disorder presenting with brownish hyperpigmentation over sun-exposed areas.
    • It lacks systemic features such as fever, joint pain, or photosensitivity-related inflammation.
  • (D) Rosacea:
    • Typically presents with erythema, papules, and pustules on the face, sparing the nasolabial fold.
    • Photosensitivity is not a hallmark, and systemic symptoms like fever and joint pain are absent.

Key Takeaway:

When a woman of childbearing age presents with fever, photosensitivity, joint pain, and a rash sparing the nasolabial fold, always consider SLE as the primary diagnosis.

questions.text: The active principle of this seed is?
questions.solution:
Given this seed is semecarpus anacardium/Marking nut seed. Its active principle is Bhilawanol. It is used to prepare artificial bruises.

Ricinus communis (Castor plant):


  • Active principle: Ricin
  • Ricin is only present in press cake, not in oil.

Croton tiglium:


  • Active principle:Crotin & Crotonoside
  • Both press cake & oil contain croton.

Arbus precatorious (Crab's eye, Ratti, Gunnar, Gunchi):


  • Active principle: Abrin
  • Medicolegal aspect: Abrin also used in SUI preparation.

questions.text: A child has enlarged tonsils, fever and is unable to swallow. The patient is also complaining of ear pain. What is the likely source of ear pain?
questions.solution:
The tympanic branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the palatine tonsils and also supplies the sensory supply to the medial surface of tympanic membrane and middle ear. So the patient having enlarged tonsils complain of the referred earache due to common nerve supply.


Other options:

Arnold's nerve supplies the sensation to the external acoustic meatus but is not commonly associated with the ear pain.

The greater Auricular nerve supplies the skin of the lower part of the external ear. It is also unlikely to be the cause of the ear pain, as the pain is associated with swallowing.

The auriculotemporal nerve supplies the salivary gland; it is unlikely to cause earaches associated with the pain while swallowing.

questions.text: A military soldier present with fever, rash and myalgia. There is an absence of rash in palms and soles. History of louse infestation in the present battalion is also present. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
The presentation described (fever, rash, myalgia, absence of rash on palms and soles, and history of louse infestation) is consistent with Epidemic Typhus, which is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

It is transmitted to humans by the body louse (Pediculus humanus), especially in conditions of crowded and unhygienic environments such as military barracks during wartime or outbreaks.

Epidemic typhus

  • Epidemic or louse borne typhus was in the past the most formidable disease caused by rickettsiae.
  • The infection is transmitted from man to man by the infected louse (P. corporis and P. capitis).
  • Man acquires the disease not by the bite of the louse, but:
    • By scratching and inoculating himself with the infected louse feces
    • By crushing an infected louse on his person
    • Inhalation of infected louse feces or dust.
  • The infected louse after 10-14 days of existence dies of the infection.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Epidemic typhus is an acute febrile disease; accompanied by headache, myalgia, eye discharge and rashes occurring after an incubation period of 1-2 weeks.
    • Rash begins on the upper trunk, usually on the fifth day and then becomes generalized, involving the entire body except the face, palms and soles.
  • In humans, the organisms can persist for many years as latent infection without any symptoms and the disease may appear later as Brill-Zinsser disease and can be transmitted to other humans by the louse.
  • The control measures comprise anti-louse measures and improvements in personal hygiene and living conditions. Under the International Health Regulations, louse-borne typhus is subject to international surveillance.

questions.text: A middle aged woman with bilateral proptosis with restricted ocular movement and chemosis. Her thyroid profile is euthyroid. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of bilateral proptosis with restricted ocular movement and chemosis with euthyroid profile suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.


Thyroid Associated Ophthalmopathy (TAO):

  • Most common cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults.
  • It can occur in any state of thyroid activity.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Inflammation → Enlargement of extra-ocular muscles → Infiltration of orbital fat → Pushing of eyeball forward → proptosis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Eye signs (Dalrymple sign- most common, Von Graefe sign, Stellwag sign)
    • Proptosis
    • Restrictive squint (muscle affected first: inferior rectus, elevation affected first)
  • Complications: Exposure keratitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with multiple firm, non-tender nodules over his Achilles tendons and extensor surfaces of the hands. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 45. Laboratory results reveal markedly elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels, with normal triglycerides. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder. It leads to markedly elevated LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol. Clinical signs include tendon xanthomas (especially in the Achilles tendon and extensor tendons of the hands) and premature atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. In this group lysosomal acid lipase deficiency is associated with micronodular cirrhosis.

  1. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency - This is seen in familial chylomicronemia syndrome. It leads to elevated chylomicrons and severe hypertriglyceridemia, not high LDL. Clinical findings include eruptive xanthomas, pancreatitis, and lipemia retinalis, not tendon xanthomas.
  2. Tangier disease - This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It leads to very low HDL levels and peripheral neuropathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. LDL may be low or normal, and tendon xanthomas are not typical.
  3. Familial chylomicronemia syndrome - Caused by lipoprotein lipase deficiency or ApoC-II deficiency. It presents with elevated triglycerides, eruptive xanthomas, pancreatitis, and hepatosplenomegaly, usually in childhood. LDL is not elevated, and tendon xanthomas are not seen.

Hypertriglyceridemia is seen in familial chylomicronemia syndrome and familial partial lipodystrophy. They are associated with eruptive xanthomas and pancreatitis.


Tangiers disease is associated with very low HDL and is associated with peripheral neuropathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Other diseases associated with low HDL are as follows:

Primary hypolipidemias: In this group abeta liporoteinemia is characterized by spinocerebellar degeneration and retinaldegeneration. Mixed dyslipidemia:

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with increasing abdominal girth and decreased liver span. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with eosinophilic material cytokeratin positive. What is the content of the inclusions?
questions.solution:
In a chronic alcoholic patient with deceased liver span the diagnosis is Alcoholic liver disease which can be steatosis, hepatitis or cirrhosis. In a patient who continues to consume alcohol, a combination of the three can be seen. The eosinophilic inclusions described are Mallory hyaline bodies, which are characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis. These are composed of intermediate filaments, specifically cytokeratins 8 and 18, which become abnormally accumulated and clumped due to hepatocyte injury. These inclusions stain positively for cytokeratin on immunohistochemistry.

Microtubules and actin are part of the cytoskeleton but are not the predominant components of Mallory hyaline. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein and not a cytoplasmic intermediate filament. Hence, the correct answer is intermediate filaments.

  • Alcoholic steatosis is characterised by the presence of microvesicular steatosis
  • Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by Ballooned hepatocytes, where the hepatocytes are damaged with cleared out cytoplasm and with extensive cytoskeletal damage resulting in eosinophilic bodies called Mallory Hyaline, which are intermediate filaments-Keratin 8 and Keratin I8 (Hence they stain positive for cytokeratin)
    • Inflammation and necrosis
    • Perivenular fibrosis: initially appear as chicken wire fibrosis. Later leads to periportal and bridging fibrosis known as Laennec Cirrhosis
    • Cirrhosis liver is characterized microscopically by the presence of parenchymal nodules surrounded by areas of fibrosis throughout the liver, resulting in the formation of nodules.
    • Fibrosis can be stained using Masson's Trichrome.

So, under light microscope the intermediate filaments appear as Mallory hyaline which are seen collapsed into the cell and they stain positive for cytokeratin.

  1. Microtubules - These are made of tubulin and involved in intracellular transport and mitosis, but they do not form Mallory-Denk bodies.
  2. Actin - This is a component of the microfilament system, involved in cell motility and structure, but not the main component of Mallory-Denk bodies.
  3. Fibronectin - This is an extracellular glycoprotein involved in cell adhesion and matrix formation; it is not a cytoplasmic structure and not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• A sebaceous cyst (technically an epidermoid cyst) is a benign, encapsulated nodule filled with keratin material.
  • Common locations: Face, neck, trunk, genitalia, and fingers, though it can occur anywhere.
  • It presents as a slowly progressing, painless nodule that remains stable for years unless infected or inflamed.
  • It is unrelated to sebaceous glands and forms within the infundibulum.
  • These cysts may be associated with Gardner syndrome or Gorlin syndrome in rare cases.

Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Alopecia areata:
    • A patchy, non-scarring hair loss condition caused by autoimmune destruction of hair follicles.
    • No cystic lesions are present.
  • (C) Trichotillomania:
    • Characterized by self-induced hair pulling, leading to irregular patches of hair loss.
    • No nodular lesions or cystic components are found.
  • (D) Tinea capitis:
    • A fungal infection of the scalp causing scaly patches of hair loss, sometimes with inflammation or pustules.
    • Does not present as a cyst. 

Key Takeaway: 

A sebaceous cyst is a benign, encapsulated subepidermal nodule filled with keratin. It is often misnamed but should be differentiated from inflammatory or infectious scalp conditions.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and mild fatigue for the past few days. On examination, he has an irregularly irregular pulse with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute and a pulse rate of 100 per minute. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Jugular venous pulse (JVP) tracing is evaluated. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on JVP examination
questions.solution:
The patient has signs suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF), indicated by an irregularly irregular pulse and pulse deficit (difference between the heart rate and palpable pulse > 10). In AF, the atria do not contract effectively. Instead, they fibrillate due to disorganized electrical activity, which means that atrial contraction is absent. In the jugular venous pulse (JVP), the 'a' wave corresponds to atrial contraction. Since atrial contraction does not occur in AF, the 'a'wave is absent.

Irregularly irregular pulse, Pulse deficit> 10 indicates Atrial Fibrillation. 'a'wave in JVP is an expression of normal atrial contraction.

In JVP, a patient with AF 'a' wave will be absent.

  1. Canon a wave - These occur when the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve, typically seen in ventricular tachycardia or AV dissociation, not in AF.
  2. Absent y-descent - Seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, not in atrial fibrillation.
  3. Prominent v wave - Seen in tricuspid regurgitation due to backflow into the right atrium during systole, not typically associated with AF.

questions.text: A 4yr child while playing, suddenly pulled back her elbow from nanny's hand and started crying and not allowing anyone to touch the elbow. She is keeping the elbow extended and pronated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This condition occurs in children between 2-5 years of age. The head of the radius is pulled partly out of the annular ligament when a child is lifted by the wrist. The child starts crying and is unable to move the affected limb. The forearm lies in an attitude of pronation. There may be mild swelling at the elbow. It is not possible to see the subluxated head on an X-ray because it is still cartilaginous; X-rays are taken only to rule out any other bony injury.


Incorrect Options:

  • A. Radial head fracture: Rare in this age group; presents with pain and swelling over the radial head, and limited range of motion, especially supination/pronation. Trauma is usually direct.
  • C. Supracondylar fracture: Common elbow fracture in children but presents with significant swelling, deformity, severe pain, and often associated neurovascular compromise.
  • D. Elbow dislocation: Rare in children without high-energy trauma. Presents with obvious joint deformity, swelling, and loss of elbow contour.

questions.text: A young Diabetic patient has presented to ENT OPD with blood stained nasal discharge, eye involvement and recent history of loose upper teeth. Which of the following is the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Blood-stained nasal discharge, eye involvement, loose upper teeth strongly suggest rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis, an invasive fungal infection common in uncontrolled diabetics, especially after ketoacidosis or immunosuppression.

Mucormycosis is an angioinvasive fungus that spreads through sinuses to orbit and the brain. MRI gives excellent visualization of:

  • Soft tissue planes
  • Orbital involvement
  • Intracranial extension
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Early imaging helps assess the extent of invasion, plan surgical debridement, and start antifungal therapy urgently. MRI is more sensitive than CT for detecting soft tissue and intracranial spread.

Other options:

Serum Ferritin Level:

  • Nonspecific acute phase reactant.
  • Elevated in many conditions including infections, inflammations, malignancy.
  • Does not confirm or exclude mucormycosis.
  • Not useful for diagnosis or treatment planning.

Glycosylated Hemoglobin (HbA1c):

  • Reflects average blood sugar over 3 months.
  • Tells about long-term diabetic control, but:
    • Does not contribute to acute diagnosis.
    • Doesn't guide the extent of disease or immediate treatment.

Nasal Swab:

  • Superficial test.
  • Often misses deep-seated fungal infection.
  • False negatives are common.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires biopsy of necrotic tissue for KOH mount and culture.
  • Swab is not reliable and not suitable as a first-line

questions.text: A patient is having gastrointestinal symptoms such as pain in abdomen and distension, bloody and mucus diarrhoea and tenesmus with rectal prolapse. A stool microscopy reveals the presence of typical barrel shaped eggs. Possible causative agent is?
questions.solution:
• Trichuris trichiura eggs are barrel-shaped (football- or lemon-shaped) measuring approximately 50-55 µm by 20-25 µm.
  • They possess thick brown shells with a pair of characteristic polar plugs at each end.
  • Eggs are passed unembryonated in the stool and darken to brown as they age in the environment.
  • Ingestion of embryonated eggs → larvae hatch in the small intestine → adults embed in cecal/colonic mucosa.
  • Heavy worm burden causes mucosal inflammation, leading to abdominal pain, distension, bloody/mucoid diarrhea, and tenesmus.
  • Chronic, intense infection in children often results in rectal prolapse due to prolonged straining and mucosal edema.
  • Life Cycle
    • Fecal-oral transmission: unembryonated eggs → embryonate in soil (2-3 weeks) → ingested by human host → larval development in small intestine → adult worm residence in colon.
  • Epidemiology & Risk Factors
    • Common in tropical/subtropical regions with poor sanitation.
    • Children are most susceptible; heavy infections correlate with malnutrition and growth retardation.
  • Diagnosis: Identification of characteristic barrel-shaped, brown eggs with bipolar plugs on stool microscopy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Campylobacter - Gram-negative curved bacilli causing acute bacterial gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea; no eggs on stool microscopy.
  • Option B: Giardia lamblia - Protozoan producing foul-smelling, non-bloody, greasy diarrhea; stool shows flagellated trophozoites or cysts, not barrel-shaped eggs.
  • Option C: Enterobius vermicularis - Pinworm eggs are ovoid with a flattened side, measure ~50-60 µm × 20-30 µm, and are not barrel-shaped; infection causes perianal pruritus rather than dysentery or rectal prolapse.

questions.text: Not suggestive of cocaine poisoning is?
questions.solution:
Cocaine poisoning typically causes sympathetic overstimulation, resulting in tachycardia.

Bradycardia is commonly seen in somniferous poisons, which include substances that cause sedation, drowsiness, or coma e.g. opioids, barbiturates, and Benzodiazepines severe overdose.

Key takeaways:

Cocaine:

  • Also known as coke, cadilac, white lady
  • Extracted from:Erythroxylum cocca plant

  • Method of drug abuse:Snorting & smokable preparation crack (Cocaine + baking soda + water)

  • C/F:
    • Sympathetic overstimulation (symptoms: Tachycardia, dilated pupil)
    • Hallucinations(Visual >Tactile)
    • Formication: Person feels some insects crawling over skin & sand grains under skin,in Cocaine poisoning this Formication is specifically called Magnan's symptoms.
    • Black tongue & teeth
    • Perforated nasal septum

  • Antidote: Diazepam + Amyl nitrile

questions.text: Serum prolactin is highest at
questions.solution: Prolactin levels during the initial 10 days of lactation have an average baseline of approximately 200 mg/dL with further increases to peak levels(400 ng/dL) after suckling . Baseline and peak levels subsequently decrease over the duration of lactation. Milk yield is not directly correlated to prolactin levels.

questions.text: Patient with generalized fatigue, tiredness. Primary clinical examination is uneventful. Normal TLC and DLC. No immature cells were seen. Superficial discrete lymph nodes enlarged. On biopsy showed effaced architecture, indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. CD10 and bcl2 positive.
questions.solution:
The histological and immunophenotypic findings are characteristic of follicular lymphoma, a common indolent subtype of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Key diagnostic features include:

  • Effacement of normal lymph node architecture
  • Atypical lymphoid cells with cleaved (indented) nuclei and prominent nucleoli
  • Positivity for CD10 and Bcl-2, which helps differentiate follicular lymphoma from reactive follicular hyperplasia (where Bcl-2 is usually negative)

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (B) Burkitt's lymphoma: While Burkitt’s lymphoma also shows atypical cells, it typically demonstrates a "starry sky" pattern on histology and does not express bcl-2. It is associated with a high proliferation index (Ki-67 > 95%).
  • (C) Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: Follicular lymphoma is a subtype of non- Hodgkin's lymphoma, but the specific findings in this case point to follicular lymphoma, not a generic diagnosis of NHL.
  • (D) Fungoid mycoses: This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with skin lesions, not generalized lymphadenopathy and bcl-2 positivity.

Key Takeaway:

Generalized lymphadenopathy with effaced lymph node architecture, CD10, and bcl-2 positivity is diagnostic of follicular lymphoma, a type of indolent non- Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: An adult patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. He has a history of regular medication. The nasal examination shows the presence of nasal polypi. Which drug he is most likely sensitive to?
questions.solution:
• The patient's known case of bronchial asthma and the presence of nasal polyp suggest that the patient may have Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), also known as Samter's Triad.
  • AERD is a condition where patients with asthma develop a hypersensitivity reaction to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like Aspirin, leading to exacerbation of respiratory symptoms, including nasal polyps and bronchospasm.
  • It is essential to avoid NSAIDs in such patients as they can trigger severe bronchoconstriction and worsen asthma symptoms.

Other options:

Ampicillin: This is a penicillin antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin, so it is a less likely option for a patient with nasal polyps.

Penicillin: This is another penicillin antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is also not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin, so it is a less likely option for a patient with nasal polyps.

Erythromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is not a member of the aspirin family, so it is not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin.

questions.text: A patient on inhaled corticosteroids for bronchial asthma presents with white lesions on the buccal mucosa consistent with oral thrush. Which antifungal is most appropriate for management?
questions.solution:
• Oral thrush is due to Candida albicans Inhaled steroids reduce local immunity in the oropharynx.
  • Clotrimazole Troches (lozenges): Dissolve slowly in the mouth, directly delivering high concentrations of drug to the infected mucosa with minimal systemic absorption. 10 mg troche of clotrimazole is allowed to dissolve in the mouth 3 - 4 times a day, or the lotion/gel is applied/swirled in the mouth for as long as possible.
  • Clotrimazole is an imidazole antifungal that inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent 14-α-demethylase.
  • Clotrimazole is also effective in the treatment of tinea infections like 60-100% cure rates are reported with 2 - 4 weeks application on a twice daily schedule.
  • Athletes' foot, otomycosis and oral/cutaneous/vaginal candidiasis have responded in >80% cases.
  • It is particularly favoured for vaginitis because of a long lasting residual effect after once daily application. A 7 day course is generally used.
  • It is also effective in skin infections caused by Corynebacteria, but like most topical antifungals, has poor efficacy in tinea capitis (scalp) and tinea unguium (nails).

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Terbinafine is an allylamine that inhibits squalene epoxidase; effective against dermatophytes (tinea), not indicated for mucosal Candida.
  • Option C: Flucytosine is a systemic pyrimidine analog used in combination with amphotericin B for severe systemic infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis); not used as monotherapy for superficial thrush.
  • Option D: Griseofulvin is an antifungal that disrupts microtubule function; therapy for dermatophyte infections (tinea capitis, corporis); no activity against Candida.

choices.text: A fibres are more susceptible to pressure than C fibres
B fibres are more susceptible to pressure than A fibres
C fibres are more susceptible to hypoxia than A fibres
C fibres are more susceptible to pressure than A fibres

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with complaints of paresis and numbness after sleeping on his arm. Which of the following explains the phenomenon correctly?
questions.solution:
When a patient sleeps on their arm for a prolonged period, it can cause compression of peripheral nerves, leading to temporary conduction block. According to the data:

  • Large-diameter, myelinated A fibers (which include motor, touch, and proprioception fibers) are more sensitive to pressure than small, unmyelinated C fibers (which carry pain and temperature).
  • This explains why motor weakness and numbness (due to impaired A fiber function) may occur, while pain sensation (carried by C fibers) is relatively preserved.
  • This is the physiological basis for "Saturday night paralysis", commonly seen in intoxicated patients who fall asleep with their arm compressed.

Based on: Erlanger and Gasser classification:


Explanation of other options:

Option b) B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers

A fibers are more susceptible to pressure than B fibers.

Option c) C fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than A fibers

B > A > C for hypoxia susceptibility. C fibers are least affected by hypoxia.

Option d) C fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers

C fibers are more resistant to pressure than A fibers, which is why pain sensation often persists.

questions.text: While recording evidence in a court of law, the lawyer asked the witness - "Did you see that Mr. 'A' killed Mr. 'B'?". The witness answered - "Yes". This type of question is permitted in?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the lawyer is asking leading questions to the witness. Leading questions are permitted during cross-examination and re-cross-examination.

Leading questions can also be asked during examination-in-chief and re-examination if the witness is declared hostile.

The judge may ask leading questions at any time during the proceedings.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Which of the following ligament develops in the arrow-marked structure
questions.solution:
• The abdominal part of the foregut is suspended by mesenteries both ventrally and dorsally.
  • The ventral mesentery of the foregut is called the ventral mesogastrium, and the dorsal mesentery is called the dorsal mesogastrium (gastrium means stomach)
  • The ventral mesogastrium becomes divided by the developing liver into a ventral part and a dorsal part.
  • The ventral part forms the ligaments of the liver, namely:
    • The falciform (Latin sickle-shaped) ligament
    • The right and left triangular ligaments
    • The superior and inferior layers of the coronary ligament
  • The dorsal part of the ventral mesogastrium forms the lesser omentum.
  • The fate of the dorsal mesogastrium is as follows.
    • The greater or caudal part of the dorsal mesogastrium becomes greatly elongated and forms the greater omentum.
    • The spleen develops in relation to the cranial part of the dorsal mesogastrium, and divides it into dorsal and ventral parts.
    • The ventral part forms the gastrosplenic ligament while the dorsal part forms the lienorenal ligament.
    • The cranial-most part of the dorsal mesogastrium forms the gastrophrenic ligament.

Derivatives of mesogastrium are as follows:


Explanation of other options:

  • (Option B) Gastrophrenic Ligament
    • Arises from the cranial-most part of the dorsal mesogastrium, not the ventral
  • (Option C) Gastrosplenic Ligament
    • Develops from the ventral part of the cranial dorsal mesogastrium, associated with the spleen and stomach, not the liver.
  • (Option D) Lienorenal Ligament
    • Arises from the dorsal part of the dorsal mesogastrium in relation to the spleen and posterior abdominal wall, not from the ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea, and weight loss for the past 2 weeks. He has recently returned from a rural area in India. Colonoscopy reveals multiple ulcers in the colon, and biopsy shows flask-shaped ulcers extending into the submucosa. Stool microscopy reveals trophozoites with ingested red blood cells.

What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of invasive intestinal amoebiasis, a condition caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. Key diagnostic clues include:

Histopathology & Stool Findings:

  • Flask-shaped ulcers in the colon are characteristic.
    • These ulcers have a narrow neck and broad base, extending into the submucosa.
  • Trophozoites with ingested RBCs on stool microscopy are diagnostic of histolytica and distinguish it from non-pathogenic amoebae.

Other Clinical Features:

  • Bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and sometimes fever
  • Often associated with poor sanitation, contaminated food or water, and travel to endemic areas (e.g., India, Africa, Latin America)
  • Can lead to extraintestinal manifestations, such as amoebic liver abscess

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • A) Giardia lamblia
    • Causes non-invasive infection of the small intestine, leading to greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea (steatorrhea) but no ulcer formation or blood in stool.
  • C) Helicobacter pylori
    • Infects the stomach, not the colon. Associated with gastritis, gastric ulcers, and peptic ulcer disease, not bloody diarrhea or flask-shaped colonic ulcers.
  • D) Enterobius vermicularis
    • Commonly causes perianal itching (especially in children) but does not invade the intestine or cause ulcers or bloody diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient received 48 hrs after fracture of femur presented with confusion and breathing difficulty. He is having PaO2 of 50. He was put on rebreathing unit and started maintaining SPO2 of 100%, but remains confused. Chest is clear. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism syndrome is a classic complication of long bone fractures (especially femur), typically appearing 24-72 hours post-injury.

It results from fat globules entering the bloodstream, lodging in pulmonary and cerebral vasculature.

The classic triad of FES includes:

  • Respiratory distress / hypoxemia
  • Neurological symptoms (confusion, agitation)
  • Petechial rash (though not always present)

Chest auscultation may be clear initially; hypoxia out of proportion to clinical findings is a clue.

Despite oxygenation, persistent confusion suggests cerebral fat emboli.

Incorrect Options:

A. Pulmonary embolism: Also causes sudden dyspnea and hypoxia, but usually presents acutely and is less likely 48 hours after trauma without risk factors like DVT. Also, neurological symptoms are rare in PE.

D. None: Incorrect, as the findings clearly support fat embolism syndrome in the context of recent long bone fracture.

choices.text: Operated only if patient is symptomatic
Majority of the goiters derive their blood supply from mediastinal vessels
Majority of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by aneckincision

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding retrosternal goiters?
questions.solution:
Retrosternal goiters are usually the result of downward extension of a long-standing multinodular goiter into the thoracic inlet. Despite their position, more than 95% of these goiters can be excised via a transcervical (neck) incision.

Retrosternal goiter tends to arise from the slow growth of a multinodular gland down into the mediastinum.As the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression and eventually airway symptoms. The vast majority of patients have minimal symptoms.

Patients should be considered for surgery if there is significant airway compression, if symptoms are present or in young patients in whom symptoms are likely to develop. In elderly patients with incidentally discovered retrosternal goiters, most surgeons would observe rather than treat prophylactically.Clearly a balance between risk and benefit must be made. If a decision is made to proceed to surgery, assessment of the extent of disease is critical. The vast majority (>95%) of retrosternal goiters can be removed transcervically. Patients most at risk of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach include those with malignant disease or who are undergoing revision, those whose goiters that extend into the posterior mediastinum and those in whom the diameter of the goiter exceeds that of the thoracic inlet. 

A. Surgery is indicated only if the patient is symptomatic - Incorrect, because surgery may also be considered in asymptomatic patients at risk of future compression or complications, especially younger patients.

B. A sternal incision is always required - Incorrect, as very less number of cases require sternotomy, typically in cases of malignancy, posterior mediastinal extension, or revision surgery.

C. Most derive their blood supply from mediastinal vessels - Incorrect, the majority of retrosternal goiters retain their cervical blood supply (superior and inferior thyroid arteries), which helps facilitate neck dissection.

questions.text: A patient has presented with loss of sensation over the lateral 3 1/2 fingers on the palmar aspect. Choose the CORRECT pair for the anatomical structure involved and the test conducted for the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• A patient has sensory loss over the lateral three and half fingers on the palmar aspect, suggestive of median nerve compression.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS): Involvement of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel at the wrist has become a very common entity.
  • The Carpal Compression Test or Durkan's Test is performed by holding the patient's wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the median nerve by applying pressure to the proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds. A positive result occurs if the patient develops pain, paresthesia, or numbness in the median nerve distribution.
  • The carpal tunnel syndrome includes motor and sensory changes as follows:
  • Motor changes: Ape-/monkey-like thumb deformity, loss of opposition of thumb. Index and middle fingers lag behind while making the fist due to paralysis of the 1st and 2nd lumbrical muscles.

  • Lagging behind of index and middle fingers in making the fist due to paralysis of the first and second lumbrical muscles in median nerve paralysis
  • Sensory changes: Loss of sensations on lateral 3½ digits, including the nail beds and distal phalanges on the dorsum of the hand.

Key Notes:

  • Guyon canal, also called the ulnar tunnel, is located at the medial side of the palm between the pisiform and hamate bones. The ulnar nerve and artery pass through this canal.
  • Froment's sign/book holding test: The patient is unable to hold the book with thumbs and other fingers. This test is to test the adductor pollicis muscle that is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Other Options

  • (A) Guyon's canal and Froment test
    • Guyon's canal involves the ulnar nerve, and Froment test is for adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).
  • (B) Guyon's canal and Durkan test
    • Durkan test is not used for the ulnar nerve.
  • (C) Carpal tunnel and Froment test
    • Froment's test does not evaluate median nerve or carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old presented with altered sensorium. CT reveals Bitemporal hemorrhage.

What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HSV-1 occurs due to reactivation of latent infection. The trigeminal ganglion is the most common site of reactivation.

A retrograde transmission of the infection along the trigeminal nerve to the brainstem results in pontine infection/rhombencephalitis.

The herpes virus has a predilection for the inferomedial temporal lobes, the insular cortex and the cingulate gyrus.

Bitemporal lesions commonly seen in herpes simplex infection. It has a propensity to involve the temporal lobes due to it's neurotropic nature of infection.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

Tb - shows basal exudates, infarcts & hydrocephalus Herpes Simplex-Mc involves temporal lobes

Japanese encephalitis- involves b/l thalmi. Varicella- involve cerebellar hemisphere

questions.text: A 30 year old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown to identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Putty kidney refers to the extensive parenchymal and pelvicalyceal system calcification occurring in the kidney. This is usually seen in chronic tubercular infection when there is extensive parenchymal and pelvicalyceal system calcification in the kidneys resulting in atrophic scarred calcified kidneys.


Psoas Abscess.


Staghorn Calculus.


Nephrocalcinosis - it is of two types

  1. Medullary Nephrocalcinosis- seen in hyperparathyroidism, hypervitaminosis vitD, Medullary sponge kidney
  2. Cortical Nephrocalcinosis- seen in Alport syndrome, Cortical necrosis.

Key TAKEAWAY-

questions.text: A anaesthetist was doing shoulder block with 0.25% bupivacaine, the patient become unresponsive and pulse become unrecordable. The best management in this patient would be
questions.solution:
• Local anesthesia systemic toxicity can be treated with 20% intralipid emulsion along with CPR if the patient becomes unconscious.
  • Cardiotoxicity and CNS toxicity are seen in the toxicity of local anesthetics like bupivacaine and levobupivacaine.
  • Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration and cerebral bupivacaine content by 18% within 15 minutes of administration.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Popeye sign is a pronounced bulging muscle in the distal aspect of the biceps region of the arm. It is clinically apparent with a complete long head of biceps tendon tear which causes distal migration of the long head of biceps muscle.

Incorrect Options:

Griesinger sign: Refers to edema and tenderness over the mastoid seen in mastoiditis.

Rising sun sign: Radiological term used in epidural hematoma on CT scan or sometimes otoscopy in CSF leak-not related to biceps or orthopedic swelling.

Reference: internet: website radiopaedia.org

questions.text: An infant has paroxysms of nocturnal cough with fever. The child also has chest retractions, gasping and cyanosis. TLC is 50000 with lymphocytosis. Management?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture with paroxysmal cough, chest retractions, gasping, cyanosis, and very high TLC with lymphocytosis is characteristic of pertussis (whooping cough) caused by Bordetella pertussis.

Macrolides like azithromycin are the first-line treatment as they eradicate the organism, reduce transmission, and improve symptoms.

Among macrolides, azithromycin is preferred in infants due to better tolerability and shorter course.

Incorrect Options:

A) Cotrimoxazole: Not the first-line drug for pertussis; used in other infections like Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

B) Amoxicillin: Ineffective against Bordetella pertussis as it is a gram-negative organism resistant to beta-lactams in this case.

D) Clarithromycin: Also effective for pertussis but less preferred than azithromycin due to longer treatment duration and more GI side effects.

Key Takeaways:-

questions.text:
Episiotomy incision extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body.

Which structure is damaged ?
questions.solution:
If a medial episiotomy incision is extended beyond the perineal body, it involves the external anal sphincter and leads to fecal incontinence.


The anatomic structures involved in a mediolateral episiotomy include the vaginal epithelium, transverse perineal muscle, bulbocavernosus muscle and perineal skin. A deep or large mediolateral episiotomy may expose the ischiorectal fossa.

choices.text: Only C and D are true
Only A and B are true

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about alpha 1 Antitrypsin?

A. Inhibits elastase
B. Deficiency is associated with pan acinar emphysema
C. Inhibits trypsin activating protease
D. Coded by PiMM gene
questions.solution:
A, B, D are true:

  • (A) Inhibits elastase: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) primarily inhibits neutrophil elastase, which is responsible for breaking down lung tissue. By inhibiting elastase, AAT protects the lung from damage.
  • (B) Deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is strongly associated with panacinar emphysema, a type of emphysema where the entire acinus is affected, particularly in the lower lobes of the lungs.
  • (D) Coded by PiMM gene: The PiMM genotype represents normal alpha-1 antitrypsin levels. Deficiency of AAT is associated with genotypes like PiZZ, leading to lung and liver diseases.

Incorrect Options Explained:

(C) Inhibits trypsin activating protease: AAT primarily inhibits elastase and does not inhibit trypsin-activating protease. Its primary function is to protect lung tissue from degradation by elastase, which is released by neutrophils.

Key Takeaway:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin inhibits elastase, and its deficiency is linked to panacinar emphysema. The normal form of the gene is PiMM.

questions.text: Bilirubin in serum can be measured by:
questions.solution:
Option A: Van den Bergh Reaction:

  • This is the colorimetric method for measuring serum bilirubin.
  • It involves the reaction of bilirubin with diazotized sulfanilic acid, forming a reddish-purple
  • It measures:
    • Direct bilirubin (conjugated) in the absence of methanol.
    • Total bilirubin in the presence of methanol.
    • The difference gives indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin.

Explanation of other Options:

Option B: Ehrlich's Reaction is used to detect urobilinogen in urine.

Option C: Schlesinger's Reaction is used to detect urobilin.

Option D: Fouchet's Reaction is used to detect bile pigment, like bilirubin, in urine.

questions.text: Cardiovascular findings in a patient were as follows: large 'a' wave on JVP, mid-diastolic murmur. Pedal edema. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Tricuspid Stenosis:

  • Large 'a' wave on JVP is seen in tricuspid stenosis due to increased resistance during right atrial contraction against a narrowed tricuspid valve.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur occurs as blood flows from the right atrium to right ventricle through a stenosed tricuspid valve, similar in timing to the murmur of mitral stenosis.
  • Pedal edema suggests right-sided heart involvement, commonly seen in tricuspid valve diseases.
  • These findings together (giant 'a' wave + mid-diastolic murmur + right-sided signs) specifically point to tricuspid stenosis.

Explanation of other options:

  • MS (Mitral Stenosis): Causes mid-diastolic murmur, but does not cause large 'a' wave in JVP (since it involves the left side); also, JVP is not typically elevated.
  • MR (Mitral Regurgitation): Causes a holosystolic murmur, not a mid-diastolic one. Also, it involves the left side, so JVP and pedal edema are not prominent features.
  • TR (Tricuspid Regurgitation): Associated with v waves, not large 'a' waves. Also causes a holosystolic murmur, not a mid-diastolic murmur.

Key Note:

Jugular venous pulse (JVP)- waveforms:


  • a wave-atrial contraction. Prominent in AV dissociation (cannon a wave) and tricuspid stenosis, absent in atrial fibrillation.
  • c wave-RV contraction (closed tricuspid valve bulging into atrium).
  • x descent-atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during the rapid ventricular ejection phase. Reduced or absent in tricuspid regurgitation and right HF because pressure gradients are reduced.
  • v wave-RA pressure due to volume against the closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent-RA emptying into RV. Prominent in constrictive pericarditis, absent in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Tetany will result from which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
Tetany is a condition marked by increased neuromuscular excitability and muscle spasms due to low ionized calcium levels in the plasma. It can result from:

  • Respiratory alkalosis:
    • Causes a rise in blood pH.
    • More calcium binds to plasma proteins (like albumin), reducing free ionized calcium.
    • This decreased ionized calcium leads to hyperexcitability of nerves and muscles, causing tetany.
  • Other causes include:
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hypomagnesemia

Explanation of other options:

a) Metabolic acidosis In acidosis, less calcium binds to proteins, increasing free ionized calcium, making tetany less likely.

c) Hyperoxemia High oxygen levels do not significantly affect calcium binding or ionized calcium levels.

d) Hypercalcemia Elevated calcium depresses neuromuscular excitability; it may cause cardiac arrhythmias, not tetany.

questions.text: In female, remnant of wolffian duct is present in
questions.solution:
In females, the Wolffian ducts (mesonephric ducts) mostly regress during embryonic development due to the absence of testosterone. However, remnants of the Wolffian duct persist in the broad ligament as small structures called Gartner's ducts or cysts. These remnants are typically asymptomatic but can sometimes form Gartner's duct cysts along the lateral vaginal wall or broad ligament area.



Incorrect Options:

B) Vagina:

  • The vagina primarily develops from the Mullerian (paramesonephric) ducts and the urogenital sinus, not from Wolffian duct remnants.

C) Ovarian ligament:

  • The ovarian ligament is a remnant of the cranial part of the gubernaculum, not related to Wolffian ducts.

D) Round ligament:

  • The round ligament of the uterus is also derived from the caudal part of the gubernaculum, not from Wolffian duct remnants.

questions.text: What is the Child-Pugh class for a patient with the following parameters: serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dL, serum albumin 3 g/dL, INR 2.0, mild ascites, and no encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis. The score is calculated based on five clinical and laboratory parameters:

  1. Serum bilirubin: 2.5 mg/dL → 2 points
  2. Serum albumin: 3.0 g/dL → 2 points
  3. INR: 2.0 → 2 points
  4. Ascites: Mild → 2 points
  5. Hepatic encephalopathy:None → 1 point

Total score = 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 1 = 9 points

Child-Pugh classification:

  • 5-6 points = Class A
  • 7-9 points = Class B
  • 10-15 points = Class C

There is no Class D in the Child-Pugh system.

So, this patient has Child-Pugh Class B cirrhosis.

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic artery and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply to which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
The common hepatic artery arises from the celiac trunk and gives rise to:

  • Right gastric artery, which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach (anastomoses with the left gastric artery).
  • Gastroduodenal artery, which gives rise to the right gastroepiploic artery that runs along the greater curvature of the stomach.

Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery will compromise blood flow through both Right gastric artery, and Right gastroepiploic artery.

Other arteries like the left gastric (from the celiac trunk) and short gastric arteries (from the splenic artery) are not directly dependent on the common hepatic artery.

  • The stomach has an arterial supply on both the lesser and greater curves . On the lesser curve, the left gastric artery, a branch of the coeliac axis, forms an anastomotic arcade with the right gastric artery, which arises from the common hepatic artery.
  • Branches of the left gastric artery pass up towards the cardia. The gastroduodenal artery, also a branch of the hepatic artery, passes behind the first part of the duodenum, which is highly relevant with respect to a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Here it divides into the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery and the right gastroepiploic artery.
  • The superior pancreaticoduodenal artery supplies the duodenum and pancreatic head and forms an anastomosis with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery, a branch of the superior mesenteric artery.
  • The right gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach, eventually forming an anastomosis with the left gastroepiploic artery, a branch of the splenic artery.
  • This vascular arcade, important during construction of a gastric conduit in oesophageal resection is often variably incomplete.
  • The fundus of the stomach is supplied by the vasa brevia (or short gastric arteries), which arise from near the termination of the splenic artery.

B. Right gastric and left gastric artery - The left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk, not the common hepatic artery.

C. Right gastroepiploic artery and short gastric arteries - The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery, which is unaffected by common hepatic artery ligation.

D. Right gastric and short gastric arteries - The right gastric is affected, but the short gastrics are supplied via the splenic artery.

questions.text: Chromosome number of partial hydatidiform mole is:
questions.solution:
69XXX: A partial hydatidiform mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease characterized by an abnormal pregnancy where the fetus is usually not viable. It has a triploid karyotype, typically 69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY. This results from fertilization of an egg with two sperm, leading to three sets of chromosomes. The mole consists of abnormal placental tissue, often with some fetal development, but it cannot progress to a viable pregnancy.

Incorrect Options Explained:

  • (A) 46XX and (B) 46XY: These karyotypes are typically seen in normal pregnancies, with 46 chromosomes (23 pairs) corresponding to normal female (XX) or male (XY) chromosomes. A partial hydatidiform mole involves an extra set of chromosomes, not a normal diploid number.
  • (D) Any of the above: This is incorrect because only a triploid set of chromosomes, as seen in option C, is associated with a partial hydatidiform mole.

Key Takeaway: A partial hydatidiform mole is triploid with a chromosome number of 69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY, reflecting the extra chromosomal material from fertilization by two sperm

questions.text: On removal of the submandibular gland and its duct, which of the following nerves is most commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The lingual nerve runs in close proximity to the submandibular duct and is especially vulnerable during surgical removal of the submandibular gland or its duct. Injury may result in loss of general sensation and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Nerves injured in submandibular gland surgery:

2 superficial nerves :

  • Marginal mandibular nerve branch of facial nerve
  • Cervical branch of facial nerve

2 deep nerves:

  • Lingual nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve

Submandibular gland duct is in very close relation with LINGUAL NERVE >> HYPOGLOSSAL NERVE, so lingual injury is more common during removal of submandibular gland and duct

B. Though the hypoglossal nerve also lies deep to the gland, it is not as intimately related to the duct and is less commonly injured.

C. The inferior alveolar nerve lies deeper within the mandible and is not at direct risk during this surgery.

D. The nerve to mylohyoid, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve, is more lateral and inferior and not typically endangered during dissection near the duct.
